title.raw: 《高祖本紀》 Annals of Gao Zu

sentences.zh: 高祖，沛豐邑中陽裏人，姓劉氏，字季。

translations.literal: Gao Zu was from Zhongyangli in Feng township, Pei, with the surname Liu and given name Ji.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Gaozu was born in Zhongyang Village, Feng Township, Pei County. His surname was Liu, and his given name was Ji.

sentences.zh: 父曰太公，母曰劉媼。

translations.literal: His father was called the Grand Duke; his mother was called Dame Liu.
translations.idiomatic: His father was known as the Grand Duke, and his mother as Dame Liu.

sentences.zh: 其先劉媼嘗息大澤之陂，夢與神遇。

translations.literal: Previously his mother Dame Liu was resting by the embankment of a great marsh and dreamed she encountered a spirit.
translations.idiomatic: Earlier, his mother Dame Liu had been resting by the dike of a great marsh when she dreamed she encountered a spirit.

sentences.zh: 是時雷電晦冥，太公往視，則見蛟龍於其上。

translations.literal: At that time there was thunder and lightning with darkness; the Grand Duke went to look and saw a scaly dragon above her.
translations.idiomatic: At that moment, thunder crashed and lightning flashed in the darkness. The Grand Duke went to check and saw a horned dragon hovering above her.

sentences.zh: 已而有身，遂產高祖。

translations.literal: Soon after she became pregnant and gave birth to Gao Zu.
translations.idiomatic: Soon after, she became pregnant and gave birth to Emperor Gaozu.

translations.literal: Gao Zu was from Zhongyangli in Feng township, Pei, with the surname Liu and given name Ji. His father was called the Grand Duke; his mother was called Dame Liu. Previously his mother Dame Liu was resting by the embankment of a great marsh and dreamed she encountered a spirit. At that time there was thunder and lightning with darkness; the Grand Duke went to look and saw a scaly dragon above her. Soon after she became pregnant and gave birth to Gao Zu.

sentences.zh: 高祖為人，隆準而龍顏，美須髯，左股有七十二黑子。

translations.literal: Gao Zu as a person had a high-bridged nose and dragon-like countenance, fine whiskers and beard, and seventy-two black moles on his left thigh.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Gaozu had a high-bridged nose and dragon-like features, with fine whiskers and beard. On his left thigh were seventy-two black moles.

sentences.zh: 仁而愛人，喜施，意豁如也。

translations.literal: He was benevolent and loved people, delighted in giving, and his spirit was open and expansive.
translations.idiomatic: He was benevolent and loved people, took delight in generosity, and had an open, expansive spirit.

sentences.zh: 常有大度，不事家人生產作業。

translations.literal: He always had a generous nature and did not attend to his family's productive work.
translations.idiomatic: He always had a generous disposition and paid no attention to his family's farming and labor.

sentences.zh: 及壯，試為吏，為泗水亭長，廷中吏無所不狎侮，好酒及色。

translations.literal: When he grew up, he tested for official service and became Pavilion Head of Sishui; among the clerks of the court there was none he did not treat familiarly or make sport of; he loved wine and women.
translations.idiomatic: When he came of age, he took the civil service exam and became Pavilion Chief of Sishui County. Among the court clerks, there was none he didn't treat familiarly or tease. He loved wine and women.

sentences.zh: 常從王媼、武負貰酒，醉臥，武負、王媼見其上常有龍，怪之。

translations.literal: He often bought wine on credit from Dame Wang and Wu Fu; when drunk and lying down, Wu Fu and Dame Wang saw that above him there was always a dragon—they found this strange.
translations.idiomatic: He often bought wine on credit from Dame Wang and Wu Fu. When drunk and lying down, Wu Fu and Dame Wang saw a dragon always hovering above him—they found this very strange.

sentences.zh: 高祖每酤留飲，酒讎數倍。

translations.literal: Whenever Gao Zu bought and lingered drinking, the wine debt would be multiplied several times.
translations.idiomatic: Whenever Emperor Gaozu bought wine and lingered drinking, his tab would multiply several times over.

sentences.zh: 及見怪，歲竟，此兩家常折券棄責。

translations.literal: When they saw these strange signs, at year's end these two households would always tear up the debt markers and forgive the debt.
translations.idiomatic: But when they saw these strange signs, at year's end both households would tear up the IOUs and forgive his debts.

translations.literal: Gao Zu as a person had a high-bridged nose and dragon-like countenance, fine whiskers and beard, and seventy-two black moles on his left thigh. He was benevolent and loved people, delighted in giving, and his spirit was open and expansive. He always had a generous nature and did not attend to his family's productive work. When he grew up, he tested for official service and became Pavilion Head of Sishui; among the clerks of the court there was none he did not treat familiarly or make sport of; he loved wine and women. He often bought wine on credit from Dame Wang and Wu Fu; when drunk and lying down, Wu Fu and Dame Wang saw that above him there was always a dragon—they found this strange. Whenever Gao Zu bought and lingered drinking, the wine debt would be multiplied several times. When they saw these strange signs, at year's end these two households would always tear up the debt markers and forgive the debt.

sentences.zh: 高祖常繇咸陽，縱觀，觀秦皇帝，喟然太息曰：「嗟乎，大丈夫當如此也！」

translations.literal: Gao Zu once went on corvée duty to Xianyang and took the opportunity to observe; seeing the Emperor of Qin, he sighed deeply and said: "Ah, a great man should be like this!"
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Gaozu once went on corvée labor to Xianyang and took the chance to observe the sights. When he saw the Emperor of Qin, he sighed deeply and said: 'Ah, a true man should be like this!'

translations.literal: Gao Zu once went on corvée duty to Xianyang and took the opportunity to observe; seeing the Emperor of Qin, he sighed deeply and said: "Ah, a great man should be like this!"

sentences.zh: 單父人呂公善沛令，避仇從之客，因家沛焉。

translations.literal: Lü Gong of Shanfu was on good terms with the Pei magistrate; fleeing from a vendetta he came to lodge with him and consequently made his home in Pei.
translations.idiomatic: Lü Gong of Shanfu was on good terms with the Pei county magistrate. Fleeing a feud, he came to stay with him and eventually settled in Pei.

sentences.zh: 沛中豪桀吏聞令有重客，皆往賀。

translations.literal: The heroic gentlemen and officials of Pei heard that the magistrate had an important guest and all went to offer congratulations.
translations.idiomatic: The local worthies and officials of Pei heard the magistrate had an important guest and all came to offer congratulations.

sentences.zh: 蕭何為主吏，主進，令諸大夫曰：「進不滿千錢，坐之堂下。」

translations.literal: Xiao He was the supervising clerk in charge of reception; he issued orders to all the gentlemen saying: "Those whose gifts are less than a thousand cash shall sit in the lower hall."
translations.idiomatic: Xiao He, as chief clerk overseeing the reception, issued orders to all the gentlemen: 'Those whose congratulatory gifts are less than a thousand cash shall sit in the lower hall.'

sentences.zh: 高祖為亭長，素易諸吏，乃紿為謁曰「賀錢萬」，實不持一錢。

translations.literal: Gao Zu as Pavilion Head had always treated the officials casually, so he falsely wrote on his visiting card 'Gift of ten thousand cash,' though he actually carried not a single coin.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Gaozu, as pavilion chief, had always treated officials casually. So he boldly wrote on his calling card 'Congratulatory gift: ten thousand cash,' though he actually brought not a single coin.

sentences.zh: 謁入，呂公大驚，起，迎之門。

translations.literal: When the card was sent in, Lü Gong was greatly surprised, rose, and welcomed him at the gate.
translations.idiomatic: When the calling card was presented, Lü Gong was greatly astonished. He rose and went out to welcome him at the gate.

sentences.zh: 呂公者，好相人，見高祖狀貌，因重敬之，引入坐。

translations.literal: Lü Gong liked reading people's physiognomy; seeing Gao Zu's appearance, he consequently held him in high regard, invited him in, and seated him.
translations.idiomatic: Lü Gong was fond of reading physiognomy. Seeing Emperor Gaozu's features, he came to hold him in great respect, invited him inside, and seated him.

sentences.zh: 蕭何曰：「劉季固多大言，少成事。」

translations.literal: Xiao He said: "Liu Ji is always full of grand talk but accomplishes little."
translations.idiomatic: Xiao He said: 'Liu Ji is certainly full of big talk but accomplishes little.'

sentences.zh: 高祖因狎侮諸客，遂坐上坐，無所詘。

translations.literal: Gao Zu then treated the guests familiarly and sat in the seat of honor without any humility.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Gaozu then treated all the guests familiarly and took the seat of honor without any deference.

sentences.zh: 酒闌，呂公因目固留高祖。

translations.literal: When wine was exhausted, Lü Gong signaled with eyes to firmly keep Gao Zu.
translations.idiomatic: As the wine flowed and the banquet wound down, Lü Gong signaled with his eyes to firmly detain Emperor Gaozu.

sentences.zh: 高祖竟酒，後。

translations.literal: Gao Zu finished the wine and remained after.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Gaozu finished his wine and stayed behind after the others left.

sentences.zh: 呂公曰：「臣少好相人，相人多矣，無如季相，願季自愛。

translations.literal: Lü Gong said: "I have long liked reading physiognomy and have read many people, but none compare to Ji's; I hope Ji will take care of himself.
translations.idiomatic: Lü Gong said: 'I have long enjoyed reading physiognomy and have read many people, but none can compare to Ji's features. I hope Ji will take good care of himself.'

sentences.zh: 臣有息女，願為季箕帚妾。」

translations.literal: I have a daughter and wish her to be Ji's humble wife."
translations.idiomatic: I have a daughter and wish her to be Ji's humble wife.''

sentences.zh: 酒罷，呂媼怒呂公曰：「公始常欲奇此女，與貴人。

translations.literal: When the wine ended, Dame Lü was angry at Lü Gong, saying: "You always wanted to treat this daughter as exceptional and give her to a noble person.
translations.idiomatic: After the banquet ended, Dame Lü angrily rebuked Lü Gong: 'You always wanted to treat this daughter as special and marry her to a nobleman.'

sentences.zh: 沛令善公，求之不與，何自妄許與劉季？」

translations.literal: The Pei magistrate is on good terms with you and sought her but you did not give her—why do you rashly promise her to Liu Ji?"
translations.idiomatic: The Pei county magistrate is on good terms with you and asked for her, but you refused. Why do you rashly promise her to Liu Ji?''

sentences.zh: 呂公曰：「此非兒女子所知也。」

translations.literal: Lü Gong said: "This is not something children and women can understand."
translations.idiomatic: Lü Gong said: 'This is not something for children and women to understand.''

sentences.zh: 卒與劉季。

translations.literal: He finally gave her to Liu Ji.
translations.idiomatic: In the end, he gave her to Liu Ji.

sentences.zh: 呂公女乃呂后也，生孝惠帝、魯元公主。

translations.literal: Lü Gong's daughter was Empress Lü; she gave birth to Emperor Xiaohui and Princess Lu Yuan.
translations.idiomatic: Lü Gong's daughter became Empress Lü. She gave birth to Emperor Xiaohui and Princess Lu Yuan.

translations.literal: Lü Gong of Shanfu was on good terms with the Pei magistrate; fleeing from a vendetta he came to lodge with him and consequently made his home in Pei. The heroic gentlemen and officials of Pei heard that the magistrate had an important guest and all went to offer congratulations. Xiao He was the supervising clerk in charge of reception; he issued orders to all the gentlemen saying: "Those whose gifts are less than a thousand cash shall sit in the lower hall." Gao Zu as Pavilion Head had always treated the officials casually, so he falsely wrote on his visiting card 'Gift of ten thousand cash,' though he actually carried not a single coin. When the card was sent in, Lü Gong was greatly surprised, rose, and welcomed him at the gate. Lü Gong liked reading people's physiognomy; seeing Gao Zu's appearance, he consequently held him in high regard, invited him in, and seated him. Xiao He said: "Liu Ji is always full of grand talk but accomplishes little." Gao Zu then treated the guests familiarly and sat in the seat of honor without any humility. When wine was exhausted, Lü Gong signaled with eyes to firmly keep Gao Zu. Gao Zu finished the wine and remained after. Lü Gong said: "I have long liked reading physiognomy and have read many people, but none compare to Ji's; I hope Ji will take care of himself. I have a daughter and wish her to be Ji's humble wife." When the wine ended, Dame Lü was angry at Lü Gong, saying: "You always wanted to treat this daughter as exceptional and give her to a noble person. The Pei magistrate is on good terms with you and sought her but you did not give her—why do you rashly promise her to Liu Ji?" Lü Gong said: "This is not something children and women can understand." He finally gave her to Liu Ji. Lü Gong's daughter was Empress Lü; she gave birth to Emperor Xiaohui and Princess Lu Yuan.

sentences.zh: 高祖為亭長時，常告歸之田。

translations.literal: When Gao Zu was Pavilion Head, he would often request leave to return to his fields.
translations.idiomatic: When Emperor Gaozu was pavilion chief, he would often request leave to return to his farm.

sentences.zh: 呂后與兩子居田中耨，有一老父過請飲，呂后因餔之。

translations.literal: Empress Lü with her two children were in the fields weeding when an old man passed by and requested a drink; Empress Lü consequently fed him.
translations.idiomatic: Empress Lü was in the fields weeding with her two children when an old man passed by and asked for a drink. Empress Lü fed him.

sentences.zh: 老父相呂后曰：「夫人天下貴人。」

translations.literal: The old man read Empress Lü's physiognomy and said: "Madam will be the most noble person under Heaven."
translations.idiomatic: The old man read Empress Lü's physiognomy and said: 'Madam will be the most noble person in the world.''

sentences.zh: 令相兩子，見孝惠，曰：「夫人所以貴者，乃此男也。」

translations.literal: He asked to read the two children's physiognomy; seeing Xiaohui, he said: "The reason Madam will be noble is because of this boy."
translations.idiomatic: He asked to read the physiognomy of both children. Looking at Xiaohui, he said: 'The reason Madam will be noble is this boy.''

sentences.zh: 相魯元，亦皆貴。

translations.literal: Reading Lu Yuan's physiognomy, she would also be noble.
translations.idiomatic: Reading Lu Yuan's physiognomy, he said she would also be noble.

sentences.zh: 老父已去，高祖適從旁舍來，呂后具言客有過，相我子母皆大貴。

translations.literal: After the old man left, Gao Zu happened to come from a neighboring house; Empress Lü fully told him that a guest had passed by and read the physiognomy of her and the children, all predicting great nobility.
translations.idiomatic: After the old man left, Emperor Gaozu happened to come from a neighboring house. Empress Lü told him in detail that a guest had passed by and read the physiognomy of her and the children, predicting great nobility for all of them.

sentences.zh: 高祖問，曰：「未遠。」

translations.literal: Gao Zu asked where he was; she said: "Not far."
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Gaozu asked where he was. She said: 'Not far.''

sentences.zh: 乃追及，問老父。

translations.literal: He then pursued and caught up with the old man and questioned him.
translations.idiomatic: He then pursued and caught up with the old man, questioning him.

sentences.zh: 老父曰：「鄉者夫人嬰兒皆似君，君相貴不可言。」

translations.literal: The old man said: "Earlier your wife and children all resemble you; your physiognomy indicates nobility beyond description."
translations.idiomatic: The old man said: 'Earlier your wife and children all resemble you. Your physiognomy indicates nobility beyond description.''

sentences.zh: 高祖乃謝曰：「誠如父言，不敢忘德。」

translations.literal: Gao Zu then bowed and said: "If it is truly as you say, I dare not forget this kindness."
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Gaozu then bowed and said: 'If it is truly as you say, I dare not forget this kindness.''

sentences.zh: 及高祖貴，遂不知老父處。

translations.literal: When Gao Zu became noble, they never found where the old man was.
translations.idiomatic: When Emperor Gaozu became noble, they could never find where the old man was.

translations.literal: When Gao Zu was Pavilion Head, he would often request leave to return to his fields. Empress Lü with her two children were in the fields weeding when an old man passed by and requested a drink; Empress Lü consequently fed him. The old man read Empress Lü's physiognomy and said: "Madam will be the most noble person under Heaven." He asked to read the two children's physiognomy; seeing Xiaohui, he said: "The reason Madam will be noble is because of this boy." Reading Lu Yuan's physiognomy, she would also be noble. After the old man left, Gao Zu happened to come from a neighboring house; Empress Lü fully told him that a guest had passed by and read the physiognomy of her and the children, all predicting great nobility. Gao Zu asked where he was; she said: "Not far." He then pursued and caught up with the old man and questioned him. The old man said: "Earlier your wife and children all resemble you; your physiognomy indicates nobility beyond description." Gao Zu then bowed and said: "If it is truly as you say, I dare not forget this kindness." When Gao Zu became noble, they never found where the old man was.

sentences.zh: 高祖為亭長，乃以竹皮為冠，令求盜之薛治之，時時冠之，及貴常冠，所謂「劉氏冠」乃是也。

translations.literal: When Gao Zu was Pavilion Head, he made a cap of bamboo bark and had the cap-maker of Xue craft it; he wore it from time to time, and when he became noble he always wore it—the so-called 'Liu cap' is this.
translations.idiomatic: When Emperor Gaozu was pavilion chief, he made a hat from bamboo bark and had the hat-maker of Xue craft it. He wore it from time to time, and when he became noble he always wore it. This is the so-called 'Liu hat.''

translations.literal: When Gao Zu was Pavilion Head, he made a cap of bamboo bark and had the cap-maker of Xue craft it; he wore it from time to time, and when he became noble he always wore it—the so-called 'Liu cap' is this.

sentences.zh: 高祖以亭長為縣送徒酈山，徒多道亡。

translations.literal: As Pavilion Head, Gao Zu escorted convicts for the county to Mount Li; many escaped on the road.
translations.idiomatic: As pavilion chief, Emperor Gaozu escorted convicts for the county to Mount Li. Many escaped along the way.

sentences.zh: 自度比至皆亡之，到豐西澤中，止飲，夜乃解縱所送徒。

translations.literal: He estimated that by the time they arrived all would have fled, so reaching the marshes west of Feng, he stopped to drink, and at night released all the convicts he was escorting.
translations.idiomatic: He estimated that by the time they arrived, all would have fled. Reaching the marshes west of Feng, he stopped to drink, and at night released all the convicts he was escorting.

sentences.zh: 曰：「公等皆去，吾亦從此逝矣！」

translations.literal: He said: "You may all go; I too will depart from here!"
translations.idiomatic: He said: 'You may all go. I too will depart from here!''

sentences.zh: 徒中壯士願從者十餘人。

translations.literal: Among the convicts over ten brave men wished to follow him.
translations.idiomatic: Among the convicts, over ten brave men wished to follow him.

sentences.zh: 高祖被酒，夜徑澤中，令一人行前。

translations.literal: Gao Zu, intoxicated, traveled by night through the marshes and ordered one man to go ahead.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Gaozu, intoxicated, traveled by night through the marshes and ordered one man to go ahead.

sentences.zh: 行前者還報曰：「前有大蛇當徑，願還。」

translations.literal: The man going ahead returned and reported: "There is a great snake blocking the path ahead; we should turn back."
translations.idiomatic: The man going ahead returned and reported: 'There is a great snake blocking the path ahead. We should turn back.''

sentences.zh: 高祖醉，曰：「壯士行，何畏！」

translations.literal: Gao Zu, drunk, said: "A brave man goes forward—what is there to fear!"
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Gaozu, drunk, said: 'A brave man goes forward—what is there to fear!''

sentences.zh: 乃前，拔劍擊斬蛇。

translations.literal: He then went forward, drew his sword, and struck and beheaded the snake.
translations.idiomatic: He then went forward, drew his sword, and struck and beheaded the snake.

sentences.zh: 蛇遂分為兩，徑開。

translations.literal: The snake was split in two and the path opened.
translations.idiomatic: The snake split in two and the path opened.

sentences.zh: 行數里，醉，因臥。

translations.literal: After traveling several li, drunk, he lay down to sleep.
translations.idiomatic: After traveling several li, drunk, he lay down to sleep.

sentences.zh: 後人來至蛇所，有一老嫗夜哭。

translations.literal: People coming after arrived at the snake's location; there was an old woman crying at night.
translations.idiomatic: People coming later arrived at where the snake had been; there was an old woman crying at night.

sentences.zh: 人問何哭，嫗曰：「人殺吾子，故哭之。」

translations.literal: People asked why she cried; the old woman said: "Someone killed my son, therefore I cry."
translations.idiomatic: People asked why she cried. The old woman said: 'Someone killed my son, therefore I cry.''

sentences.zh: 人曰：「嫗子何為見殺？」

translations.literal: People said: "Why was your son killed?"
translations.idiomatic: People said: 'Why was your son killed?''

sentences.zh: 嫗曰：「吾，白帝子也，化為蛇，當道，今為赤帝子斬之，故哭。」

translations.literal: The old woman said: "My son is the son of the White Emperor; he transformed into a snake and blocked the road; now he was beheaded by the son of the Red Emperor, therefore I cry."
translations.idiomatic: The old woman said: 'My son is the son of the White Emperor. He transformed into a snake and blocked the road. Now he was beheaded by the son of the Red Emperor, therefore I cry.''

sentences.zh: 人乃以嫗為不誠，欲告之，嫗因忽不見。

translations.literal: People thought the old woman was lying and wanted to punish her, but the old woman suddenly disappeared.
translations.idiomatic: People thought the old woman was lying and wanted to report her, but the old woman suddenly disappeared.

sentences.zh: 後人至，高祖覺。

translations.literal: When the people behind arrived, Gao Zu awoke.
translations.idiomatic: When the people behind arrived, Emperor Gaozu awoke.

sentences.zh: 後人告高祖，高祖乃心獨喜，自負。

translations.literal: The people behind told Gao Zu; Gao Zu was secretly delighted in his heart and felt self-assured.
translations.idiomatic: The people behind told Emperor Gaozu. He was secretly delighted in his heart and felt self-assured.

sentences.zh: 諸從者日益畏之。

translations.literal: Those who followed him grew daily more in awe of him.
translations.idiomatic: Those who followed him grew daily more in awe of him.

translations.literal: As Pavilion Head, Gao Zu escorted convicts for the county to Mount Li; many escaped on the road. He estimated that by the time they arrived all would have fled, so reaching the marshes west of Feng, he stopped to drink, and at night released all the convicts he was escorting. He said: "You may all go; I too will depart from here!" Among the convicts over ten brave men wished to follow him. Gao Zu, intoxicated, traveled by night through the marshes and ordered one man to go ahead. The man going ahead returned and reported: "There is a great snake blocking the path ahead; we should turn back." Gao Zu, drunk, said: "A brave man goes forward—what is there to fear!" He then went forward, drew his sword, and struck and beheaded the snake. The snake was split in two and the path opened. After traveling several li, drunk, he lay down to sleep. People coming after arrived at the snake's location; there was an old woman crying at night. People asked why she cried; the old woman said: "Someone killed my son, therefore I cry." People said: "Why was your son killed?" The old woman said: "My son is the son of the White Emperor; he transformed into a snake and blocked the road; now he was beheaded by the son of the Red Emperor, therefore I cry." People thought the old woman was lying and wanted to punish her, but the old woman suddenly disappeared. When the people behind arrived, Gao Zu awoke. The people behind told Gao Zu; Gao Zu was secretly delighted in his heart and felt self-assured. Those who followed him grew daily more in awe of him.

sentences.zh: 秦始皇帝常曰「東南有天子氣」，於是因東游以厭之。

translations.literal: The First Emperor of Qin often said "In the southeast there is the qi of a Son of Heaven," and consequently made eastern tours to suppress it.
translations.idiomatic: The First Emperor of Qin often said: 'In the southeast there is the qi of a Son of Heaven.' Consequently, he made eastern tours to suppress it.

sentences.zh: 高祖即自疑，亡匿，隱於芒、碭山澤巖石之閒。

translations.literal: Gao Zu then suspected it was himself, fled and hid, concealing himself among the cliffs and rocks of the marshes and mountains of Mang and Dang.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Gaozu then suspected it referred to himself. He fled and hid, concealing himself among the cliffs and rocks of the marshes and mountains of Mang and Dang.

sentences.zh: 呂后與人俱求，常得之。

translations.literal: Empress Lü with others sought him and always found him.
translations.idiomatic: Empress Lü searched for him along with others and always found him.

sentences.zh: 高祖怪問之。

translations.literal: Gao Zu found this strange and questioned her.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Gaozu found this strange and questioned her.

sentences.zh: 呂后曰：「季所居上常有雲氣，故從往常得季。」

translations.literal: Empress Lü said: "Where Ji resides there is always cloud qi above, so following it I always find Ji."
translations.idiomatic: Empress Lü said: 'Where Ji resides, there is always cloud qi above. By following it, I always find Ji.''

sentences.zh: 高祖心喜。

translations.literal: Gao Zu was pleased in his heart.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Gaozu was pleased in his heart.

sentences.zh: 沛中子弟或聞之，多欲附者矣。

translations.literal: Some of the young men of Pei heard of this and many wished to attach themselves to him.
translations.idiomatic: Some of the young men of Pei heard of this and many wished to attach themselves to him.

translations.literal: The First Emperor of Qin often said "In the southeast there is the qi of a Son of Heaven," and consequently made eastern tours to suppress it. Gao Zu then suspected it was himself, fled and hid, concealing himself among the cliffs and rocks of the marshes and mountains of Mang and Dang. Empress Lü with others sought him and always found him. Gao Zu found this strange and questioned her. Empress Lü said: "Where Ji resides there is always cloud qi above, so following it I always find Ji." Gao Zu was pleased in his heart. Some of the young men of Pei heard of this and many wished to attach themselves to him.

sentences.zh: 秦二世元年秋，陳勝等起蘄，至陳而王，號為「張楚」。

translations.literal: In autumn of the first year of the Second Emperor of Qin, Chen Sheng and others arose at Qi, reached Chen and became king, with the title 'Zhang Chu.'
translations.idiomatic: In the autumn of the first year of Qin's Second Emperor, Chen Sheng and others rose up at Qi. They reached Chen and he became king, taking the title 'Zhang Chu.'

sentences.zh: 諸郡縣皆多殺其長吏以應陳涉。

translations.literal: The commanderies and counties mostly all killed their magistrates to respond to Chen She.
translations.idiomatic: The commanderies and counties mostly killed their chief officials to respond to Chen She.

sentences.zh: 沛令恐，欲以沛應涉。

translations.literal: The Pei magistrate was afraid and wished to have Pei respond to She.
translations.idiomatic: The Pei county magistrate was afraid and wished to have Pei respond to Chen She.

sentences.zh: 掾、主吏蕭何、曹參乃曰：「君為秦吏，今欲背之，率沛子弟，恐不聽。

translations.literal: Assistant clerks and supervising officials Xiao He and Cao Can then said: "You are a Qin official; now if you wish to betray it and lead the sons and younger brothers of Pei, I fear they will not obey.
translations.idiomatic: Assistant clerks and supervising officials Xiao He and Cao Can then said: 'You are a Qin official. Now if you wish to betray Qin and lead the young men of Pei, I fear they will not obey.''

sentences.zh: 願君召諸亡在外者，可得數百人，因劫眾，眾不敢不聽。」

translations.literal: We hope you will summon those who are fugitives outside—you can obtain several hundred men to coerce the masses, and the masses will not dare disobey."
translations.idiomatic: We hope you will summon the fugitives outside. You can obtain several hundred men to coerce the masses, and the masses will not dare disobey.''

sentences.zh: 乃令樊噲召劉季。

translations.literal: He then ordered Fan Kuai to summon Liu Ji.
translations.idiomatic: He then ordered Fan Kuai to summon Liu Ji.

sentences.zh: 劉季之眾已數十百人矣。

translations.literal: Liu Ji's followers already numbered several tens or hundreds.
translations.idiomatic: Liu Ji's followers already numbered dozens or hundreds.

translations.literal: In autumn of the first year of the Second Emperor of Qin, Chen Sheng and others arose at Qi, reached Chen and became king, with the title 'Zhang Chu.' The commanderies and counties mostly all killed their magistrates to respond to Chen She. The Pei magistrate was afraid and wished to have Pei respond to She. Assistant clerks and supervising officials Xiao He and Cao Can then said: "You are a Qin official; now if you wish to betray it and lead the sons and younger brothers of Pei, I fear they will not obey. We hope you will summon those who are fugitives outside—you can obtain several hundred men to coerce the masses, and the masses will not dare disobey." He then ordered Fan Kuai to summon Liu Ji. Liu Ji's followers already numbered several tens or hundreds.

sentences.zh: 於是樊噲從劉季來。

translations.literal: Thereupon Fan Kuai followed Liu Ji and came.
translations.idiomatic: Thereupon Fan Kuai went with Liu Ji and came.

sentences.zh: 沛令後悔，恐其有變，乃閉城城守，欲誅蕭、曹。

translations.literal: The Pei magistrate later regretted it, fearing there would be trouble, so he closed the city gates to defend the city and wished to execute Xiao and Cao.
translations.idiomatic: The Pei magistrate later regretted his decision, fearing trouble would arise. He closed the city gates to defend the city and wanted to execute Xiao He and Cao Can.

sentences.zh: 蕭、曹恐，踰城保劉季。

translations.literal: Xiao and Cao were afraid and climbed over the wall to join Liu Ji.
translations.idiomatic: Xiao He and Cao Can were afraid and climbed over the city wall to join Liu Ji.

sentences.zh: 劉季乃書帛射城上，謂沛父老曰：「天下苦秦久矣。

translations.literal: Liu Ji then wrote on silk and shot it over the city wall, saying to the elders of Pei: "All under Heaven has long suffered under Qin.
translations.idiomatic: Liu Ji then wrote on silk and shot it over the city wall, telling the elders of Pei: 'All under Heaven has long suffered under Qin.''

sentences.zh: 今父老雖為沛令守，諸侯并起，今屠沛。

translations.literal: Now though the elders support the Pei magistrate in defending, the feudal lords are rising together and will now massacre Pei.
translations.idiomatic: Although you elders are defending for the Pei magistrate, the feudal lords are rising together and will now massacre Pei.'

sentences.zh: 沛今共誅令，擇子弟可立者立之，以應諸侯，則家室完。

translations.literal: If Pei now together executes the magistrate and chooses from among the sons and younger brothers one who can be installed and installs him to respond to the feudal lords, then households will be preserved intact.
translations.idiomatic: If Pei now together executes the magistrate and selects one of the young men to install as leader to respond to the feudal lords, then your households will be preserved intact.'

sentences.zh: 不然，父子俱屠，無為也。」

translations.literal: If not, fathers and sons will all be massacred—there is no point."
translations.idiomatic: Otherwise, fathers and sons will all be massacred—there is no point.''

sentences.zh: 父老乃率子弟共殺沛令，開城門迎劉季，欲以為沛令。

translations.literal: The elders then led the sons and younger brothers to together kill the Pei magistrate, opened the city gates, and welcomed Liu Ji, wishing to make him Pei magistrate.
translations.idiomatic: The elders then led the young men to kill the Pei magistrate together. They opened the city gates and welcomed Liu Ji, wanting to make him the Pei magistrate.

sentences.zh: 劉季曰：「天下方擾，諸侯并起，今置將不善，壹敗涂地。

translations.literal: Liu Ji said: "All under Heaven is in chaos; the feudal lords are rising together; now if we install a general who is not good, with one defeat all will be lost.
translations.idiomatic: Liu Ji said: 'All under Heaven is in chaos. The feudal lords are rising together. If we install a general who is not competent, one defeat will destroy everything.''

sentences.zh: 吾非敢自愛，恐能薄，不能完父兄子弟。

translations.literal: It is not that I dare be selfish, but I fear my abilities are meager and I cannot keep safe the fathers, elder brothers, sons, and younger brothers.
translations.idiomatic: I'm not being selfish—I fear my abilities are insufficient and I cannot protect your fathers, brothers, sons, and families.''

sentences.zh: 此大事，願更相推擇可者。」

translations.literal: This is a great matter; I hope you will again recommend and choose someone suitable."
translations.idiomatic: This is a grave matter. I hope you will reconsider and choose someone more suitable.''

sentences.zh: 蕭、曹等皆文吏，自愛，恐事不就，後秦種族其家，盡讓劉季。

translations.literal: Xiao, Cao, and the others were all civil clerks who cherished themselves; fearing that if the affair did not succeed Qin would later exterminate their clans, they all deferred to Liu Ji.
translations.idiomatic: Xiao He, Cao Can, and the others were all civil officials who valued their own lives. Fearing that if the rebellion failed, Qin would later exterminate their clans, they all deferred to Liu Ji.

sentences.zh: 諸父老皆曰：「平生所聞劉季諸珍怪，當貴，且卜筮之，莫如劉季最吉。」

translations.literal: All the elders said: "Throughout life we have heard of the various strange and wondrous signs about Liu Ji; he should be noble; moreover, divining by oracle, none is as auspicious as Liu Ji."
translations.idiomatic: All the elders said: 'Throughout our lives we have heard of the various strange and wondrous signs about Liu Ji. He is destined for nobility. Moreover, divination shows that none is more auspicious than Liu Ji.''

sentences.zh: 於是劉季數讓。

translations.literal: Thereupon Liu Ji declined several times.
translations.idiomatic: Thereupon Liu Ji declined several times.

sentences.zh: 眾莫敢為，乃立季為沛公。

translations.literal: Since none of the multitude dared take it, they installed Ji as Duke of Pei.
translations.idiomatic: Since none of the multitude dared take the position, they installed Ji as Duke of Pei.

sentences.zh: 祠黃帝，祭蚩尤於沛庭，而釁鼓旗，幟皆赤。

translations.literal: They made offerings to the Yellow Emperor, sacrificed to Chiyou in the courtyard of Pei, and consecrated drums and flags—all banners were red.
translations.idiomatic: They made offerings to the Yellow Emperor and sacrificed to Chiyou in the Pei courtyard. They consecrated the drums and flags—all banners were red.

sentences.zh: 由所殺蛇白帝子，殺者赤帝子，故上赤。

translations.literal: Because the snake he killed was the son of the White Emperor and the killer was the son of the Red Emperor, therefore they honored red.
translations.idiomatic: Because the snake he killed was the son of the White Emperor and the killer was the son of the Red Emperor, they honored red.

sentences.zh: 於是少年豪吏如蕭、曹、樊噲等皆為收沛子弟二三千人，攻胡陵、方與，還守豐。

translations.literal: Thereupon young heroes and officials like Xiao, Cao, and Fan Kuai all gathered two or three thousand sons and younger brothers of Pei, attacked Huling and Fangyu, and returned to defend Feng.
translations.idiomatic: Thereupon young heroes and officials like Xiao He, Cao Can, and Fan Kuai gathered two or three thousand young men from Pei. They attacked Huling and Fangyu, then returned to defend Feng.

translations.literal: Thereupon Fan Kuai followed Liu Ji and came. The Pei magistrate later regretted it, fearing there would be trouble, so he closed the city gates to defend the city and wished to execute Xiao and Cao. Xiao and Cao were afraid and climbed over the wall to join Liu Ji. Liu Ji then wrote on silk and shot it over the city wall, saying to the elders of Pei: "All under Heaven has long suffered under Qin. Now though the elders support the Pei magistrate in defending, the feudal lords are rising together and will now massacre Pei. If Pei now together executes the magistrate and chooses from among the sons and younger brothers one who can be installed and installs him to respond to the feudal lords, then households will be preserved intact. If not, fathers and sons will all be massacred—there is no point." The elders then led the sons and younger brothers to together kill the Pei magistrate, opened the city gates, and welcomed Liu Ji, wishing to make him Pei magistrate. Liu Ji said: "All under Heaven is in chaos; the feudal lords are rising together; now if we install a general who is not good, with one defeat all will be lost. It is not that I dare be selfish, but I fear my abilities are meager and I cannot keep safe the fathers, elder brothers, sons, and younger brothers. This is a great matter; I hope you will again recommend and choose someone suitable." Xiao, Cao, and the others were all civil clerks who cherished themselves; fearing that if the affair did not succeed Qin would later exterminate their clans, they all deferred to Liu Ji. All the elders said: "Throughout life we have heard of the various strange and wondrous signs about Liu Ji; he should be noble; moreover, divining by oracle, none is as auspicious as Liu Ji." Thereupon Liu Ji declined several times. Since none of the multitude dared take it, they installed Ji as Duke of Pei. They made offerings to the Yellow Emperor, sacrificed to Chiyou in the courtyard of Pei, and consecrated drums and flags—all banners were red. Because the snake he killed was the son of the White Emperor and the killer was the son of the Red Emperor, therefore they honored red. Thereupon young heroes and officials like Xiao, Cao, and Fan Kuai all gathered two or three thousand sons and younger brothers of Pei, attacked Huling and Fangyu, and returned to defend Feng.

sentences.zh: 秦二世二年，陳涉之將周章軍西至戲而還。

translations.literal: In the second year of the Second Emperor of Qin, Chen She's general Zhou Zhang's army went west reaching Xi and returned.
translations.idiomatic: In the second year of Qin's Second Emperor, Chen She's general Zhou Zhang led his army west as far as Xi, then turned back.

sentences.zh: 燕、趙、齊、魏皆自立為王。

translations.literal: Yan, Zhao, Qi, and Wei all made themselves kings.
translations.idiomatic: Yan, Zhao, Qi, and Wei all proclaimed themselves kingdoms.

sentences.zh: 項氏起吳。

translations.literal: The Xiang clan arose in Wu.
translations.idiomatic: The Xiang clan rose up in Wu.

sentences.zh: 秦泗川監平將兵圍豐，二日，出與戰，破之。

translations.literal: The Supervisor of Sichuan, Ping, led troops to surround Feng for two days; they came out to do battle and broke them.
translations.idiomatic: The Qin supervisor of Sichuan, Ping, led troops to besiege Feng for two days. The defenders came out to fight and defeated them.

sentences.zh: 命雍齒守豐，引兵之薛。

translations.literal: He ordered Yong Chi to defend Feng and led his troops to Xue.
translations.idiomatic: He ordered Yong Chi to defend Feng and led his troops to Xue.

sentences.zh: 泗州守壯敗於薛，走至戚，沛公左司馬得泗川守壯，殺之。

translations.literal: The Administrator of Sizhou, Zhuang, was defeated at Xue and fled to Qi; the Duke of Pei's Left Major captured Administrator Zhuang of Sichuan and killed him.
translations.idiomatic: The Qin administrator of Sizhou, Zhuang, was defeated at Xue and fled to Qi. The Duke of Pei's Left Major captured Administrator Zhuang of Sichuan and killed him.

sentences.zh: 沛公還軍亢父，至方與，（周市來攻方與）未戰。

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei returned his army to Kangfu, reached Fangyu, and had not yet fought.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei returned his army to Kangfu and reached Fangyu, but had not yet fought.

sentences.zh: 陳王使魏人周市略地。

translations.literal: King Chen sent Zhou Shi of Wei to take territory.
translations.idiomatic: King Chen sent Zhou Shi of Wei to seize territory.

sentences.zh: 周市使人謂雍齒曰：「豐，故梁徙也。

translations.literal: Zhou Shi sent someone to say to Yong Chi: "Feng was formerly a Liang relocated town.
translations.idiomatic: Zhou Shi sent someone to tell Yong Chi: 'Feng was formerly a relocated town from Liang.'

sentences.zh: 今魏地已定者數十城。

translations.literal: Now the Wei territory that has been settled numbers several tens of cities.
translations.idiomatic: Wei has already pacified dozens of cities.'

sentences.zh: 齒今下魏，魏以齒為侯守豐。

translations.literal: If Chi now surrenders to Wei, Wei will make Chi a marquis defending Feng.
translations.idiomatic: If Yong Chi surrenders to Wei now, Wei will make him Marquis of Feng.'

sentences.zh: 不下，且屠豐。」

translations.literal: If you do not surrender, we will massacre Feng."
translations.idiomatic: If you don't surrender, we'll massacre Feng.''

sentences.zh: 雍齒雅不欲屬沛公，及魏招之，即反為魏守豐。

translations.literal: Yong Chi had long been unwilling to be subordinate to the Duke of Pei; when Wei recruited him, he immediately rebelled and defended Feng for Wei.
translations.idiomatic: Yong Chi had long been unwilling to serve under the Duke of Pei. When Wei recruited him, he immediately defected and defended Feng for Wei.

sentences.zh: 沛公引兵攻豐，不能取。

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei led troops to attack Feng but could not take it.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei led troops to attack Feng but could not capture it.

sentences.zh: 沛公病，還之沛。

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei fell ill and returned to Pei.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei fell ill and returned to Pei.

sentences.zh: 沛公怨雍齒與豐子弟叛之，聞東陽甯君、秦嘉立景駒為假王，在留，乃往從之，欲請兵以攻豐。

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei resented that Yong Chi and the sons and younger brothers of Feng had betrayed him; hearing that Lord Ning of Dongyang and Qin Jia had installed Jing Ju as Provisional King at Liu, he went to join them, wishing to request troops to attack Feng.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei resented Yong Chi and the young men of Feng for betraying him. Hearing that Lord Ning of Dongyang and Qin Jia had installed Jing Ju as Provisional King at Liu, he went to join them, hoping to request troops to attack Feng.

sentences.zh: 是時秦將章邯從陳，別將司馬夷將兵北定楚地，屠相，至碭。

translations.literal: At this time Qin general Zhang Han came from Chen; a separate general, Sima Yi, led troops to pacify Chu territory to the north, massacred Xiang, and reached Dang.
translations.idiomatic: At this time, Qin general Zhang Han came from Chen. A separate commander, Sima Yi, led troops to pacify northern Chu territory, massacred Xiang, and reached Dang.

sentences.zh: 東陽甯君、沛公引兵西，與戰蕭西，不利。

translations.literal: Lord Ning of Dongyang and the Duke of Pei led troops west and fought with them west of Xiao; it went unfavorably.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Ning of Dongyang and the Duke of Pei led troops west and fought Qin forces west of Xiao, but were defeated.

sentences.zh: 還收兵聚留，引兵攻碭，三日乃取碭。

translations.literal: They returned to gather troops and assembled at Liu, then led troops to attack Dang, taking it after three days.
translations.idiomatic: They retreated to gather troops and assembled at Liu, then led troops to attack Dang, capturing it after three days.

sentences.zh: 因收碭兵，得五六千人。

translations.literal: Consequently gathering Dang's troops, they obtained five or six thousand men.
translations.idiomatic: They consequently recruited troops from Dang, obtaining five or six thousand men.

sentences.zh: 攻下邑，拔之。

translations.literal: They attacked Xiayi and took it.
translations.idiomatic: They attacked Xiayi and captured it.

sentences.zh: 還軍豐。

translations.literal: They returned the army to Feng.
translations.idiomatic: They returned the army to Feng.

sentences.zh: 聞項梁在薛，從騎百餘往見之。

translations.literal: Hearing that Xiang Liang was at Xue, he went with over a hundred cavalry to see him.
translations.idiomatic: Hearing that Xiang Liang was at Xue, he went with over a hundred cavalry to meet him.

sentences.zh: 項梁益沛公卒五千人，五大夫將十人。

translations.literal: Xiang Liang augmented the Duke of Pei's troops with five thousand men and ten commanders of the fifth rank.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Liang augmented the Duke of Pei's forces with five thousand troops and ten commanders of the fifth rank.

sentences.zh: 沛公還，引兵攻豐。

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei returned and led troops to attack Feng.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei returned and led troops to attack Feng.

translations.literal: In the second year of the Second Emperor of Qin, Chen She's general Zhou Zhang's army went west reaching Xi and returned. Yan, Zhao, Qi, and Wei all made themselves kings. The Xiang clan arose in Wu. The Supervisor of Sichuan, Ping, led troops to surround Feng for two days; they came out to do battle and broke them. He ordered Yong Chi to defend Feng and led his troops to Xue. The Administrator of Sizhou, Zhuang, was defeated at Xue and fled to Qi; the Duke of Pei's Left Major captured Administrator Zhuang of Sichuan and killed him. The Duke of Pei returned his army to Kangfu, reached Fangyu, and had not yet fought. King Chen sent Zhou Shi of Wei to take territory. Zhou Shi sent someone to say to Yong Chi: "Feng was formerly a Liang relocated town. Now the Wei territory that has been settled numbers several tens of cities. If Chi now surrenders to Wei, Wei will make Chi a marquis defending Feng. If you do not surrender, we will massacre Feng." Yong Chi had long been unwilling to be subordinate to the Duke of Pei; when Wei recruited him, he immediately rebelled and defended Feng for Wei. The Duke of Pei led troops to attack Feng but could not take it. The Duke of Pei fell ill and returned to Pei. The Duke of Pei resented that Yong Chi and the sons and younger brothers of Feng had betrayed him; hearing that Lord Ning of Dongyang and Qin Jia had installed Jing Ju as Provisional King at Liu, he went to join them, wishing to request troops to attack Feng. At this time Qin general Zhang Han came from Chen; a separate general, Sima Yi, led troops to pacify Chu territory to the north, massacred Xiang, and reached Dang. Lord Ning of Dongyang and the Duke of Pei led troops west and fought with them west of Xiao; it went unfavorably. They returned to gather troops and assembled at Liu, then led troops to attack Dang, taking it after three days. Consequently gathering Dang's troops, they obtained five or six thousand men. They attacked Xiayi and took it. They returned the army to Feng. Hearing that Xiang Liang was at Xue, he went with over a hundred cavalry to see him. Xiang Liang augmented the Duke of Pei's troops with five thousand men and ten commanders of the fifth rank. The Duke of Pei returned and led troops to attack Feng.

sentences.zh: 從項梁月餘，項羽已拔襄城還。

translations.literal: Following Xiang Liang for over a month, Xiang Yu had already taken Xiangcheng and returned.
translations.idiomatic: He followed Xiang Liang for over a month, during which Xiang Yu had already captured Xiangcheng and returned.

sentences.zh: 項梁盡召別將居薛。

translations.literal: Xiang Liang summoned all the separate generals to assemble at Xue.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Liang summoned all the separate generals to assemble at Xue.

sentences.zh: 聞陳王定死，因立楚後懷王孫心為楚王，治盱臺。

translations.literal: Hearing that King Chen had definitely died, they consequently installed Xin, grandson of the former King Huai of Chu, as King of Chu, governing from Xutai.
translations.idiomatic: Hearing that King Chen had definitely died, they consequently installed Xin, grandson of the former King Huai of Chu, as King of Chu, governing from Xutai.

sentences.zh: 項梁號武信君。

translations.literal: Xiang Liang took the title Lord of Martial Trust.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Liang took the title Lord Wu Xin.

sentences.zh: 居數月，北攻亢父，救東阿，破秦軍。

translations.literal: After several months, they attacked Kangfu to the north, rescued Dong'e, and broke the Qin army.
translations.idiomatic: After several months, they attacked Kangfu to the north, rescued Dong'e, and defeated the Qin army.

sentences.zh: 齊軍歸，楚獨追北，使沛公、項羽別攻城陽，屠之。

translations.literal: The Qi army returned; only Chu pursued northward, sending the Duke of Pei and Xiang Yu separately to attack Chengyang and massacre it.
translations.idiomatic: The Qi army retreated. Only Chu pursued northward, sending the Duke of Pei and Xiang Yu separately to attack Chengyang and massacre its inhabitants.

sentences.zh: 軍濮陽之東，與秦軍戰，破之。

translations.literal: They encamped east of Puyang and fought with the Qin army, breaking them.
translations.idiomatic: They encamped east of Puyang and fought the Qin army, defeating them.

translations.literal: Following Xiang Liang for over a month, Xiang Yu had already taken Xiangcheng and returned. Xiang Liang summoned all the separate generals to assemble at Xue. Hearing that King Chen had definitely died, they consequently installed Xin, grandson of the former King Huai of Chu, as King of Chu, governing from Xutai. Xiang Liang took the title Lord of Martial Trust. After several months, they attacked Kangfu to the north, rescued Dong'e, and broke the Qin army. The Qi army returned; only Chu pursued northward, sending the Duke of Pei and Xiang Yu separately to attack Chengyang and massacre it. They encamped east of Puyang and fought with the Qin army, breaking them.

sentences.zh: 秦軍復振，守濮陽，環水。

translations.literal: The Qin army rallied again, defended Puyang, and surrounded by water.
translations.idiomatic: The Qin army rallied again, defended Puyang, and was surrounded by water.

sentences.zh: 楚軍去而攻定陶，定陶未下。

translations.literal: The Chu army departed and attacked Dingtao, but Dingtao did not fall.
translations.idiomatic: The Chu army departed and attacked Dingtao, but could not capture it.

sentences.zh: 沛公與項羽西略地至雍丘之下，與秦軍戰，大破之，斬李由。

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei and Xiang Yu went west taking territory to below Yongqiu, fought with the Qin army, greatly broke them, and beheaded Li You.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei and Xiang Yu went west seizing territory as far as below Yongqiu. They fought the Qin army, decisively defeated them, and beheaded Li You.

sentences.zh: 還攻外黃，外黃未下。

translations.literal: Returning they attacked Waihuang, but Waihuang did not fall.
translations.idiomatic: Returning, they attacked Waihuang, but could not capture it.

translations.literal: The Qin army rallied again, defended Puyang, and surrounded by water. The Chu army departed and attacked Dingtao, but Dingtao did not fall. The Duke of Pei and Xiang Yu went west taking territory to below Yongqiu, fought with the Qin army, greatly broke them, and beheaded Li You. Returning they attacked Waihuang, but Waihuang did not fall.

sentences.zh: 項梁再破秦軍，有驕色。

translations.literal: Xiang Liang twice broke the Qin army and showed an arrogant bearing.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Liang had twice defeated the Qin army and showed an arrogant demeanor.

sentences.zh: 宋義諫，不聽。

translations.literal: Song Yi remonstrated, but he did not listen.
translations.idiomatic: Song Yi advised him against it, but he did not listen.

sentences.zh: 秦益章邯兵，夜銜枚擊項梁，大破之定陶，項梁死。

translations.literal: Qin reinforced Zhang Han's troops; by night with gags in their mouths they struck Xiang Liang, greatly broke him at Dingtao; Xiang Liang died.
translations.idiomatic: Qin reinforced Zhang Han's troops. By night, with gags in their mouths to maintain silence, they struck Xiang Liang, decisively defeating him at Dingtao. Xiang Liang died.

sentences.zh: 沛公與項羽方攻陳留，聞項梁死，引兵與呂將軍俱東。

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei and Xiang Yu were attacking Chenliu when they heard of Xiang Liang's death; they led their troops eastward together with General Lü.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei and Xiang Yu were in the midst of attacking Chenliu when they heard of Xiang Liang's death. They led their troops eastward together with General Lü.

sentences.zh: 呂臣軍彭城東，項羽軍彭城西，沛公軍碭。

translations.literal: Lü Chen's army was east of Pengcheng, Xiang Yu's army west of Pengcheng, and the Duke of Pei's army at Dang.
translations.idiomatic: Lü Chen's army was east of Pengcheng, Xiang Yu's army west of Pengcheng, and the Duke of Pei's army at Dang.

translations.literal: Xiang Liang twice broke the Qin army and showed an arrogant bearing. Song Yi remonstrated, but he did not listen. Qin reinforced Zhang Han's troops; by night with gags in their mouths they struck Xiang Liang, greatly broke him at Dingtao; Xiang Liang died. The Duke of Pei and Xiang Yu were attacking Chenliu when they heard of Xiang Liang's death; they led their troops eastward together with General Lü. Lü Chen's army was east of Pengcheng, Xiang Yu's army west of Pengcheng, and the Duke of Pei's army at Dang.

sentences.zh: 章邯已破項梁軍，則以為楚地兵不足憂，乃渡河，北擊趙，大破之。

translations.literal: Having broken Xiang Liang's army, Zhang Han considered that Chu territory's troops were not worth worrying about, so he crossed the Yellow River and attacked Zhao to the north, greatly breaking them.
translations.idiomatic: Having defeated Xiang Liang's army, Zhang Han considered Chu's troops no longer a threat. He crossed the Yellow River north and attacked Zhao, decisively defeating them.

sentences.zh: 當是之時，趙歇為王，秦將王離圍之鉅鹿城，此所謂河北之軍也。

translations.literal: At that time, Zhao Xie was king; Qin general Wang Li surrounded him at Julu city—this was called the army north of the Yellow River.
translations.idiomatic: At that time, Zhao Xie was king. Qin general Wang Li besieged him at Julu city—this was called the army north of the Yellow River.

translations.literal: Having broken Xiang Liang's army, Zhang Han considered that Chu territory's troops were not worth worrying about, so he crossed the Yellow River and attacked Zhao to the north, greatly breaking them. At that time, Zhao Xie was king; Qin general Wang Li surrounded him at Julu city—this was called the army north of the Yellow River.

sentences.zh: 秦二世三年，楚懷王見項梁軍破，恐，徙盱臺都彭城，并呂臣、項羽軍自將之。

translations.literal: In the third year of the Second Emperor of Qin, King Huai of Chu saw that Xiang Liang's army was broken and was afraid; he moved from Xutai and made his capital at Pengcheng, combining Lü Chen's and Xiang Yu's armies to command them himself.
translations.idiomatic: In the third year of Qin's Second Emperor, King Huai of Chu saw that Xiang Liang's army had been defeated and grew fearful. He moved his capital from Xutai to Pengcheng and personally took command of Lü Chen's and Xiang Yu's combined armies.

sentences.zh: 以沛公為碭郡長，封為武安侯，將碭郡兵。

translations.literal: He made the Duke of Pei Administrator of Dang Commandery, enfeoffed him as Marquis of Wu'an, and had him command the troops of Dang Commandery.
translations.idiomatic: He appointed the Duke of Pei as Governor of Dang Commandery, enfeoffed him as Marquis of Wu'an, and put him in command of Dang's troops.

sentences.zh: 封項羽為長安侯，號為魯公。

translations.literal: He enfeoffed Xiang Yu as Marquis of Chang'an and gave him the title Duke of Lu.
translations.idiomatic: He enfeoffed Xiang Yu as Marquis of Chang'an and gave him the title Duke of Lu.

sentences.zh: 呂臣為司徒，其父呂青為令尹。

translations.literal: Lü Chen was made Minister of Ceremonies, and his father Lü Qing Grand Councillor.
translations.idiomatic: Lü Chen was appointed Minister of Ceremonies, and his father Lü Qing became Grand Councillor.

translations.literal: In the third year of the Second Emperor of Qin, King Huai of Chu saw that Xiang Liang's army was broken and was afraid; he moved from Xutai and made his capital at Pengcheng, combining Lü Chen's and Xiang Yu's armies to command them himself. He made the Duke of Pei Administrator of Dang Commandery, enfeoffed him as Marquis of Wu'an, and had him command the troops of Dang Commandery. He enfeoffed Xiang Yu as Marquis of Chang'an and gave him the title Duke of Lu. Lü Chen was made Minister of Ceremonies, and his father Lü Qing Grand Councillor.

sentences.zh: 趙數請救，懷王乃以宋義為上將軍，項羽為次將，范增為末將，北救趙。

translations.literal: Zhao repeatedly requested rescue; King Huai then made Song Yi Supreme General, Xiang Yu second general, and Fan Zeng final general, to rescue Zhao to the north.
translations.idiomatic: Zhao repeatedly requested rescue. King Huai then appointed Song Yi as Supreme General, Xiang Yu as Deputy General, and Fan Zeng as Rear General, to go north and rescue Zhao.

sentences.zh: 令沛公西略地入關。

translations.literal: He ordered the Duke of Pei to go west taking territory and enter the passes.
translations.idiomatic: He ordered the Duke of Pei to go west, seize territory, and enter the passes.

sentences.zh: 與諸將約，先入定關中者王之。

translations.literal: Making an agreement with all the generals: he who first enters and settles Guanzhong shall be its king.
translations.idiomatic: He made an agreement with all the generals: whoever first enters and pacifies Guanzhong shall be made its king.

translations.literal: Zhao repeatedly requested rescue; King Huai then made Song Yi Supreme General, Xiang Yu second general, and Fan Zeng final general, to rescue Zhao to the north. He ordered the Duke of Pei to go west taking territory and enter the passes. Making an agreement with all the generals: he who first enters and settles Guanzhong shall be its king.

sentences.zh: 當是時，秦兵彊，常乘勝逐北，諸將莫利先入關。

translations.literal: At that time, Qin troops were strong and constantly rode victory pursuing northward; none of the generals found it advantageous to enter the passes first.
translations.idiomatic: At that time, Qin troops were strong and constantly pressing their victories northward. None of the generals saw advantage in entering the passes first.

sentences.zh: 獨項羽怨秦破項梁軍，奮，願與沛公西入關。

translations.literal: Only Xiang Yu resented that Qin had broken Xiang Liang's army and was determined, wishing to go west into the passes with the Duke of Pei.
translations.idiomatic: Only Xiang Yu, resentful that Qin had destroyed his uncle Xiang Liang's army, was determined and wished to go west into the passes with the Duke of Pei.

sentences.zh: 懷王諸老將皆曰：「項羽為人彊悍猾賊。

translations.literal: King Huai's various old generals all said: "Xiang Yu as a person is fierce, violent, cunning, and cruel.
translations.idiomatic: King Huai's veteran generals all said: 'Xiang Yu is fierce, violent, cunning, and cruel.'

sentences.zh: 項羽嘗攻襄城，襄城無遺類，皆阬之，諸所過無不殘滅。

translations.literal: When Xiang Yu attacked Xiangcheng, none of Xiangcheng's population remained—all were buried alive; wherever he passes he completely destroys everything.
translations.idiomatic: When Xiang Yu attacked Xiangcheng, he left no survivors—all were buried alive. Wherever he goes, he completely destroys everything.

sentences.zh: 且楚數進取，前陳王、項梁皆敗。

translations.literal: Moreover, Chu has repeatedly advanced offensively; previously King Chen and Xiang Liang both were defeated.
translations.idiomatic: Moreover, Chu has repeatedly gone on the offensive, but previously King Chen and Xiang Liang both were defeated.

sentences.zh: 不如更遣長者扶義而西，告諭秦父兄。

translations.literal: It would be better to send an elder to uphold righteousness and go west, to inform and instruct the fathers and elder brothers of Qin.
translations.idiomatic: It would be better to send an elder to uphold righteousness and go west, to inform and persuade the fathers and brothers of Qin.

sentences.zh: 秦父兄苦其主久矣，今誠得長者往，毋侵暴，宜可下。

translations.literal: The fathers and elder brothers of Qin have long suffered under their lord; now if we truly obtain an elder to go who does not invade or commit violence, they should be amenable to surrender.
translations.idiomatic: The fathers and brothers of Qin have long suffered under their ruler. If we truly send a benevolent elder who commits no violence, they should be amenable to surrender.

sentences.zh: 今項羽彊悍，今不可遣。

translations.literal: Now Xiang Yu is fierce and violent; he cannot be sent.
translations.idiomatic: Now Xiang Yu is fierce and violent; he cannot be sent.

sentences.zh: 獨沛公素寬大長者，可遣。」

translations.literal: Only the Duke of Pei has always been generous and magnanimous, an elder; he can be sent."
translations.idiomatic: Only the Duke of Pei has always been generous and magnanimous, a true elder. He can be sent.''

sentences.zh: 卒不許項羽，而遣沛公西略地，收陳王、項梁散卒。

translations.literal: In the end they did not permit Xiang Yu, but sent the Duke of Pei west to take territory and gather the scattered troops of King Chen and Xiang Liang.
translations.idiomatic: In the end they did not permit Xiang Yu, but sent the Duke of Pei west to seize territory and gather the scattered troops of King Chen and Xiang Liang.

sentences.zh: 乃道碭至成陽，與杠裏秦軍夾壁，破（魏）［秦］二軍。

translations.literal: They then went by way of Dang to Chengyang and with Qin troops at Gangli faced each other across ramparts, breaking the two Qin armies.
translations.idiomatic: They then went by way of Dang to Chengyang and faced off against Qin troops at Gangli across ramparts, defeating the two Qin armies.

sentences.zh: 楚軍出兵擊王離，大破之。

translations.literal: The Chu army sent out troops to strike Wang Li and greatly broke him.
translations.idiomatic: The Chu army sent out troops to attack Wang Li and decisively defeated him.

translations.literal: At that time, Qin troops were strong and constantly rode victory pursuing northward; none of the generals found it advantageous to enter the passes first. Only Xiang Yu resented that Qin had broken Xiang Liang's army and was determined, wishing to go west into the passes with the Duke of Pei. King Huai's various old generals all said: "Xiang Yu as a person is fierce, violent, cunning, and cruel. When Xiang Yu attacked Xiangcheng, none of Xiangcheng's population remained—all were buried alive; wherever he passes he completely destroys everything. Moreover, Chu has repeatedly advanced offensively; previously King Chen and Xiang Liang both were defeated. It would be better to send an elder to uphold righteousness and go west, to inform and instruct the fathers and elder brothers of Qin. The fathers and elder brothers of Qin have long suffered under their lord; now if we truly obtain an elder to go who does not invade or commit violence, they should be amenable to surrender. Now Xiang Yu is fierce and violent; he cannot be sent. Only the Duke of Pei has always been generous and magnanimous, an elder; he can be sent." In the end they did not permit Xiang Yu, but sent the Duke of Pei west to take territory and gather the scattered troops of King Chen and Xiang Liang. They then went by way of Dang to Chengyang and with Qin troops at Gangli faced each other across ramparts, breaking the two Qin armies. The Chu army sent out troops to strike Wang Li and greatly broke him.

sentences.zh: 沛公引兵西，遇彭越昌邑，因與俱攻秦軍，戰不利。

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei led troops west and met Peng Yue at Changyi; consequently they together attacked the Qin army, but the battle went unfavorably.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei led troops west and met Peng Yue at Changyi. They consequently attacked the Qin army together, but the battle went unfavorably.

sentences.zh: 還至栗，遇剛武侯，奪其軍，可四千餘人，并之。

translations.literal: Returning to reach Li, he met Marquis Gangwu, seized his army of over four thousand men, and combined them.
translations.idiomatic: Returning to Li, he met Marquis Gangwu, seized his army of over four thousand men, and incorporated them.

sentences.zh: 與魏將皇欣、魏申徒武蒲之軍并攻昌邑，昌邑未拔。

translations.literal: Together with Wei generals Huang Xin, Wei Shentu, and the army of Wu Pu, they jointly attacked Changyi, but Changyi did not fall.
translations.idiomatic: Together with Wei generals Huang Xin, Wei Shentu, and Wu Pu's army, they jointly attacked Changyi, but could not capture it.

sentences.zh: 西過高陽。

translations.literal: Going west they passed Gaoyang.
translations.idiomatic: Going west, they passed Gaoyang.

sentences.zh: 酈食其（謂）［為］監門，曰：「諸將過此者多，吾視沛公大人長者。」

translations.literal: Li Yiji was gate guard and said: "Many generals have passed through here; I observe that the Duke of Pei is a great man and elder."
translations.idiomatic: Li Yiji was gate guard and said: 'Many generals have passed through here. I observe that the Duke of Pei is a great man and true elder.''

sentences.zh: 乃求見說沛公。

translations.literal: He then sought an audience to persuade the Duke of Pei.
translations.idiomatic: He then sought an audience to persuade the Duke of Pei.

sentences.zh: 沛公方踞床，使兩女子洗足。

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei was squatting on the bed having two women wash his feet.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei was sitting cross-legged on the bed, having two women wash his feet.

sentences.zh: 酈生不拜，長揖，曰：「足下必欲誅無道秦，不宜踞見長者。」

translations.literal: Li Sheng did not bow but made a long salute, saying: "If you wish to execute the lawless Qin, you should not squat to receive an elder."
translations.idiomatic: Li Sheng did not bow but made a deep bow, saying: 'If you wish to execute the lawless Qin, you should not sit cross-legged to receive an elder.''

sentences.zh: 於是沛公起，攝衣謝之，延上坐。

translations.literal: Thereupon the Duke of Pei rose, adjusted his clothing, apologized, and invited him to the seat of honor.
translations.idiomatic: Thereupon the Duke of Pei rose, adjusted his clothing, apologized, and invited him to the seat of honor.

sentences.zh: 食其說沛公襲陳留，得秦積粟。

translations.literal: Li Yiji persuaded the Duke of Pei to attack Chenliu and obtain Qin's accumulated grain.
translations.idiomatic: Li Yiji persuaded the Duke of Pei to attack Chenliu and obtain Qin's accumulated grain.

sentences.zh: 乃以酈食其為廣野君，酈商為將，將陳留兵，與偕攻開封，開封未拔。

translations.literal: He then made Li Yiji Lord of Guangye and Li Shang a general to command the troops of Chenliu and together attack Kaifeng, but Kaifeng did not fall.
translations.idiomatic: He then made Li Yiji Lord of Guangye and Li Shang a general to command Chenliu's troops. Together they attacked Kaifeng, but could not capture it.

sentences.zh: 西與秦將楊熊戰白馬，又戰曲遇東，大破之。

translations.literal: Going west they fought with Qin general Yang Xiong at Baima, and again fought east of Quyu, greatly breaking them.
translations.idiomatic: Going west, they fought Qin general Yang Xiong at Baima, and again fought east of Quyu, decisively defeating them.

sentences.zh: 楊熊走之滎陽，二世使使者斬以徇。

translations.literal: Yang Xiong fled to Yingyang; the Second Emperor sent an envoy to behead him as a warning.
translations.idiomatic: Yang Xiong fled to Yingyang. The Second Emperor sent an envoy to behead him as a public warning.

sentences.zh: 南攻潁陽，屠之。

translations.literal: They attacked Yingyang to the south and massacred it.
translations.idiomatic: They attacked Yingyang to the south and massacred its inhabitants.

sentences.zh: 因張良遂略韓地轘轅。

translations.literal: Through Zhang Liang they then took the territory of Han at Huanyuan.
translations.idiomatic: Through Zhang Liang they then seized Han territory at Huanyuan.

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei led troops west and met Peng Yue at Changyi; consequently they together attacked the Qin army, but the battle went unfavorably. Returning to reach Li, he met Marquis Gangwu, seized his army of over four thousand men, and combined them. Together with Wei generals Huang Xin, Wei Shentu, and the army of Wu Pu, they jointly attacked Changyi, but Changyi did not fall. Going west they passed Gaoyang. Li Yiji was gate guard and said: "Many generals have passed through here; I observe that the Duke of Pei is a great man and elder." He then sought an audience to persuade the Duke of Pei. The Duke of Pei was squatting on the bed having two women wash his feet. Li Sheng did not bow but made a long salute, saying: "If you wish to execute the lawless Qin, you should not squat to receive an elder." Thereupon the Duke of Pei rose, adjusted his clothing, apologized, and invited him to the seat of honor. Li Yiji persuaded the Duke of Pei to attack Chenliu and obtain Qin's accumulated grain. He then made Li Yiji Lord of Guangye and Li Shang a general to command the troops of Chenliu and together attack Kaifeng, but Kaifeng did not fall. Going west they fought with Qin general Yang Xiong at Baima, and again fought east of Quyu, greatly breaking them. Yang Xiong fled to Yingyang; the Second Emperor sent an envoy to behead him as a warning. They attacked Yingyang to the south and massacred it. Through Zhang Liang they then took the territory of Han at Huanyuan.

sentences.zh: 當是時，趙別將司馬卬方欲渡河入關，沛公乃北攻平陰，絕河津。

translations.literal: At that time, Zhao's separate general Sima Ang was about to cross the Yellow River to enter the passes; the Duke of Pei then attacked Pingyin to the north, cutting off the river ford.
translations.idiomatic: At that time, Zhao's separate general Sima Ang was about to cross the Yellow River into the passes. The Duke of Pei then attacked Pingyin to the north, cutting off the river crossing.

sentences.zh: 南，戰雒陽東，軍不利，還至陽城，收軍中馬騎，與南陽守齮戰犨東，破之。

translations.literal: Going south, they fought east of Luoyang; the army went unfavorably, so they returned to Yangcheng, gathered cavalry within the army, and fought with Nanyang Administrator Qi east of Chu, breaking him.
translations.idiomatic: Going south, they fought east of Luoyang, but the army fared poorly. They returned to Yangcheng, gathered cavalry from their forces, and fought Nanyang Administrator Qi east of Chu, defeating him.

sentences.zh: 略南陽郡，南陽守齮走，保城守宛。

translations.literal: They took Nanyang Commandery; Administrator Qi fled and defended and held the city of Wan.
translations.idiomatic: They seized Nanyang Commandery. Administrator Qi fled and defended the city of Wan.

sentences.zh: 沛公引兵過而西。

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei led his troops to pass by and go west.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei led his troops past and continued west.

sentences.zh: 張良諫曰：「沛公雖欲急入關，秦兵尚眾，距險。

translations.literal: Zhang Liang remonstrated, saying: "Though the Duke of Pei wishes to urgently enter the passes, Qin troops are still numerous and hold dangerous positions.
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Liang remonstrated, saying: 'Though the Duke of Pei wishes to urgently enter the passes, Qin troops are still numerous and hold dangerous defensive positions.'

sentences.zh: 今不下宛，宛從後擊，彊秦在前，此危道也。」

translations.literal: Now if we do not take Wan, Wan will strike from behind, while strong Qin is ahead—this is a dangerous path."
translations.idiomatic: If we don't take Wan now, Wan will strike from behind while strong Qin forces are ahead—this is a dangerous path.''

sentences.zh: 於是沛公乃夜引兵從他道還，更旗幟，黎明，圍宛城三匝。

translations.literal: Thereupon the Duke of Pei led his troops by night from another road and returned, changed flags and banners, and at dawn surrounded Wan city three times round.
translations.idiomatic: Thereupon the Duke of Pei led his troops by night along another road back, changed the flags and banners, and at dawn surrounded Wan city three times over.

sentences.zh: 南陽守欲自剄。

translations.literal: The Administrator of Nanyang wished to slit his own throat.
translations.idiomatic: The Administrator of Nanyang wished to commit suicide.

sentences.zh: 其舍人陳恢曰：「死未晚也。」

translations.literal: His retainer Chen Hui said: "It is not too late to die."
translations.idiomatic: His retainer Chen Hui said: 'It is not too late to die.''

sentences.zh: 乃踰城見沛公，曰：「臣聞足下約，先入咸陽者王之。

translations.literal: He then climbed over the city wall to see the Duke of Pei and said: "I have heard of your agreement: he who first enters Xianyang shall be its king.
translations.idiomatic: He then climbed over the city wall to see the Duke of Pei and said: 'I have heard of your agreement: whoever first enters Xianyang shall be made its king.'

sentences.zh: 今足下留守宛。

translations.literal: Now you remain besieging Wan.
translations.idiomatic: Now you remain besieging Wan.'

sentences.zh: 宛，大郡之都也，連城數十，人民眾，積蓄多，吏人自以為降必死，故皆堅守乘城。

translations.literal: Wan is the capital of a great commandery with dozens of connected cities, numerous people, and abundant stores; the officials and people believe that if they surrender they will certainly die, therefore all firmly defend and man the walls.
translations.idiomatic: Wan is the capital of a major commandery with dozens of connected cities, numerous people, and abundant supplies. The officials and people believe that if they surrender they will certainly die, so they all defend firmly and man the walls.

sentences.zh: 今足下盡日止攻，士死傷者必多；

translations.literal: Now if you spend the whole day attacking, officers and troops who die or are wounded will certainly be many;
translations.idiomatic: If you spend the whole day attacking now, many officers and troops will certainly die or be wounded;

sentences.zh: 引兵去宛，宛必隨足下後：足下前則失咸陽之約，後又有彊宛之患。

translations.literal: if you lead troops away from Wan, Wan will certainly follow behind you; ahead you will lose the agreement about Xianyang, and behind you will have the trouble of strong Wan.
translations.idiomatic: if you lead troops away from Wan, Wan will certainly follow behind you. Ahead you will lose the agreement about Xianyang, and behind you will have the trouble of strong Wan.

sentences.zh: 為足下計，莫若約降，封其守，因使止守，引其甲卒與之西。

translations.literal: Planning for you, nothing would be better than to agree to accept surrender, enfeoff their administrator, consequently have him remain defending, and lead his armored troops with you westward.
translations.idiomatic: Planning for you, nothing would be better than to agree to accept their surrender, enfeoff their administrator, have him remain defending, and lead his armored troops westward with you.

sentences.zh: 諸城未下者，聞聲爭開門而待，足下通行無所累。」

translations.literal: Cities that have not yet surrendered, hearing the news, will compete to open their gates and wait; you will pass through everywhere without obstruction."
translations.idiomatic: Cities that have not yet surrendered, hearing this news, will compete to open their gates and wait for you. You will pass through everywhere without obstruction.''

sentences.zh: 沛公曰：「善。」

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei said: "Excellent."
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei said: 'Excellent.''

sentences.zh: 乃以宛守為殷侯，封陳恢千戶。

translations.literal: He then made the Administrator of Wan Marquis of Yin and enfeoffed Chen Hui with a thousand households.
translations.idiomatic: He then made the Administrator of Wan Marquis of Yin and enfeoffed Chen Hui with a thousand households.

sentences.zh: 引兵西，無不下者。

translations.literal: Leading troops westward, there were none that did not surrender.
translations.idiomatic: Leading troops westward, none failed to surrender.

sentences.zh: 至丹水，高武侯鰓、襄侯王陵降西陵。

translations.literal: Reaching Danshui, Marquis Gaowu Sai and Marquis Xiang Wang Ling surrendered at Xiling.
translations.idiomatic: Reaching Danshui, Marquis Gaowu Sai and Marquis Xiang Wang Ling surrendered at Xiling.

sentences.zh: 還攻胡陽，遇番君別將梅鋗，與皆，降析、酈。

translations.literal: Returning they attacked Huyang, met Lord Fan's separate general Mei Xuan, went together with them, and accepted the surrender of Xi and Li.
translations.idiomatic: Returning, they attacked Huyang, met Lord Fan's separate general Mei Xuan, joined forces with them, and accepted the surrender of Xi and Li.

sentences.zh: 遣魏人甯昌使秦，使者未來。

translations.literal: They dispatched Ning Chang of Wei as envoy to Qin, but the envoy had not yet returned.
translations.idiomatic: They dispatched Ning Chang of Wei as envoy to Qin, but the envoy had not yet returned.

sentences.zh: 是時章邯已以軍降項羽於趙矣。

translations.literal: At this time Zhang Han had already surrendered his army to Xiang Yu at Zhao.
translations.idiomatic: At this time Zhang Han had already surrendered his army to Xiang Yu at Zhao.

translations.literal: At that time, Zhao's separate general Sima Ang was about to cross the Yellow River to enter the passes; the Duke of Pei then attacked Pingyin to the north, cutting off the river ford. Going south, they fought east of Luoyang; the army went unfavorably, so they returned to Yangcheng, gathered cavalry within the army, and fought with Nanyang Administrator Qi east of Chu, breaking him. They took Nanyang Commandery; Administrator Qi fled and defended and held the city of Wan. The Duke of Pei led his troops to pass by and go west. Zhang Liang remonstrated, saying: "Though the Duke of Pei wishes to urgently enter the passes, Qin troops are still numerous and hold dangerous positions. Now if we do not take Wan, Wan will strike from behind, while strong Qin is ahead—this is a dangerous path." Thereupon the Duke of Pei led his troops by night from another road and returned, changed flags and banners, and at dawn surrounded Wan city three times round. The Administrator of Nanyang wished to slit his own throat. His retainer Chen Hui said: "It is not too late to die." He then climbed over the city wall to see the Duke of Pei and said: "I have heard of your agreement: he who first enters Xianyang shall be its king. Now you remain besieging Wan. Wan is the capital of a great commandery with dozens of connected cities, numerous people, and abundant stores; the officials and people believe that if they surrender they will certainly die, therefore all firmly defend and man the walls. Now if you spend the whole day attacking, officers and troops who die or are wounded will certainly be many; if you lead troops away from Wan, Wan will certainly follow behind you; ahead you will lose the agreement about Xianyang, and behind you will have the trouble of strong Wan. Planning for you, nothing would be better than to agree to accept surrender, enfeoff their administrator, consequently have him remain defending, and lead his armored troops with you westward. Cities that have not yet surrendered, hearing the news, will compete to open their gates and wait; you will pass through everywhere without obstruction." The Duke of Pei said: "Excellent." He then made the Administrator of Wan Marquis of Yin and enfeoffed Chen Hui with a thousand households. Leading troops westward, there were none that did not surrender. Reaching Danshui, Marquis Gaowu Sai and Marquis Xiang Wang Ling surrendered at Xiling. Returning they attacked Huyang, met Lord Fan's separate general Mei Xuan, went together with them, and accepted the surrender of Xi and Li. They dispatched Ning Chang of Wei as envoy to Qin, but the envoy had not yet returned. At this time Zhang Han had already surrendered his army to Xiang Yu at Zhao.

sentences.zh: 初，項羽與宋義北救趙，及項羽殺宋義，代為上將軍，諸將黥布皆屬，破秦將王離軍，降章邯，諸侯皆附。

translations.literal: Initially, Xiang Yu with Song Yi had gone north to rescue Zhao; when Xiang Yu killed Song Yi and replaced him as Supreme General, all the generals including Qing Bu were subordinated to him; he broke Qin general Wang Li's army, accepted Zhang Han's surrender, and all the feudal lords attached themselves.
translations.idiomatic: Initially, Xiang Yu and Song Yi had gone north to rescue Zhao. When Xiang Yu killed Song Yi and replaced him as Supreme General, all the generals including Qing Bu were subordinated to him. He defeated Qin general Wang Li's army, accepted Zhang Han's surrender, and all the feudal lords attached themselves.

sentences.zh: 及趙高已殺二世，使人來，欲約分王關中。

translations.literal: When Zhao Gao had already killed the Second Emperor, he sent men to come wishing to make an agreement to divide and rule Guanzhong.
translations.idiomatic: When Zhao Gao had already killed the Second Emperor, he sent men to come wishing to make an agreement to divide and rule Guanzhong.

sentences.zh: 沛公以為詐，乃用張良計，使酈生、陸賈往說秦將，啗以利，因襲攻武關，破之。

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei considered this deceitful, so he used Zhang Liang's stratagem, sending Li Sheng and Lu Jia to persuade the Qin generals, enticing them with benefits, and consequently launched a surprise attack on Wuguan, breaking it.
