translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei considered this deceitful, so he used Zhang Liang's stratagem. He sent Li Sheng and Lu Jia to persuade the Qin generals, enticing them with benefits, and consequently launched a surprise attack on Wuguan, breaking through it.

sentences.zh: 又與秦軍戰於藍田南，益張疑兵旗幟，諸所過毋得掠鹵，秦人喜，秦軍解，因大破之。

translations.literal: They again fought with the Qin army south of Lantian, increased deceptive troop flags and banners; wherever they passed they were not to plunder; the Qin people were pleased, the Qin army relaxed, and they consequently greatly broke them.
translations.idiomatic: They again fought the Qin army south of Lantian, increased their deceptive troop flags and banners. Wherever they passed they were forbidden to plunder. The Qin people were pleased, the Qin army relaxed, and they consequently decisively defeated them.

sentences.zh: 又戰其北，大破之。

translations.literal: Again fighting to their north, they greatly broke them.
translations.idiomatic: Again fighting to the north, they decisively defeated them.

sentences.zh: 乘勝，遂破之。

translations.literal: Riding victory, they then broke them completely.
translations.idiomatic: Riding their victory, they then broke them completely.

translations.literal: Initially, Xiang Yu with Song Yi had gone north to rescue Zhao; when Xiang Yu killed Song Yi and replaced him as Supreme General, all the generals including Qing Bu were subordinated to him; he broke Qin general Wang Li's army, accepted Zhang Han's surrender, and all the feudal lords attached themselves. When Zhao Gao had already killed the Second Emperor, he sent men to come wishing to make an agreement to divide and rule Guanzhong. The Duke of Pei considered this deceitful, so he used Zhang Liang's stratagem, sending Li Sheng and Lu Jia to persuade the Qin generals, enticing them with benefits, and consequently launched a surprise attack on Wuguan, breaking it. They again fought with the Qin army south of Lantian, increased deceptive troop flags and banners; wherever they passed they were not to plunder; the Qin people were pleased, the Qin army relaxed, and they consequently greatly broke them. Again fighting to their north, they greatly broke them. Riding victory, they then broke them completely.

sentences.zh: 漢元年十月，沛公兵遂先諸侯至霸上。

translations.literal: In the tenth month of the first year of Han, the Duke of Pei's troops were thus first among the feudal lords to reach Bashang.
translations.idiomatic: In the tenth month of the first year of Han, the Duke of Pei's troops thus arrived first among the feudal lords at Bashang.

sentences.zh: 秦王子嬰素車白馬，系頸以組，封皇帝璽符節，降軹道旁。

translations.literal: The King of Qin, Ziying, in a plain chariot drawn by white horses, with a cord tied around his neck, sealed the Emperor's seal, tallies, and tokens, and surrendered by the side of Zhidao.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Qin Ziying, in a plain chariot drawn by white horses with a cord tied around his neck, sealed the Emperor's seal, tallies, and tokens, and surrendered by the side of Zhidao.

sentences.zh: 諸將或言誅秦王。

translations.literal: Some generals spoke of executing the King of Qin.
translations.idiomatic: Some generals spoke of executing the King of Qin.

sentences.zh: 沛公曰：「始懷王遣我，固以能寬容；

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei said: "At first when King Huai sent me, it was precisely because I am capable of being tolerant and magnanimous;
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei said: 'At first when King Huai sent me, it was precisely because I am capable of being tolerant and magnanimous;'

sentences.zh: 且人已服降，又殺之，不祥。」

translations.literal: moreover, the man has already submitted in surrender—to kill him again would be inauspicious."
translations.idiomatic: moreover, the man has already submitted and surrendered—to kill him now would be inauspicious.''

sentences.zh: 乃以秦王屬吏，遂西入咸陽。

translations.literal: He then handed the King of Qin over to officials and proceeded west into Xianyang.
translations.idiomatic: He then handed the King of Qin over to officials and proceeded west into Xianyang.

sentences.zh: 欲止宮休舍，樊噲、張良諫，乃封秦重寶財物府庫，還軍霸上。

translations.literal: He wished to stop and rest in the palaces, but Fan Kuai and Zhang Liang remonstrated; he then sealed Qin's precious treasures, wealth, and goods in the treasuries, and returned his army to Bashang.
translations.idiomatic: He wished to stop and rest in the palaces, but Fan Kuai and Zhang Liang remonstrated. He then sealed Qin's precious treasures and wealth in the treasuries and returned his army to Bashang.

sentences.zh: 召諸縣父老豪桀曰：「父老苦秦苛法久矣，誹謗者族，偶語者棄市。

translations.literal: He summoned the elders and heroes of the various counties and said: "The elders have long suffered under Qin's harsh laws; those who spoke ill had their clans exterminated, those who spoke together in pairs were executed in the marketplace.
translations.idiomatic: He summoned the elders and heroes of the various counties and said: 'The elders have long suffered under Qin's harsh laws. Those who spoke ill had their clans exterminated, those who spoke together in pairs were executed in the marketplace.'

sentences.zh: 吾與諸侯約，先入關者王之，吾當王關中。

translations.literal: I made an agreement with the feudal lords: he who first enters the passes shall be its king; I should be king of Guanzhong.
translations.idiomatic: I made an agreement with the feudal lords: whoever first enters the passes shall be its king. I should be king of Guanzhong.

sentences.zh: 與父老約，法三章耳：殺人者死，傷人及盜抵罪。

translations.literal: I make an agreement with the elders—laws of only three articles: he who kills shall die, he who wounds others or steals shall be punished accordingly.
translations.idiomatic: I make an agreement with the elders—laws of only three articles: whoever kills shall die, whoever wounds others or steals shall be punished accordingly.

sentences.zh: 餘悉除去秦法。

translations.literal: All the rest of Qin's laws are eliminated.
translations.idiomatic: All the rest of Qin's laws are eliminated.

sentences.zh: 諸吏人皆案堵如故。

translations.literal: All officials and people shall remain peacefully as before.
translations.idiomatic: All officials and people shall remain peacefully as before.

sentences.zh: 凡吾所以來，為父老除害，非有所侵暴，無恐！

translations.literal: The reason I have come is to eliminate harm for the elders, not to invade or commit violence—have no fear!
translations.idiomatic: The reason I have come is to eliminate harm for the elders, not to invade or commit violence—have no fear!

sentences.zh: 且吾所以還軍霸上，待諸侯至而定約束耳。」

translations.literal: Moreover, the reason I have returned my army to Bashang is to wait for the feudal lords to arrive and establish agreements."
translations.idiomatic: Moreover, the reason I have returned my army to Bashang is to wait for the feudal lords to arrive and establish agreements.''

sentences.zh: 乃使人與秦吏行縣鄉邑，告諭之。

translations.literal: He then sent people with Qin officials to go through the counties, districts, and townships to inform and instruct them.
translations.idiomatic: He then sent people along with Qin officials to go through the counties, districts, and townships to inform and instruct them.

sentences.zh: 秦人大喜，爭持牛羊酒食獻饗軍士。

translations.literal: The Qin people were greatly pleased and competed to bring oxen, sheep, wine, and food to offer feasts for the soldiers.
translations.idiomatic: The Qin people were greatly pleased and competed to bring oxen, sheep, wine, and food to offer feasts for the soldiers.

sentences.zh: 沛公又讓不受，曰：「倉粟多，非乏，不欲費人。」

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei again declined and would not accept, saying: "The granaries have abundant grain; there is no scarcity—I do not wish to burden the people."
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei again declined and would not accept, saying: 'The granaries have abundant grain; there is no scarcity—I do not wish to burden the people.''

sentences.zh: 人又益喜，唯恐沛公不為秦王。

translations.literal: The people were even more pleased and only feared the Duke of Pei would not become King of Qin.
translations.idiomatic: The people were even more pleased and only feared the Duke of Pei would not become King of Qin.

translations.literal: In the tenth month of the first year of Han, the Duke of Pei's troops were thus first among the feudal lords to reach Bashang. The King of Qin, Ziying, in a plain chariot drawn by white horses, with a cord tied around his neck, sealed the Emperor's seal, tallies, and tokens, and surrendered by the side of Zhidao. Some generals spoke of executing the King of Qin. The Duke of Pei said: "At first when King Huai sent me, it was precisely because I am capable of being tolerant and magnanimous; moreover, the man has already submitted in surrender—to kill him again would be inauspicious." He then handed the King of Qin over to officials and proceeded west into Xianyang. He wished to stop and rest in the palaces, but Fan Kuai and Zhang Liang remonstrated; he then sealed Qin's precious treasures, wealth, and goods in the treasuries, and returned his army to Bashang. He summoned the elders and heroes of the various counties and said: "The elders have long suffered under Qin's harsh laws; those who spoke ill had their clans exterminated, those who spoke together in pairs were executed in the marketplace. I made an agreement with the feudal lords: he who first enters the passes shall be its king; I should be king of Guanzhong. I make an agreement with the elders—laws of only three articles: he who kills shall die, he who wounds others or steals shall be punished accordingly. All the rest of Qin's laws are eliminated. All officials and people shall remain peacefully as before. The reason I have come is to eliminate harm for the elders, not to invade or commit violence—have no fear! Moreover, the reason I have returned my army to Bashang is to wait for the feudal lords to arrive and establish agreements." He then sent people with Qin officials to go through the counties, districts, and townships to inform and instruct them. The Qin people were greatly pleased and competed to bring oxen, sheep, wine, and food to offer feasts for the soldiers. The Duke of Pei again declined and would not accept, saying: "The granaries have abundant grain; there is no scarcity—I do not wish to burden the people." The people were even more pleased and only feared the Duke of Pei would not become King of Qin.

sentences.zh: 或說沛公曰：「秦富十倍天下，地形彊。

translations.literal: Someone persuaded the Duke of Pei, saying: "Qin is ten times richer than all under Heaven, and its terrain is strong.
translations.idiomatic: Someone persuaded the Duke of Pei, saying: 'Qin is ten times richer than all under Heaven, and its terrain is strong.'

sentences.zh: 今聞章邯降項羽，項羽乃號為雍王，王關中。

translations.literal: Now I hear Zhang Han has surrendered to Xiang Yu, and Xiang Yu has taken the title King of Yong to rule Guanzhong.
translations.idiomatic: Now I hear Zhang Han has surrendered to Xiang Yu, and Xiang Yu has taken the title King of Yong to rule Guanzhong.

sentences.zh: 今則來，沛公恐不得有此。

translations.literal: Now if he comes, Duke of Pei fears cannot possess this.
translations.idiomatic: Now if he comes, Duke of Pei fears he cannot possess this.

sentences.zh: 可急使兵守函谷關，無內諸侯軍，稍徵關中兵以自益，距之。」

translations.literal: You should urgently send troops to defend Hangu Pass, not admit the feudal lords' armies, and gradually conscript troops from Guanzhong to strengthen yourself and resist them."
translations.idiomatic: You should urgently send troops to defend Hangu Pass, not admit the feudal lords' armies, gradually conscript troops from Guanzhong to strengthen yourself, and resist them.''

sentences.zh: 沛公然其計，從之。

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei agreed with this plan and followed it.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei agreed with this plan and followed it.

sentences.zh: 十一月中，項羽果率諸侯兵西，欲入關，關門閉。

translations.literal: In the eleventh month, Xiang Yu indeed led the feudal lords' troops west wishing to enter the passes, but the pass gates were closed.
translations.idiomatic: In the eleventh month, Xiang Yu indeed led the feudal lords' troops west wishing to enter the passes, but the pass gates were closed.

sentences.zh: 聞沛公已定關中，大怒，使黥布等攻破函谷關。

translations.literal: Hearing that the Duke of Pei had already settled Guanzhong, he was greatly enraged and sent Qing Bu and others to attack and break through Hangu Pass.
translations.idiomatic: Hearing that the Duke of Pei had already settled Guanzhong, he was greatly enraged and sent Qing Bu and others to attack and break through Hangu Pass.

sentences.zh: 十二月中，遂至戲。

translations.literal: In the twelfth month, they then reached Xi.
translations.idiomatic: In the twelfth month, they then reached Xi.

sentences.zh: 沛公左司馬曹無傷聞項王怒，欲攻沛公，使人言項羽曰：「沛公欲王關中，令子嬰為相，珍寶盡有之。」

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei's Left Major Cao Wushang heard that King Xiang was angry and wished to attack the Duke of Pei, so he sent someone to tell Xiang Yu: "The Duke of Pei wishes to be king of Guanzhong, make Ziying prime minister, and possess all the precious treasures."
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei's Left Major Cao Wushang heard that King Xiang was angry and wished to attack the Duke of Pei, so he sent someone to tell Xiang Yu: 'The Duke of Pei wishes to be king of Guanzhong, make Ziying prime minister, and possess all the precious treasures.''

sentences.zh: 欲以求封。

translations.literal: He wished to seek enfeoffment by this.
translations.idiomatic: He wished to seek enfeoffment by this.

sentences.zh: 亞父勸項羽擊沛公。

translations.literal: The Second Father urged Xiang Yu to strike the Duke of Pei.
translations.idiomatic: The Second Father urged Xiang Yu to strike the Duke of Pei.

sentences.zh: 方饗士，旦日合戰。

translations.literal: They were feasting the troops and would join battle the next day.
translations.idiomatic: They were feasting the troops and would join battle the next day.

sentences.zh: 是時項羽兵四十萬，號百萬。

translations.literal: At that time Xiang Yu had four hundred thousand troops, claimed to be a million.
translations.idiomatic: At that time Xiang Yu had four hundred thousand troops, claimed to be a million.

sentences.zh: 沛公兵十萬，號二十萬，力不敵。

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei had one hundred thousand troops, claimed to be two hundred thousand; in strength they were no match.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei had one hundred thousand troops, claimed to be two hundred thousand; in strength they were no match.

sentences.zh: 會項伯欲活張良，夜往見良，因以文諭項羽，項羽乃止。

translations.literal: It happened that Xiang Bo wished to save Zhang Liang's life; by night he went to see Liang and consequently with elegant words persuaded Xiang Yu, and Xiang Yu then desisted.
translations.idiomatic: It happened that Xiang Bo wished to save Zhang Liang's life. By night he went to see Liang and consequently with elegant words persuaded Xiang Yu, and Xiang Yu then desisted.

sentences.zh: 沛公從百餘騎，驅之鴻門，見謝項羽。

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei with over a hundred cavalry galloped to Hongmen to see and apologize to Xiang Yu.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei with over a hundred cavalry galloped to Hongmen to see and apologize to Xiang Yu.

sentences.zh: 項羽曰：「此沛公左司馬曹無傷言之。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu said: "This was told by the Duke of Pei's Left Major Cao Wushang.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu said: 'This was told by the Duke of Pei's Left Major Cao Wushang.'

sentences.zh: 不然，籍何以生此！」

translations.literal: If not, how would I have come to this suspicion!"
translations.idiomatic: If not, how would I have come to this suspicion!''

sentences.zh: 沛公以樊噲、張良故，得解歸。

translations.literal: The Duke of Pei through Fan Kuai and Zhang Liang's efforts was able to be released and return.
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Pei through Fan Kuai and Zhang Liang's efforts was able to be released and return.

sentences.zh: 歸，立誅曹無傷。

translations.literal: Returning, he immediately executed Cao Wushang.
translations.idiomatic: Returning, he immediately executed Cao Wushang.

translations.literal: Someone persuaded the Duke of Pei, saying: "Qin is ten times richer than all under Heaven, and its terrain is strong. Now I hear Zhang Han has surrendered to Xiang Yu, and Xiang Yu has taken the title King of Yong to rule Guanzhong. Now if he comes, Duke of Pei fears cannot possess this. You should urgently send troops to defend Hangu Pass, not admit the feudal lords' armies, and gradually conscript troops from Guanzhong to strengthen yourself and resist them." The Duke of Pei agreed with this plan and followed it. In the eleventh month, Xiang Yu indeed led the feudal lords' troops west wishing to enter the passes, but the pass gates were closed. Hearing that the Duke of Pei had already settled Guanzhong, he was greatly enraged and sent Qing Bu and others to attack and break through Hangu Pass. In the twelfth month, they then reached Xi. The Duke of Pei's Left Major Cao Wushang heard that King Xiang was angry and wished to attack the Duke of Pei, so he sent someone to tell Xiang Yu: "The Duke of Pei wishes to be king of Guanzhong, make Ziying prime minister, and possess all the precious treasures." He wished to seek enfeoffment by this. The Second Father urged Xiang Yu to strike the Duke of Pei. They were feasting the troops and would join battle the next day. At that time Xiang Yu had four hundred thousand troops, claimed to be a million. The Duke of Pei had one hundred thousand troops, claimed to be two hundred thousand; in strength they were no match. It happened that Xiang Bo wished to save Zhang Liang's life; by night he went to see Liang and consequently with elegant words persuaded Xiang Yu, and Xiang Yu then desisted. The Duke of Pei with over a hundred cavalry galloped to Hongmen to see and apologize to Xiang Yu. Xiang Yu said: "This was told by the Duke of Pei's Left Major Cao Wushang. If not, how would I have come to this suspicion!" The Duke of Pei through Fan Kuai and Zhang Liang's efforts was able to be released and return. Returning, he immediately executed Cao Wushang.

sentences.zh: 項羽遂西，屠燒咸陽秦宮室，所過無不殘破。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu then went west, massacred and burned Xianyang and the Qin palace chambers; wherever he passed he completely destroyed everything.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu then went west, massacred and burned Xianyang and the Qin palace chambers. Wherever he passed he completely destroyed everything.

sentences.zh: 秦人大失望，然恐，不敢不服耳。

translations.literal: The Qin people were greatly disappointed but were afraid and dared not disobey.
translations.idiomatic: The Qin people were greatly disappointed but were afraid and dared not disobey.

translations.literal: Xiang Yu then went west, massacred and burned Xianyang and the Qin palace chambers; wherever he passed he completely destroyed everything. The Qin people were greatly disappointed but were afraid and dared not disobey.

sentences.zh: 項羽使人還報懷王。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu sent men to report back to King Huai.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu sent men to report back to King Huai.

sentences.zh: 懷王曰：「如約。」

translations.literal: King Huai said: "According to the agreement."
translations.idiomatic: King Huai said: 'According to the agreement.''

sentences.zh: 項羽怨懷王不肯令與沛公俱西入關，而北救趙，後天下約。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu resented that King Huai would not permit him to go west into the passes together with the Duke of Pei, but instead went north to rescue Zhao, coming after the agreement about all under Heaven.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu resented that King Huai would not permit him to go west into the passes together with the Duke of Pei, but instead went north to rescue Zhao, coming after the agreement about all under Heaven.

sentences.zh: 乃曰：「懷王者，吾家項梁所立耳，非有功伐，何以得主約！

translations.literal: He then said: "King Huai was merely installed by my kinsman Xiang Liang; he has no achievements or victories—how can he preside over the agreement!
translations.idiomatic: He then said: 'King Huai was merely installed by my kinsman Xiang Liang; he has no achievements or victories—how can he preside over the agreement!'

sentences.zh: 本定天下，諸將及籍也。」

translations.literal: Those who originally settled all under Heaven were the various generals and I."
translations.idiomatic: Those who originally settled all under Heaven were the various generals and I.''

sentences.zh: 乃詳尊懷王為義帝，實不用其命。

translations.literal: He then outwardly honored King Huai as the Righteous Emperor but actually did not use his commands.
translations.idiomatic: He then outwardly honored King Huai as the Righteous Emperor but actually did not use his commands.

translations.literal: Xiang Yu sent men to report back to King Huai. King Huai said: "According to the agreement." Xiang Yu resented that King Huai would not permit him to go west into the passes together with the Duke of Pei, but instead went north to rescue Zhao, coming after the agreement about all under Heaven. He then said: "King Huai was merely installed by my kinsman Xiang Liang; he has no achievements or victories—how can he preside over the agreement! Those who originally settled all under Heaven were the various generals and I." He then outwardly honored King Huai as the Righteous Emperor but actually did not use his commands.

sentences.zh: 正月，項羽自立為西楚霸王，王梁、楚地九郡，都彭城。

translations.literal: In the first month, Xiang Yu made himself King of Western Chu, ruling nine commanderies of Liang and Chu, with his capital at Pengcheng.
translations.idiomatic: In the first month, Xiang Yu made himself King of Western Chu, ruling nine commanderies of Liang and Chu, with his capital at Pengcheng.

sentences.zh: 負約，更立沛公為漢王，王巴、蜀、漢中，都南鄭。

translations.literal: Breaking the agreement, he instead installed the Duke of Pei as King of Han, to rule Ba, Shu, and Hanzhong, with his capital at Nanzheng.
translations.idiomatic: Breaking the agreement, he instead installed the Duke of Pei as King of Han, to rule Ba, Shu, and Hanzhong, with his capital at Nanzheng.

sentences.zh: 三分關中，立秦三將：章邯為雍王，都廢丘；

translations.literal: He divided Guanzhong into three parts and installed the three Qin generals: Zhang Han as King of Yong, with his capital at Feiqiu;
translations.idiomatic: He divided Guanzhong into three parts and installed the three Qin generals: Zhang Han as King of Yong, with his capital at Feiqiu;

sentences.zh: 司馬欣為塞王，都櫟陽；

translations.literal: Sima Xin as King of Sai, with his capital at Liyang;
translations.idiomatic: Sima Xin as King of Sai, with his capital at Liyang;

sentences.zh: 董翳為翟王，都高奴。

translations.literal: Dong Yi as King of Di, with his capital at Gaonu.
translations.idiomatic: Dong Yi as King of Di, with his capital at Gaonu.

sentences.zh: 楚將瑕丘申陽為河南王，都洛陽。

translations.literal: Chu general Shen Yang of Xiaqiu as King of Henan, with his capital at Luoyang.
translations.idiomatic: Chu general Shen Yang of Xiaqiu as King of Henan, with his capital at Luoyang.

sentences.zh: 趙將司馬卬為殷王，都朝歌。

translations.literal: Zhao general Sima Ang as King of Yin, with his capital at Chaoge.
translations.idiomatic: Zhao general Sima Ang as King of Yin, with his capital at Chaoge.

sentences.zh: 趙王歇徙王代。

translations.literal: King Xie of Zhao was moved to be King of Dai.
translations.idiomatic: King Xie of Zhao was moved to be King of Dai.

sentences.zh: 趙相張耳為常山王，都襄國。

translations.literal: Zhao's Prime Minister Zhang Er as King of Changshan, with his capital at Xiangguo.
translations.idiomatic: Zhao's Prime Minister Zhang Er as King of Changshan, with his capital at Xiangguo.

sentences.zh: 當陽君黥布為九江王，都六。

translations.literal: Lord Dangyang Qing Bu as King of Jiujiang, with his capital at Liu.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Dangyang Qing Bu as King of Jiujiang, with his capital at Liu.

sentences.zh: 懷王柱國共敖為臨江王，都江陵。

translations.literal: King Huai's Supreme Pillar of State Gong Ao as King of Linjiang, with his capital at Jiangling.
translations.idiomatic: King Huai's Supreme Pillar of State Gong Ao as King of Linjiang, with his capital at Jiangling.

sentences.zh: 番君吳芮為衡山王，都邾。

translations.literal: Lord Fan Wu Rui as King of Hengshan, with his capital at Zhu.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Fan Wu Rui as King of Hengshan, with his capital at Zhu.

sentences.zh: 燕將臧荼為燕王，都薊。

translations.literal: Yan general Zang Tu as King of Yan, with his capital at Ji.
translations.idiomatic: Yan general Zang Tu as King of Yan, with his capital at Ji.

sentences.zh: 故燕王韓廣徙王遼東。

translations.literal: The former King of Yan Han Guang was moved to be King of Liaodong.
translations.idiomatic: The former King of Yan Han Guang was moved to be King of Liaodong.

sentences.zh: 廣不聽，臧荼攻殺之無終。

translations.literal: Guang would not obey; Zang Tu attacked and killed him at Wuzhong.
translations.idiomatic: Guang would not obey; Zang Tu attacked and killed him at Wuzhong.

sentences.zh: 封成安君陳餘河閒三縣，居南皮。

translations.literal: He enfeoffed Lord Chengan Chen Yu with three counties of Hejian, residing at Nanpi.
translations.idiomatic: He enfeoffed Lord Chengan Chen Yu with three counties of Hejian, residing at Nanpi.

sentences.zh: 封梅鋗十萬戶。

translations.literal: He enfeoffed Mei Xuan with a hundred thousand households.
translations.idiomatic: He enfeoffed Mei Xuan with a hundred thousand households.

translations.literal: In the first month, Xiang Yu made himself King of Western Chu, ruling nine commanderies of Liang and Chu, with his capital at Pengcheng. Breaking the agreement, he instead installed the Duke of Pei as King of Han, to rule Ba, Shu, and Hanzhong, with his capital at Nanzheng. He divided Guanzhong into three parts and installed the three Qin generals: Zhang Han as King of Yong, with his capital at Feiqiu; Sima Xin as King of Sai, with his capital at Liyang; Dong Yi as King of Di, with his capital at Gaonu. Chu general Shen Yang of Xiaqiu as King of Henan, with his capital at Luoyang. Zhao general Sima Ang as King of Yin, with his capital at Chaoge. King Xie of Zhao was moved to be King of Dai. Zhao's Prime Minister Zhang Er as King of Changshan, with his capital at Xiangguo. Lord Dangyang Qing Bu as King of Jiujiang, with his capital at Liu. King Huai's Supreme Pillar of State Gong Ao as King of Linjiang, with his capital at Jiangling. Lord Fan Wu Rui as King of Hengshan, with his capital at Zhu. Yan general Zang Tu as King of Yan, with his capital at Ji. The former King of Yan Han Guang was moved to be King of Liaodong. Guang would not obey; Zang Tu attacked and killed him at Wuzhong. He enfeoffed Lord Chengan Chen Yu with three counties of Hejian, residing at Nanpi. He enfeoffed Mei Xuan with a hundred thousand households.

sentences.zh: 四月，兵罷戲下，諸侯各就國。

translations.literal: In the fourth month, the troops were dismissed below Xi; the feudal lords each went to their states.
translations.idiomatic: In the fourth month, the troops were dismissed below Xi; the feudal lords each went to their states.

sentences.zh: 漢王之國，項王使卒三萬人從，楚與諸侯之慕從者數萬人，從杜南入蝕中。

translations.literal: When the King of Han went to his state, King Xiang sent thirty thousand troops to follow; those from Chu and the feudal lords who admired and followed numbered several tens of thousands; they entered Shizh from south of Du.
translations.idiomatic: When the King of Han went to his state, King Xiang sent thirty thousand troops to follow. Those from Chu and the feudal lords who admired and followed numbered several tens of thousands. They entered Shizh from south of Du.

sentences.zh: 去輒燒絕棧道，以備諸侯盜兵襲之，亦示項羽無東意。

translations.literal: As they departed they immediately burned and severed the plank roads to prepare against the feudal lords' troops raiding them, and also to show Xiang Yu they had no intention of going east.
translations.idiomatic: As they departed they immediately burned and severed the plank roads to prepare against the feudal lords' troops raiding them, and also to show Xiang Yu they had no intention of going east.

sentences.zh: 至南鄭，諸將及士卒多道亡歸，士卒皆歌思東歸。

translations.literal: Reaching Nanzheng, many generals and officers and troops escaped on the road and returned; the officers and troops all sang songs longing to return east.
translations.idiomatic: Reaching Nanzheng, many generals and officers and troops escaped on the road and returned. The officers and troops all sang songs longing to return east.

sentences.zh: 韓信說漢王曰：「項羽王諸將之有功者，而王獨居南鄭，是遷也。

translations.literal: Han Xin persuaded the King of Han, saying: "Xiang Yu made kings of generals who had achievements, while the king alone resides at Nanzheng—this is exile.
translations.idiomatic: Han Xin persuaded the King of Han, saying: 'Xiang Yu made kings of generals who had achievements, while the king alone resides at Nanzheng—this is exile.'

sentences.zh: 軍吏士卒皆山東之人也，日夜跂而望歸，及其鋒而用之，可以有大功。

translations.literal: The military officers and troops are all men from east of the mountains; day and night they stand on tiptoe longing to return—use them while they are at their peak and you can achieve great merit.
translations.idiomatic: The military officers and troops are all men from east of the mountains. Day and night they stand on tiptoe longing to return—use them while they are at their peak and you can achieve great merit.

sentences.zh: 天下已定，人皆自寧，不可復用。

translations.literal: Once all under Heaven is settled, people will all seek their own comfort and cannot be used again.
translations.idiomatic: Once all under Heaven is settled, people will all seek their own comfort and cannot be used again.

sentences.zh: 不如決策東鄉，爭權天下。」

translations.literal: It would be better to make a decisive plan to face east and contend for authority over all under Heaven."
translations.idiomatic: It would be better to make a decisive plan to face east and contend for authority over all under Heaven.''

translations.literal: In the fourth month, the troops were dismissed below Xi; the feudal lords each went to their states. When the King of Han went to his state, King Xiang sent thirty thousand troops to follow; those from Chu and the feudal lords who admired and followed numbered several tens of thousands; they entered Shizh from south of Du. As they departed they immediately burned and severed the plank roads to prepare against the feudal lords' troops raiding them, and also to show Xiang Yu they had no intention of going east. Reaching Nanzheng, many generals and officers and troops escaped on the road and returned; the officers and troops all sang songs longing to return east. Han Xin persuaded the King of Han, saying: "Xiang Yu made kings of generals who had achievements, while the king alone resides at Nanzheng—this is exile. The military officers and troops are all men from east of the mountains; day and night they stand on tiptoe longing to return—use them while they are at their peak and you can achieve great merit. Once all under Heaven is settled, people will all seek their own comfort and cannot be used again. It would be better to make a decisive plan to face east and contend for authority over all under Heaven."

sentences.zh: 項羽出關，使人徙義帝。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu having left the passes sent men to relocate the Righteous Emperor.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu having left the passes sent men to relocate the Righteous Emperor.

sentences.zh: 曰：「古之帝者地方千里，必居上游。」

translations.literal: He said: "Ancient emperors had territories a thousand li square and must reside at the upper reaches."
translations.idiomatic: He said: 'Ancient emperors had territories a thousand li square and must reside at the upper reaches.''

sentences.zh: 乃使使徙義帝長沙郴縣，趣義帝行，群臣稍倍叛之，乃陰令衡山王、臨江王擊之，殺義帝江南。

translations.literal: He then sent envoys to relocate the Righteous Emperor to Chen County in Changsha, urged the Righteous Emperor to travel; the assembled ministers gradually betrayed and rebelled against him, and he then secretly ordered the King of Hengshan and King of Linjiang to strike and kill the Righteous Emperor south of the Yangtze.
translations.idiomatic: He then sent envoys to relocate the Righteous Emperor to Chen County in Changsha and urged the Righteous Emperor to travel. The assembled ministers gradually betrayed and rebelled against him, and he then secretly ordered the King of Hengshan and King of Linjiang to strike and kill the Righteous Emperor south of the Yangtze.

sentences.zh: 項羽怨田榮，立齊將田都為齊王。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu resented Tian Rong and installed Qi general Tian Du as King of Qi.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu resented Tian Rong and installed Qi general Tian Du as King of Qi.

sentences.zh: 田榮怒，因自立為齊王，殺田都而反楚；

translations.literal: Tian Rong was angry and consequently made himself King of Qi, killed Tian Du, and rebelled against Chu;
translations.idiomatic: Tian Rong was angry and consequently made himself King of Qi, killed Tian Du, and rebelled against Chu;

sentences.zh: 予彭越將軍印，令反梁地。

translations.literal: Gave Peng Yue general seal, ordered him to rebel in Liang lands.
translations.idiomatic: He gave Peng Yue a general's seal and ordered him to rebel in Liang territory.

sentences.zh: 楚令蕭公角擊彭越，彭越大破之。

translations.literal: Chu ordered Xiao Gongjiao to strike Peng Yue; Peng Yue greatly broke him.
translations.idiomatic: Chu ordered Xiao Gongjiao to strike Peng Yue; Peng Yue decisively defeated him.

sentences.zh: 陳餘怨項羽之弗王己也，令夏說說田榮，請兵擊張耳。

translations.literal: Chen Yu resented that Xiang Yu had not made him king; he had Xia Shuo persuade Tian Rong to request troops to strike Zhang Er.
translations.idiomatic: Chen Yu resented that Xiang Yu had not made him king. He had Xia Shuo persuade Tian Rong to request troops to strike Zhang Er.

sentences.zh: 齊予陳餘兵，擊破常山王張耳，張耳亡歸漢。

translations.literal: Qi gave Chen Yu troops; he struck and broke King Zhang Er of Changshan; Zhang Er fled and submitted to Han.
translations.idiomatic: Qi gave Chen Yu troops. He struck and broke King Zhang Er of Changshan. Zhang Er fled and submitted to Han.

sentences.zh: 迎趙王歇於代，復立為趙王。

translations.literal: They welcomed King Xie of Zhao from Dai and again installed him as King of Zhao.
translations.idiomatic: They welcomed King Xie of Zhao from Dai and again installed him as King of Zhao.

sentences.zh: 趙王因立陳餘為代王。

translations.literal: The King of Zhao consequently installed Chen Yu as King of Dai.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Zhao consequently installed Chen Yu as King of Dai.

sentences.zh: 項羽大怒，北擊齊。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu was greatly enraged and attacked Qi to the north.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu was greatly enraged and attacked Qi to the north.

translations.literal: Xiang Yu having left the passes sent men to relocate the Righteous Emperor. He said: "Ancient emperors had territories a thousand li square and must reside at the upper reaches." He then sent envoys to relocate the Righteous Emperor to Chen County in Changsha, urged the Righteous Emperor to travel; the assembled ministers gradually betrayed and rebelled against him, and he then secretly ordered the King of Hengshan and King of Linjiang to strike and kill the Righteous Emperor south of the Yangtze. Xiang Yu resented Tian Rong and installed Qi general Tian Du as King of Qi. Tian Rong was angry and consequently made himself King of Qi, killed Tian Du, and rebelled against Chu; Gave Peng Yue general seal, ordered him to rebel in Liang lands. Chu ordered Xiao Gongjiao to strike Peng Yue; Peng Yue greatly broke him. Chen Yu resented that Xiang Yu had not made him king; he had Xia Shuo persuade Tian Rong to request troops to strike Zhang Er. Qi gave Chen Yu troops; he struck and broke King Zhang Er of Changshan; Zhang Er fled and submitted to Han. They welcomed King Xie of Zhao from Dai and again installed him as King of Zhao. The King of Zhao consequently installed Chen Yu as King of Dai. Xiang Yu was greatly enraged and attacked Qi to the north.

sentences.zh: 八月，漢王用韓信之計，從故道還，襲雍王章邯。

translations.literal: In the eighth month, the King of Han used Han Xin's stratagem, returned from the old road, and launched a surprise attack on King Zhang Han of Yong.
translations.idiomatic: In the eighth month, the King of Han used Han Xin's stratagem. He returned from the old road and launched a surprise attack on King Zhang Han of Yong.

sentences.zh: 邯迎擊漢陳倉，雍兵敗，還走；

translations.literal: Han met and struck Han at Chencang; the Yong troops were defeated and fled back;
translations.idiomatic: Zhang Han met and struck the Han forces at Chencang. The Yong troops were defeated and fled back;

sentences.zh: 止戰好畤，又復敗，走廢丘。

translations.literal: they made a stand and fought at Haozhi, were again defeated, and fled to Feiqiu.
translations.idiomatic: They made a stand and fought at Haozhi, were again defeated, and fled to Feiqiu.

sentences.zh: 漢王遂定雍地。

translations.literal: The King of Han then settled the territory of Yong.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han then settled the territory of Yong.

sentences.zh: 東至咸陽，引兵圍雍王廢丘，而遣諸將略定隴西、北地、上郡。

translations.literal: Going east to Xianyang, he led troops to besiege King of Yong at Feiqiu, and dispatched various generals to take and settle Longxi, Beidi, and Shangjun.
translations.idiomatic: Going east to Xianyang, he led troops to besiege the King of Yong at Feiqiu, and dispatched various generals to seize and settle Longxi, Beidi, and Shangjun.

sentences.zh: 令將軍薛歐、王吸出武關，因王陵兵南陽，以迎太公、呂後於沛。

translations.literal: He ordered generals Xue Ou and Wang Xi to go out through Wuguan, use Wang Ling's troops at Nanyang, to welcome the Grand Duke and Empress Lü at Pei.
translations.idiomatic: He ordered generals Xue Ou and Wang Xi to go out through Wuguan, use Wang Ling's troops at Nanyang, to welcome the Grand Duke and Empress Lü at Pei.

sentences.zh: 楚聞之，發兵距之陽夏，不得前。

translations.literal: Chu heard of this and sent troops to resist them at Yangxia; they could not advance.
translations.idiomatic: Chu heard of this and sent troops to resist them at Yangxia; they could not advance.

sentences.zh: 令故吳令鄭昌為韓王，距漢兵。

translations.literal: He ordered the former magistrate of Wu, Zheng Chang, to be King of Han to resist the Han troops.
translations.idiomatic: He ordered the former magistrate of Wu, Zheng Chang, to be King of Han to resist the Han troops.

translations.literal: In the eighth month, the King of Han used Han Xin's stratagem, returned from the old road, and launched a surprise attack on King Zhang Han of Yong. Han met and struck Han at Chencang; the Yong troops were defeated and fled back; they made a stand and fought at Haozhi, were again defeated, and fled to Feiqiu. The King of Han then settled the territory of Yong. Going east to Xianyang, he led troops to besiege King of Yong at Feiqiu, and dispatched various generals to take and settle Longxi, Beidi, and Shangjun. He ordered generals Xue Ou and Wang Xi to go out through Wuguan, use Wang Ling's troops at Nanyang, to welcome the Grand Duke and Empress Lü at Pei. Chu heard of this and sent troops to resist them at Yangxia; they could not advance. He ordered the former magistrate of Wu, Zheng Chang, to be King of Han to resist the Han troops.

sentences.zh: 二年，漢王東略地，塞王欣、翟王翳、河南王申陽皆降。

translations.literal: In the second year, the King of Han went east taking territory; King Xin of Sai, King Yi of Di, and King Shen Yang of Henan all surrendered.
translations.idiomatic: In the second year, the King of Han went east taking territory. King Xin of Sai, King Yi of Di, and King Shen Yang of Henan all surrendered.

sentences.zh: 韓王昌不聽，使韓信擊破之。

translations.literal: King Chang of Han would not obey; he sent Han Xin to strike and break him.
translations.idiomatic: King Chang of Han would not obey. He sent Han Xin to strike and break him.

sentences.zh: 於是置隴西、北地、上郡、渭南、河上、中地郡；

translations.literal: Thereupon he established Longxi, Beidi, Shangjun, Weinan, Heshang, and Zhongdi commanderies;
translations.idiomatic: Thereupon he established Longxi, Beidi, Shangjun, Weinan, Heshang, and Zhongdi commanderies;

sentences.zh: 關外置河南郡。

translations.literal: outside the passes he established Henan Commandery.
translations.idiomatic: Outside the passes he established Henan Commandery.

sentences.zh: 更立韓太尉信為韓王。

translations.literal: He reinstalled Han's Grand Commandant Xin as King of Han.
translations.idiomatic: He reinstalled Han's Grand Commandant Xin as King of Han.

sentences.zh: 諸將以萬人若以一郡降者，封萬戶。

translations.literal: Generals who surrendered with ten thousand men or with a commandery were enfeoffed with ten thousand households.
translations.idiomatic: Generals who surrendered with ten thousand men or with a commandery were enfeoffed with ten thousand households.

sentences.zh: 繕治河上塞。

translations.literal: They repaired and constructed the fortifications along the Yellow River.
translations.idiomatic: They repaired and constructed the fortifications along the Yellow River.

sentences.zh: 諸故秦苑囿園池，皆令人得田之，正月，虜雍王弟章平。

translations.literal: All the former Qin parks, gardens, and ponds were permitted for people to farm; in the first month, they captured Chapter Ping, younger brother of the King of Yong.
translations.idiomatic: All the former Qin parks, gardens, and ponds were permitted for people to farm. In the first month, they captured Zhang Ping, younger brother of the King of Yong.

sentences.zh: 大赦罪人。

translations.literal: They granted a great amnesty to criminals.
translations.idiomatic: They granted a great amnesty to criminals.

translations.literal: In the second year, the King of Han went east taking territory; King Xin of Sai, King Yi of Di, and King Shen Yang of Henan all surrendered. King Chang of Han would not obey; he sent Han Xin to strike and break him. Thereupon he established Longxi, Beidi, Shangjun, Weinan, Heshang, and Zhongdi commanderies; outside the passes he established Henan Commandery. He reinstalled Han's Grand Commandant Xin as King of Han. Generals who surrendered with ten thousand men or with a commandery were enfeoffed with ten thousand households. They repaired and constructed the fortifications along the Yellow River. All the former Qin parks, gardens, and ponds were permitted for people to farm; in the first month, they captured Chapter Ping, younger brother of the King of Yong. They granted a great amnesty to criminals.

sentences.zh: 漢王之出關至陜，撫關外父老，還，張耳來見，漢王厚遇之。

translations.literal: When the King of Han left the passes and reached Shan, he consoled the fathers and elders outside the passes, returned, and Zhang Er came to see him; the King of Han treated him generously.
translations.idiomatic: When the King of Han left the passes and reached Shan, he consoled the fathers and elders outside the passes. He returned, and Zhang Er came to see him. The King of Han treated him generously.

translations.literal: When the King of Han left the passes and reached Shan, he consoled the fathers and elders outside the passes, returned, and Zhang Er came to see him; the King of Han treated him generously.

sentences.zh: 二月，令除秦社稷，更立漢社稷。

translations.literal: In the second month, he ordered the elimination of Qin's altars of soil and grain and the establishment anew of Han's altars of soil and grain.
translations.idiomatic: In the second month, he ordered the elimination of Qin's altars of soil and grain and the establishment anew of Han's altars of soil and grain.

translations.literal: In the second month, he ordered the elimination of Qin's altars of soil and grain and the establishment anew of Han's altars of soil and grain.

sentences.zh: 三月，漢王從臨晉渡，魏王豹將兵從。

translations.literal: In the third month, the King of Han crossed from Linjin; King Bao of Wei led troops to follow.
translations.idiomatic: In the third month, the King of Han crossed from Linjin. King Bao of Wei led troops to follow.

sentences.zh: 下河內，虜殷王，置河內郡。

translations.literal: He took Henei, captured the King of Yin, and established Henei Commandery.
translations.idiomatic: He took Henei, captured the King of Yin, and established Henei Commandery.

sentences.zh: 南渡平陰津，至雒陽。

translations.literal: He crossed south over Pingyin ford and reached Luoyang.
translations.idiomatic: He crossed south over Pingyin ford and reached Luoyang.

sentences.zh: 新城三老董公遮說漢王以義帝死故。

translations.literal: Elder Dong Gong of Xincheng blocked the way and persuaded the King of Han with the story of the Righteous Emperor's death.
translations.idiomatic: Elder Dong Gong of Xincheng blocked the way and persuaded the King of Han with the story of the Righteous Emperor's death.

sentences.zh: 漢王聞之，袒而大哭。

translations.literal: The King of Han heard this, bared his torso, and wept loudly.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han heard this, bared his torso, and wept loudly.

sentences.zh: 遂為義帝發喪，臨三日。

translations.literal: He then announced mourning for the Righteous Emperor and mourned for three days.
translations.idiomatic: He then announced mourning for the Righteous Emperor and mourned for three days.

sentences.zh: 發使者告諸侯曰：「天下共立義帝，北面事之。

translations.literal: He sent envoys to inform the feudal lords, saying: "All under Heaven together installed the Righteous Emperor and faced north to serve him.
translations.idiomatic: He sent envoys to inform the feudal lords, saying: 'All under Heaven together installed the Righteous Emperor and faced north to serve him.'

sentences.zh: 今項羽放殺義帝於江南，大逆無道。

translations.literal: Now Xiang Yu has banished and killed the Righteous Emperor south of the Yangtze—this is great rebellion and lawlessness.
translations.idiomatic: Now Xiang Yu has banished and killed the Righteous Emperor south of the Yangtze—this is great rebellion and lawlessness.''

sentences.zh: 寡人親為發喪，諸侯皆縞素。

translations.literal: I personally have announced mourning; may all the feudal lords wear white mourning garments.
translations.idiomatic: I personally have announced mourning; may all the feudal lords wear white mourning garments.''

sentences.zh: 悉發關內兵，收三河士，南浮江漢以下，願從諸侯王擊楚之殺義帝者。」

translations.literal: Mobilize all troops within the passes, gather the gentlemen of the Three Rivers, float south down the Yangtze and Han rivers; I wish to follow the feudal lord kings to strike those of Chu who killed the Righteous Emperor."
translations.idiomatic: Mobilize all troops within the passes, gather the gentlemen of the Three Rivers, float south down the Yangtze and Han rivers. I wish to follow the feudal lord kings to strike those of Chu who killed the Righteous Emperor.''

translations.literal: In the third month, the King of Han crossed from Linjin; King Bao of Wei led troops to follow. He took Henei, captured the King of Yin, and established Henei Commandery. He crossed south over Pingyin ford and reached Luoyang. Elder Dong Gong of Xincheng blocked the way and persuaded the King of Han with the story of the Righteous Emperor's death. The King of Han heard this, bared his torso, and wept loudly. He then announced mourning for the Righteous Emperor and mourned for three days. He sent envoys to inform the feudal lords, saying: "All under Heaven together installed the Righteous Emperor and faced north to serve him. Now Xiang Yu has banished and killed the Righteous Emperor south of the Yangtze—this is great rebellion and lawlessness. I personally have announced mourning; may all the feudal lords wear white mourning garments. Mobilize all troops within the passes, gather the gentlemen of the Three Rivers, float south down the Yangtze and Han rivers; I wish to follow the feudal lord kings to strike those of Chu who killed the Righteous Emperor."

sentences.zh: 是時項王北擊齊，田榮與戰城陽。

translations.literal: At this time King Xiang was attacking Qi to the north; Tian Rong fought with him at Chengyang.
translations.idiomatic: At this time King Xiang was attacking Qi to the north. Tian Rong fought with him at Chengyang.

sentences.zh: 田榮敗，走平原，平原民殺之。

translations.literal: Tian Rong was defeated and fled to Pingyuan; the people of Pingyuan killed him.
translations.idiomatic: Tian Rong was defeated and fled to Pingyuan. The people of Pingyuan killed him.

sentences.zh: 齊皆降楚。

translations.literal: All of Qi surrendered to Chu.
translations.idiomatic: All of Qi surrendered to Chu.

sentences.zh: 楚因焚燒其城郭，系虜其子女。

translations.literal: Chu consequently burned their city walls and took their sons and daughters as captives.
translations.idiomatic: Chu consequently burned their city walls and took their sons and daughters as captives.

sentences.zh: 齊人叛之。

translations.literal: The Qi people rebelled against them.
translations.idiomatic: The Qi people rebelled against them.

sentences.zh: 田榮弟橫立榮子廣為齊王，齊王反楚城陽。

translations.literal: Tian Rong's younger brother Heng installed Rong's son Guang as King of Qi; the King of Qi rebelled against Chu at Chengyang.
translations.idiomatic: Tian Rong's younger brother Heng installed Rong's son Guang as King of Qi. The King of Qi rebelled against Chu at Chengyang.

sentences.zh: 項羽雖聞漢東，既已連齊兵，欲遂破之而擊漢。

translations.literal: Though Xiang Yu heard Han had gone east, having already engaged Qi's troops, he wished to completely break them before striking Han.
translations.idiomatic: Though Xiang Yu heard Han had gone east, having already engaged Qi's troops, he wished to completely break them before striking Han.

sentences.zh: 漢王以故得劫五諸侯兵，遂入彭城。

translations.literal: The King of Han because of this was able to coerce the troops of five feudal lords and then entered Pengcheng.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han because of this was able to coerce the troops of five feudal lords and then entered Pengcheng.

sentences.zh: 項羽聞之，乃引兵去齊，從魯出胡陵，至蕭，與漢大戰彭城靈壁東睢水上，大破漢軍，多殺士卒，睢水為之不流。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu heard of this and led his troops away from Qi, came out from Lu through Huling, reached Xiao, and fought a great battle with Han at Pengcheng, east of Lingbi on the Sui River, greatly breaking the Han army, killing many officers and troops—the Sui River stopped flowing because of them.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu heard of this and led his troops away from Qi. He came out from Lu through Huling, reached Xiao, and fought a great battle with Han at Pengcheng, east of Lingbi on the Sui River. He greatly broke the Han army, killing many officers and troops—the Sui River stopped flowing because of them.

sentences.zh: 乃取漢王父母妻子於沛，置之軍中以為質。

translations.literal: He then took the King of Han's father, mother, wife, and children at Pei and placed them in the army as hostages.
translations.idiomatic: He then took the King of Han's father, mother, wife, and children at Pei and placed them in the army as hostages.

sentences.zh: 當是時，諸侯見楚彊漢敗，還皆去漢復為楚。

translations.literal: At that time, the feudal lords saw Chu was strong and Han defeated; they all turned away from Han and again became Chu.
translations.idiomatic: At that time, the feudal lords saw Chu was strong and Han defeated. They all turned away from Han and again became Chu.

sentences.zh: 塞王欣亡入楚。

translations.literal: King Xin of Sai fled and entered Chu.
translations.idiomatic: King Xin of Sai fled and entered Chu.

translations.literal: At this time King Xiang was attacking Qi to the north; Tian Rong fought with him at Chengyang. Tian Rong was defeated and fled to Pingyuan; the people of Pingyuan killed him. All of Qi surrendered to Chu. Chu consequently burned their city walls and took their sons and daughters as captives. The Qi people rebelled against them. Tian Rong's younger brother Heng installed Rong's son Guang as King of Qi; the King of Qi rebelled against Chu at Chengyang. Though Xiang Yu heard Han had gone east, having already engaged Qi's troops, he wished to completely break them before striking Han. The King of Han because of this was able to coerce the troops of five feudal lords and then entered Pengcheng. Xiang Yu heard of this and led his troops away from Qi, came out from Lu through Huling, reached Xiao, and fought a great battle with Han at Pengcheng, east of Lingbi on the Sui River, greatly breaking the Han army, killing many officers and troops—the Sui River stopped flowing because of them. He then took the King of Han's father, mother, wife, and children at Pei and placed them in the army as hostages. At that time, the feudal lords saw Chu was strong and Han defeated; they all turned away from Han and again became Chu. King Xin of Sai fled and entered Chu.

sentences.zh: 呂后兄周呂侯為漢將兵，居下邑。

translations.literal: Empress Lü's elder brother Lord Zhou Lü commanded Han troops, stationed at Xiayi.
translations.idiomatic: Empress Lü's elder brother Lord Zhou Lü commanded Han troops, stationed at Xiayi.

sentences.zh: 漢王從之，稍收士卒，軍碭。

translations.literal: The King of Han joined him and gradually gathered officers and troops, encamping at Dang.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han joined him and gradually gathered officers and troops, encamping at Dang.

sentences.zh: 漢王乃西過梁地，至虞。

translations.literal: The King of Han then went west through the land of Liang and reached Yu.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han then went west through the land of Liang and reached Yu.

sentences.zh: 使謁者隨何之九江王布所，曰：「公能令布舉兵叛楚，項羽必留擊之。

translations.literal: He sent the herald Sui He to the King of Jiujiang Bu's location, saying: "If you can make Bu raise troops and rebel against Chu, Xiang Yu will certainly remain to strike him.
translations.idiomatic: He sent the herald Sui He to the King of Jiujiang Bu's location, saying: 'If you can make Bu raise troops and rebel against Chu, Xiang Yu will certainly remain to strike him.'

sentences.zh: 得留數月，吾取天下必矣。」

translations.literal: If we can keep him there for several months, my taking of all under Heaven is certain."
translations.idiomatic: If we can keep him there for several months, my taking of all under Heaven is certain.''

sentences.zh: 隨何往說九江王布，布果背楚。

translations.literal: Sui He went and persuaded King Bu of Jiujiang; Bu indeed turned his back on Chu.
translations.idiomatic: Sui He went and persuaded King Bu of Jiujiang. Bu indeed turned his back on Chu.

sentences.zh: 楚使龍且往擊之。

translations.literal: Chu sent Long Ju to strike him.
translations.idiomatic: Chu sent Long Ju to strike him.

translations.literal: Empress Lü's elder brother Lord Zhou Lü commanded Han troops, stationed at Xiayi. The King of Han joined him and gradually gathered officers and troops, encamping at Dang. The King of Han then went west through the land of Liang and reached Yu. He sent the herald Sui He to the King of Jiujiang Bu's location, saying: "If you can make Bu raise troops and rebel against Chu, Xiang Yu will certainly remain to strike him. If we can keep him there for several months, my taking of all under Heaven is certain." Sui He went and persuaded King Bu of Jiujiang; Bu indeed turned his back on Chu. Chu sent Long Ju to strike him.

sentences.zh: 漢王之敗彭城而西，行使人求家室，家室亦亡，不相得。

translations.literal: When the King of Han was defeated at Pengcheng and went west, he sent people on the road to seek his family, but his family had also disappeared and they could not find each other.
translations.idiomatic: When the King of Han was defeated at Pengcheng and went west, he sent people on the road to seek his family. But his family had also disappeared and they could not find each other.

sentences.zh: 敗後乃獨得孝惠，六月，立為太子，大赦罪人。

translations.literal: After the defeat he alone found Xiaohui; in the sixth month, he installed him as Crown Prince and granted a great amnesty to criminals.
translations.idiomatic: After the defeat he alone found Xiaohui. In the sixth month, he installed him as Crown Prince and granted a great amnesty to criminals.

sentences.zh: 令太子守櫟陽，諸侯子在關中者皆集櫟陽為衛。

translations.literal: He ordered the Crown Prince to defend Liyang; all sons of feudal lords who were in Guanzhong assembled at Liyang to serve as guards.
translations.idiomatic: He ordered the Crown Prince to defend Liyang. All sons of feudal lords who were in Guanzhong assembled at Liyang to serve as guards.

sentences.zh: 引水灌廢丘，廢丘降，章邯自殺。

translations.literal: They diverted water to flood Feiqiu; Feiqiu surrendered and Zhang Han committed suicide.
translations.idiomatic: They diverted water to flood Feiqiu. Feiqiu surrendered and Zhang Han committed suicide.

sentences.zh: 更名廢丘為槐里。

translations.literal: They renamed Feiqiu as Huaili.
translations.idiomatic: They renamed Feiqiu as Huaili.

sentences.zh: 於是令祠官祀天地四方上帝山川，以時祀之。

translations.literal: Thereupon he ordered the sacrificial officials to make offerings to Heaven, Earth, the Four Directions, the Supreme Deity, mountains, and rivers, sacrificing to them at the proper times.
translations.idiomatic: Thereupon he ordered the sacrificial officials to make offerings to Heaven, Earth, the Four Directions, the Supreme Deity, mountains, and rivers, sacrificing to them at the proper times.

sentences.zh: 興關內卒乘塞。

translations.literal: He mobilized troops from within the passes to man the fortifications.
translations.idiomatic: He mobilized troops from within the passes to man the fortifications.

translations.literal: When the King of Han was defeated at Pengcheng and went west, he sent people on the road to seek his family, but his family had also disappeared and they could not find each other. After the defeat he alone found Xiaohui; in the sixth month, he installed him as Crown Prince and granted a great amnesty to criminals. He ordered the Crown Prince to defend Liyang; all sons of feudal lords who were in Guanzhong assembled at Liyang to serve as guards. They diverted water to flood Feiqiu; Feiqiu surrendered and Zhang Han committed suicide. They renamed Feiqiu as Huaili. Thereupon he ordered the sacrificial officials to make offerings to Heaven, Earth, the Four Directions, the Supreme Deity, mountains, and rivers, sacrificing to them at the proper times. He mobilized troops from within the passes to man the fortifications.

sentences.zh: 是時九江王布與龍且戰，不勝，與隨何閒行歸漢。

translations.literal: At this time King Bu of Jiujiang fought with Long Ju, did not win, and traveled secretly with Sui He to return to Han.
translations.idiomatic: At this time King Bu of Jiujiang fought with Long Ju, did not win, and traveled secretly with Sui He to return to Han.

sentences.zh: 漢王稍收士卒，與諸將及關中卒益出，是以兵大振滎陽，破楚京、索閒。

translations.literal: The King of Han gradually gathered officers and troops; together with the various generals and troops from within the passes they increasingly came out, so that the troops greatly rallied at Yingyang and broke Chu between Jing and Suo.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han gradually gathered officers and troops. Together with the various generals and troops from within the passes they increasingly came out. So that the troops greatly rallied at Yingyang and broke Chu between Jing and Suo.

translations.literal: At this time King Bu of Jiujiang fought with Long Ju, did not win, and traveled secretly with Sui He to return to Han. The King of Han gradually gathered officers and troops; together with the various generals and troops from within the passes they increasingly came out, so that the troops greatly rallied at Yingyang and broke Chu between Jing and Suo.

sentences.zh: 三年，魏王豹謁歸視親疾，至即絕河津，反為楚。

translations.literal: In the third year, King Bao of Wei requested leave to return to visit his ailing relatives; when he arrived he immediately cut off the Yellow River ford and rebelled to become Chu.
translations.idiomatic: In the third year, King Bao of Wei requested leave to return to visit his ailing relatives. When he arrived he immediately cut off the Yellow River ford and rebelled to become Chu.

sentences.zh: 漢王使酈生說豹，豹不聽。

translations.literal: The King of Han sent Li Sheng to persuade Bao, but Bao would not listen.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han sent Li Sheng to persuade Bao, but Bao would not listen.

sentences.zh: 漢王遣將軍韓信擊，大破之，虜豹。

translations.literal: The King of Han dispatched General Han Xin to strike, greatly broke him, and captured Bao.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han dispatched General Han Xin to strike. He greatly broke him and captured Bao.

sentences.zh: 遂定魏地，置三郡，曰河東、太原、上黨。

translations.literal: They then settled the territory of Wei, establishing three commanderies: Hedong, Taiyuan, and Shangdang.
translations.idiomatic: They then settled the territory of Wei, establishing three commanderies: Hedong, Taiyuan, and Shangdang.

sentences.zh: 漢王乃令張耳與韓信遂東下井陘擊趙，斬陳餘、趙王歇。

translations.literal: The King of Han then ordered Zhang Er and Han Xin to proceed east down Jingxing to strike Zhao, behead Chen Yu and King Xie of Zhao.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han then ordered Zhang Er and Han Xin to proceed east down Jingxing to strike Zhao. They beheaded Chen Yu and King Xie of Zhao.

sentences.zh: 其明年，立張耳為趙王。

translations.literal: The next year, he installed Zhang Er as King of Zhao.
translations.idiomatic: The next year, he installed Zhang Er as King of Zhao.

translations.literal: In the third year, King Bao of Wei requested leave to return to visit his ailing relatives; when he arrived he immediately cut off the Yellow River ford and rebelled to become Chu. The King of Han sent Li Sheng to persuade Bao, but Bao would not listen. The King of Han dispatched General Han Xin to strike, greatly broke him, and captured Bao. They then settled the territory of Wei, establishing three commanderies: Hedong, Taiyuan, and Shangdang. The King of Han then ordered Zhang Er and Han Xin to proceed east down Jingxing to strike Zhao, behead Chen Yu and King Xie of Zhao. The next year, he installed Zhang Er as King of Zhao.

sentences.zh: 漢王軍滎陽南，筑甬道屬之河，以取敖倉。

translations.literal: The King of Han's army was south of Yingyang, constructing a walled supply road connecting it to the river to obtain grain from Ao Granary.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han's army was south of Yingyang, constructing a walled supply road connecting it to the river to obtain grain from Ao Granary.

sentences.zh: 與項羽相距歲餘。

translations.literal: They confronted Xiang Yu for over a year.
translations.idiomatic: They confronted Xiang Yu for over a year.

sentences.zh: 項羽數侵奪漢甬道，漢軍乏食，遂圍漢王。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu repeatedly raided and seized Han's supply road; the Han army lacked food and was then besieged by the King of Han.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu repeatedly raided and seized Han's supply road. The Han army lacked food and was then besieged.

sentences.zh: 漢王請和，割滎陽以西者為漢。

translations.literal: The King of Han requested peace, offering to cede Yingyang and westward as Han.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han requested peace, offering to cede Yingyang and westward as Han.

sentences.zh: 項王不聽。

translations.literal: King Xiang would not listen.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang would not listen.

sentences.zh: 漢王患之，乃用陳平之計，予陳平金四萬斤，以閒疏楚君臣。

translations.literal: The King of Han was troubled by this, so he used Chen Ping's stratagem, giving Chen Ping forty thousand jin of gold to sow discord between Chu's lord and ministers.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han was troubled by this, so he used Chen Ping's stratagem. He gave Chen Ping forty thousand jin of gold to sow discord between Chu's lord and ministers.

sentences.zh: 於是項羽乃疑亞父。

translations.literal: Thereupon Xiang Yu became suspicious of the Second Father.
translations.idiomatic: Thereupon Xiang Yu became suspicious of the Second Father.

sentences.zh: 亞父是時勸項羽遂下滎陽，及其見疑，乃怒，辭老，願賜骸骨歸卒伍，未至彭城而死。

translations.literal: At that time the Second Father urged Xiang Yu to take Yingyang; when he saw himself suspected, he became angry, pleaded old age, requested to be granted his aged bones to return to the ranks; he died before reaching Pengcheng.
translations.idiomatic: At that time the Second Father urged Xiang Yu to take Yingyang. When he saw himself suspected, he became angry, pleaded old age, and requested to be granted his aged bones to return to the ranks. He died before reaching Pengcheng.

translations.literal: The King of Han's army was south of Yingyang, constructing a walled supply road connecting it to the river to obtain grain from Ao Granary. They confronted Xiang Yu for over a year. Xiang Yu repeatedly raided and seized Han's supply road; the Han army lacked food and was then besieged by the King of Han. The King of Han requested peace, offering to cede Yingyang and westward as Han. King Xiang would not listen. The King of Han was troubled by this, so he used Chen Ping's stratagem, giving Chen Ping forty thousand jin of gold to sow discord between Chu's lord and ministers. Thereupon Xiang Yu became suspicious of the Second Father. At that time the Second Father urged Xiang Yu to take Yingyang; when he saw himself suspected, he became angry, pleaded old age, requested to be granted his aged bones to return to the ranks; he died before reaching Pengcheng.

sentences.zh: 漢軍絕食，乃夜出女子東門二千餘人，被甲，楚因四面擊之。

translations.literal: The Han army was cut off from food, so by night they sent out over two thousand women from the east gate wearing armor; Chu consequently attacked them from four sides.
translations.idiomatic: The Han army was cut off from food, so by night they sent out over two thousand women from the east gate wearing armor. Chu consequently attacked them from four sides.

sentences.zh: 將軍紀信乃乘王駕，詐為漢王，誑楚，楚皆呼萬歲，之城東觀，以故漢王得與數十騎出西門遁。

translations.literal: General Ji Xin then rode in the king's chariot, pretended to be the King of Han, and deceived Chu; all the Chu troops shouted 'Long live!' and went to observe east of the city; because of this the King of Han was able to escape out the west gate with several tens of riders.
translations.idiomatic: General Ji Xin then rode in the king's chariot, pretended to be the King of Han, and deceived Chu. All the Chu troops shouted 'Long live!' and went to observe east of the city. Because of this the King of Han was able to escape out the west gate with several tens of riders.

sentences.zh: 令御史大夫周苛、魏豹、樅公守滎陽。

translations.literal: He ordered Imperial Secretary Zhou Ke, Wei Bao, and Duke Cong to defend Yingyang.
translations.idiomatic: He ordered Imperial Secretary Zhou Ke, Wei Bao, and Duke Cong to defend Yingyang.

sentences.zh: 諸將卒不能從者，盡在城中。

translations.literal: All generals and troops who could not follow were entirely in the city.
translations.idiomatic: All generals and troops who could not follow were entirely in the city.

sentences.zh: 周苛、樅公相謂曰：「反國之王，難與守城。」

translations.literal: Zhou Ke and Duke Cong said to each other: "A king who has rebelled against his state is difficult to defend a city with."
translations.idiomatic: Zhou Ke and Duke Cong said to each other: 'A king who has rebelled against his state is difficult to defend a city with.''

sentences.zh: 因殺魏豹。

translations.literal: They consequently killed Wei Bao.
translations.idiomatic: They consequently killed Wei Bao.

translations.literal: The Han army was cut off from food, so by night they sent out over two thousand women from the east gate wearing armor; Chu consequently attacked them from four sides. General Ji Xin then rode in the king's chariot, pretended to be the King of Han, and deceived Chu; all the Chu troops shouted 'Long live!' and went to observe east of the city; because of this the King of Han was able to escape out the west gate with several tens of riders. He ordered Imperial Secretary Zhou Ke, Wei Bao, and Duke Cong to defend Yingyang. All generals and troops who could not follow were entirely in the city. Zhou Ke and Duke Cong said to each other: "A king who has rebelled against his state is difficult to defend a city with." They consequently killed Wei Bao.

sentences.zh: 漢王之出滎陽入關，收兵欲復東。

translations.literal: When the King of Han left Yingyang and entered the passes, he gathered troops wishing to go east again.
translations.idiomatic: When the King of Han left Yingyang and entered the passes, he gathered troops wishing to go east again.

sentences.zh: 袁生說漢王曰：「漢與楚相距滎陽數歲，漢常困。

translations.literal: Yuan Sheng persuaded the King of Han, saying: "Han and Chu have confronted each other at Yingyang for several years; Han has constantly been in difficulty.
translations.idiomatic: Yuan Sheng persuaded the King of Han, saying: 'Han and Chu have confronted each other at Yingyang for several years. Han has constantly been in difficulty.'

sentences.zh: 願君王出武關，項羽必引兵南走，王深壁，令滎陽成皋閒且得休。

translations.literal: I hope the king will go out through Wuguan; Xiang Yu will certainly lead troops south in pursuit; the king should entrench deeply, allowing those between Yingyang and Chenggao to obtain some rest.
translations.idiomatic: I hope the king will go out through Wuguan. Xiang Yu will certainly lead troops south in pursuit. The king should entrench deeply, allowing those between Yingyang and Chenggao to obtain some rest.

sentences.zh: 使韓信等輯河北趙地，連燕齊，君王乃復走滎陽，未晚也。

translations.literal: Have Han Xin and others pacify the territory of Zhao north of the Yellow River, connect with Yan and Qi, then the king can return to Yingyang—it will not be too late.
translations.idiomatic: Have Han Xin and others pacify the territory of Zhao north of the Yellow River, connect with Yan and Qi. Then the king can return to Yingyang—it will not be too late.

sentences.zh: 如此，則楚所備者多，力分，漢得休，復與之戰，破楚必矣。」

translations.literal: If this is done, then what Chu must prepare for will be many places, their strength divided; Han will obtain rest and fight with them again—breaking Chu will be certain."
translations.idiomatic: If this is done, then what Chu must prepare for will be many places, their strength divided. Han will obtain rest and fight with them again—breaking Chu will be certain.''

sentences.zh: 漢王從其計，出軍宛葉閒，與黥布行收兵。

translations.literal: The King of Han followed his plan, sent out his army between Wan and Ye, and traveled with Qing Bu gathering troops.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han followed his plan, sent out his army between Wan and Ye, and traveled with Qing Bu gathering troops.

translations.literal: When the King of Han left Yingyang and entered the passes, he gathered troops wishing to go east again. Yuan Sheng persuaded the King of Han, saying: "Han and Chu have confronted each other at Yingyang for several years; Han has constantly been in difficulty. I hope the king will go out through Wuguan; Xiang Yu will certainly lead troops south in pursuit; the king should entrench deeply, allowing those between Yingyang and Chenggao to obtain some rest. Have Han Xin and others pacify the territory of Zhao north of the Yellow River, connect with Yan and Qi, then the king can return to Yingyang—it will not be too late. If this is done, then what Chu must prepare for will be many places, their strength divided; Han will obtain rest and fight with them again—breaking Chu will be certain." The King of Han followed his plan, sent out his army between Wan and Ye, and traveled with Qing Bu gathering troops.

sentences.zh: 項羽聞漢王在宛，果引兵南。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu heard the King of Han was at Wan and indeed led troops south.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu heard the King of Han was at Wan and indeed led troops south.

sentences.zh: 漢王堅壁不與戰。

translations.literal: The King of Han entrenched firmly and would not engage in battle.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han entrenched firmly and would not engage in battle.

sentences.zh: 是時彭越渡睢水，與項聲、薛公戰下邳，彭越大破楚軍。

translations.literal: At this time Peng Yue crossed the Sui River and fought with Xiang Sheng and Xue Gong at Xiapei; Peng Yue greatly broke the Chu army.
translations.idiomatic: At this time Peng Yue crossed the Sui River and fought with Xiang Sheng and Xue Gong at Xiapei. Peng Yue greatly broke the Chu army.

sentences.zh: 項羽乃引兵東擊彭越。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu then led troops east to strike Peng Yue.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu then led troops east to strike Peng Yue.

sentences.zh: 漢王亦引兵北軍成皋。

translations.literal: The King of Han also led troops north to encamp at Chenggao.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han also led troops north to encamp at Chenggao.

sentences.zh: 項羽已破走彭越，聞漢王復軍成皋，乃復引兵西，拔滎陽，誅周苛、樅公，而虜韓王信，遂圍成皋。

translations.literal: Having broken and driven off Peng Yue, Xiang Yu heard the King of Han had again encamped at Chenggao, so he again led troops west, took Yingyang, executed Zhou Ke and Duke Cong, captured King Xin of Han as prisoner, and then besieged Chenggao.
translations.idiomatic: Having broken and driven off Peng Yue, Xiang Yu heard the King of Han had again encamped at Chenggao. So he again led troops west, took Yingyang, executed Zhou Ke and Duke Cong, captured King Xin of Han as prisoner, and then besieged Chenggao.

translations.literal: Xiang Yu heard the King of Han was at Wan and indeed led troops south. The King of Han entrenched firmly and would not engage in battle. At this time Peng Yue crossed the Sui River and fought with Xiang Sheng and Xue Gong at Xiapei; Peng Yue greatly broke the Chu army. Xiang Yu then led troops east to strike Peng Yue. The King of Han also led troops north to encamp at Chenggao. Having broken and driven off Peng Yue, Xiang Yu heard the King of Han had again encamped at Chenggao, so he again led troops west, took Yingyang, executed Zhou Ke and Duke Cong, captured King Xin of Han as prisoner, and then besieged Chenggao.

sentences.zh: 漢王跳，獨與滕公共車出成皋玉門，北渡河，馳宿修武。

translations.literal: The King of Han leaped out, alone with Duke Teng sharing a chariot going out Chenggao's Jade Gate, crossed the Yellow River to the north, and galloped to lodge at Xiuwu.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han leaped out, alone with Duke Teng sharing a chariot going out Chenggao's Jade Gate. He crossed the Yellow River to the north and galloped to lodge at Xiuwu.

sentences.zh: 自稱使者，晨馳入張耳、韓信壁，而奪之軍。

translations.literal: Calling himself an envoy, at dawn he galloped into Zhang Er and Han Xin's encampment and seized their army.
translations.idiomatic: Calling himself an envoy, at dawn he galloped into Zhang Er and Han Xin's encampment and seized their army.

sentences.zh: 乃使張耳北益收兵趙地，使韓信東擊齊。

translations.literal: He then sent Zhang Er north to further gather troops in Zhao territory and sent Han Xin east to strike Qi.
translations.idiomatic: He then sent Zhang Er north to further gather troops in Zhao territory and sent Han Xin east to strike Qi.

sentences.zh: 漢王得韓信軍，則復振。

translations.literal: The King of Han having obtained Han Xin's army then rallied again.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han having obtained Han Xin's army then rallied again.

sentences.zh: 引兵臨河，南饗軍小修武南，欲復戰。

translations.literal: He led troops to the Yellow River, feasted the army to the south at Little Xiuwu to the south, wishing to fight again.
translations.idiomatic: He led troops to the Yellow River, feasted the army to the south at Little Xiuwu, wishing to fight again.

sentences.zh: 郎中鄭忠乃說止漢王，使高壘深塹，勿與戰。

translations.literal: Gentleman Zheng Zhong then persuaded and stopped the King of Han, having him build high ramparts and dig deep trenches and not engage in battle.
translations.idiomatic: Gentleman Zheng Zhong then persuaded and stopped the King of Han, having him build high ramparts and dig deep trenches and not engage in battle.

sentences.zh: 漢王聽其計，使盧綰、劉賈將卒二萬人，騎數百，渡白馬津，入楚地，與彭越復擊破楚軍燕郭西，遂復下梁地十餘城。

translations.literal: The Han king listened to their plan, sent Lu Wan and Liu Jia to lead twenty thousand troops and several hundred cavalry, cross the Bai Ma ford, enter Chu territory, and together with Peng Yue again strike and break Chu army at Yan Guo west, then recapture over ten Liang cities.
translations.idiomatic: The Han king listened to their plan, sent Lu Wan and Liu Jia to lead twenty thousand troops and several hundred cavalry. They crossed the Bai Ma ford, entered Chu territory, and together with Peng Yue again struck and broke Chu army at Yan Guo west, then recaptured over ten Liang cities.

translations.literal: The King of Han leaped out, alone with Duke Teng sharing a chariot going out Chenggao's Jade Gate, crossed the Yellow River to the north, and galloped to lodge at Xiuwu. Calling himself an envoy, at dawn he galloped into Zhang Er and Han Xin's encampment and seized their army. He then sent Zhang Er north to further gather troops in Zhao territory and sent Han Xin east to strike Qi. The King of Han having obtained Han Xin's army then rallied again. He led troops to the Yellow River, feasted the army to the south at Little Xiuwu to the south, wishing to fight again. Gentleman Zheng Zhong then persuaded and stopped the King of Han, having him build high ramparts and dig deep trenches and not engage in battle. The Han king listened to their plan, sent Lu Wan and Liu Jia to lead twenty thousand troops and several hundred cavalry, cross the Bai Ma ford, enter Chu territory, and together with Peng Yue again strike and break Chu army at Yan Guo west, then recapture over ten Liang cities.

sentences.zh: 淮陰已受命東，未渡平原。

translations.literal: Marquis of Huaiyin already received orders east, not yet crossed Pingyuan.
translations.idiomatic: The Marquis of Huaiyin had already received orders to go east but had not yet crossed Pingyuan.

sentences.zh: 漢王使酈生往說齊王田廣，廣叛楚，與漢和，共擊項羽。

translations.literal: The King of Han sent Li Sheng to persuade King Tian Guang of Qi; Guang rebelled against Chu and made peace with Han to together strike Xiang Yu.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han sent Li Sheng to persuade King Tian Guang of Qi. Guang rebelled against Chu and made peace with Han to together strike Xiang Yu.

sentences.zh: 韓信用蒯通計，遂襲破齊。

translations.literal: Han Xin used Kuai Tong's stratagem and then launched a surprise attack and broke Qi.
translations.idiomatic: Han Xin used Kuai Tong's stratagem and then launched a surprise attack and broke Qi.

sentences.zh: 齊王烹酈生，東走高密。

translations.literal: The King of Qi boiled Li Sheng alive and fled east to Gaomi.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Qi boiled Li Sheng alive and fled east to Gaomi.

sentences.zh: 項羽聞韓信已舉河北兵破齊、趙，且欲擊楚，則使龍且、周蘭往擊之。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu heard that Han Xin had already raised troops north of the Yellow River and broken Qi and Zhao and was about to strike Chu, so he sent Long Ju and Zhou Lan to strike him.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu heard that Han Xin had already raised troops north of the Yellow River and broken Qi and Zhao and was about to strike Chu. So he sent Long Ju and Zhou Lan to strike him.

sentences.zh: 韓信與戰，騎將灌嬰擊，大破楚軍，殺龍且。

translations.literal: Han Xin engaged in battle; cavalry general Guan Ying struck and greatly broke the Chu army, killing Long Ju.
translations.idiomatic: Han Xin engaged in battle. Cavalry general Guan Ying struck and greatly broke the Chu army, killing Long Ju.

sentences.zh: 齊王廣奔彭越。

translations.literal: King Guang of Qi fled to Peng Yue.
translations.idiomatic: King Guang of Qi fled to Peng Yue.

sentences.zh: 當此時，彭越將兵居梁地，往來苦楚兵，絕其糧食。

translations.literal: At this time, Peng Yue led troops stationed in the land of Liang, traveling back and forth tormenting the Chu troops and cutting off their grain supply.
translations.idiomatic: At this time, Peng Yue led troops stationed in the land of Liang, traveling back and forth tormenting the Chu troops and cutting off their grain supply.

translations.literal: Marquis of Huaiyin already received orders east, not yet crossed Pingyuan. The King of Han sent Li Sheng to persuade King Tian Guang of Qi; Guang rebelled against Chu and made peace with Han to together strike Xiang Yu. Han Xin used Kuai Tong's stratagem and then launched a surprise attack and broke Qi. The King of Qi boiled Li Sheng alive and fled east to Gaomi. Xiang Yu heard that Han Xin had already raised troops north of the Yellow River and broken Qi and Zhao and was about to strike Chu, so he sent Long Ju and Zhou Lan to strike him. Han Xin engaged in battle; cavalry general Guan Ying struck and greatly broke the Chu army, killing Long Ju. King Guang of Qi fled to Peng Yue. At this time, Peng Yue led troops stationed in the land of Liang, traveling back and forth tormenting the Chu troops and cutting off their grain supply.

sentences.zh: 四年，項羽乃謂海春侯大司馬曹咎曰：「謹守成皋。
