translations.literal: In the fourth year, Xiang Yu then said to Marquis of Haichun Grand Marshal Cao Jiu: "Carefully defend Chenggao.
translations.idiomatic: In the fourth year, Xiang Yu then said to Marquis of Haichun Grand Marshal Cao Jiu: 'Carefully defend Chenggao.'

sentences.zh: 若漢挑戰，慎勿與戰，無令得東而已。

translations.literal: If Han challenges to battle, be cautious not to engage in battle, and do not let them get east—that is all.
translations.idiomatic: If Han challenges to battle, be cautious not to engage in battle, and do not let them get east—that is all.''

sentences.zh: 我十五日必定梁地，復從將軍。」

translations.literal: In fifteen days I will certainly settle the land of Liang and return to join the generals."
translations.idiomatic: In fifteen days I will certainly settle the land of Liang and return to join the generals.''

sentences.zh: 乃行擊陳留、外黃、睢陽，下之。

translations.literal: He then marched to strike Chenliu, Waihuang, and Suiyang, taking them.
translations.idiomatic: He then marched to strike Chenliu, Waihuang, and Suiyang, taking them.

sentences.zh: 漢果數挑楚軍，楚軍不出，使人辱之五六日，大司馬怒，度兵汜水。

translations.literal: Han indeed repeatedly challenged the Chu army to battle; the Chu army would not come out; they sent men to insult them for five or six days; the Grand Marshal was enraged and crossed his troops over the Fan River.
translations.idiomatic: Han indeed repeatedly challenged the Chu army to battle. The Chu army would not come out. They sent men to insult them for five or six days. The Grand Marshal was enraged and crossed his troops over the Fan River.

sentences.zh: 士卒半渡，漢擊之，大破楚軍，盡得楚國金玉貨賂。

translations.literal: When half the officers and troops had crossed, Han struck them, greatly broke the Chu army, and completely obtained all Chu's gold, jade, wealth, and bribes.
translations.idiomatic: When half the officers and troops had crossed, Han struck them, greatly broke the Chu army, and completely obtained all Chu's gold, jade, wealth, and bribes.

sentences.zh: 大司馬咎、長史欣皆自剄汜水上。

translations.literal: Grand Marshal Jiu and Chief Clerk Xin both slit their own throats at the Fan River.
translations.idiomatic: Grand Marshal Jiu and Chief Clerk Xin both slit their own throats at the Fan River.

sentences.zh: 項羽至睢陽，聞海春侯破，乃引兵還。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu reached Suiyang and heard that Marquis of Haichun was broken, so he led his troops back.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu reached Suiyang and heard that Marquis of Haichun was broken. So he led his troops back.

sentences.zh: 漢軍方圍鐘離眛於滎陽東，項羽至，盡走險阻。

translations.literal: The Han army was besieging Zhongli Mo east of Yingyang; when Xiang Yu arrived, they all fled to dangerous terrain.
translations.idiomatic: The Han army was besieging Zhongli Mo east of Yingyang. When Xiang Yu arrived, they all fled to dangerous terrain.

translations.literal: In the fourth year, Xiang Yu then said to Marquis of Haichun Grand Marshal Cao Jiu: "Carefully defend Chenggao. If Han challenges to battle, be cautious not to engage in battle, and do not let them get east—that is all. In fifteen days I will certainly settle the land of Liang and return to join the generals." He then marched to strike Chenliu, Waihuang, and Suiyang, taking them. Han indeed repeatedly challenged the Chu army to battle; the Chu army would not come out; they sent men to insult them for five or six days; the Grand Marshal was enraged and crossed his troops over the Fan River. When half the officers and troops had crossed, Han struck them, greatly broke the Chu army, and completely obtained all Chu's gold, jade, wealth, and bribes. Grand Marshal Jiu and Chief Clerk Xin both slit their own throats at the Fan River. Xiang Yu reached Suiyang and heard that Marquis of Haichun was broken, so he led his troops back. The Han army was besieging Zhongli Mo east of Yingyang; when Xiang Yu arrived, they all fled to dangerous terrain.

sentences.zh: 韓信已破齊，使人言曰：「齊邊楚，權輕，不為假王，恐不能安齊。」

translations.literal: Han Xin having already broken Qi sent someone to say: "Qi borders Chu; authority is light—if I am not made provisional king, I fear I cannot stabilize Qi."
translations.idiomatic: Han Xin having already broken Qi sent someone to say: 'Qi borders Chu; authority is light—if I am not made provisional king, I fear I cannot stabilize Qi.''

sentences.zh: 漢王欲攻之。

translations.literal: The King of Han wished to attack him.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han wished to attack him.

sentences.zh: 留侯曰：「不如因而立之，使自為守。」

translations.literal: The Marquis of Liu said: "It would be better to consequently install him and have him defend on his own."
translations.idiomatic: The Marquis of Liu said: 'It would be better to consequently install him and have him defend on his own.''

sentences.zh: 乃遣張良操印綬立韓信為齊王。

translations.literal: He then dispatched Zhang Liang bearing the seal and ribbons to install Han Xin as King of Qi.
translations.idiomatic: He then dispatched Zhang Liang bearing the seal and ribbons to install Han Xin as King of Qi.

translations.literal: Han Xin having already broken Qi sent someone to say: "Qi borders Chu; authority is light—if I am not made provisional king, I fear I cannot stabilize Qi." The King of Han wished to attack him. The Marquis of Liu said: "It would be better to consequently install him and have him defend on his own." He then dispatched Zhang Liang bearing the seal and ribbons to install Han Xin as King of Qi.

sentences.zh: 項羽聞龍且軍破，則恐，使盱臺人武涉往說韓信。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu heard that Long Ju's army was broken and was then afraid, sending Wu She of Xutai to persuade Han Xin.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu heard that Long Ju's army was broken and was then afraid. He sent Wu She of Xutai to persuade Han Xin.

sentences.zh: 韓信不聽。

translations.literal: Han Xin would not listen.
translations.idiomatic: Han Xin would not listen.

translations.literal: Xiang Yu heard that Long Ju's army was broken and was then afraid, sending Wu She of Xutai to persuade Han Xin. Han Xin would not listen.

sentences.zh: 楚漢久相持未決，丁壯苦軍旅，老弱罷轉馕。

translations.literal: Chu and Han long confronted each other without resolution; the able-bodied suffered from military service, the old and weak were exhausted transporting grain.
translations.idiomatic: Chu and Han long confronted each other without resolution. The able-bodied suffered from military service, the old and weak were exhausted transporting grain.

sentences.zh: 漢王項羽相與臨廣武之閒而語。

translations.literal: The King of Han and Xiang Yu faced each other between Guangwu and spoke.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han and Xiang Yu faced each other between Guangwu and spoke.

sentences.zh: 項羽欲與漢王獨身挑戰。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu wished to challenge the King of Han to single combat.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu wished to challenge the King of Han to single combat.

sentences.zh: 漢王數項羽曰：「始與項羽俱受命懷王，曰先入定關中者王之，項羽負約，王我於蜀漢，罪一。

translations.literal: The King of Han enumerated Xiang Yu's crimes, saying: "At first Xiang Yu and I both received orders from King Huai saying he who first enters and settles Guanzhong shall be its king; Xiang Yu broke the agreement and made me king in Shu and Han—crime one.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han enumerated Xiang Yu's crimes, saying: 'At first Xiang Yu and I both received orders from King Huai saying he who first enters and settles Guanzhong shall be its king. Xiang Yu broke the agreement and made me king in Shu and Han—crime one.'

sentences.zh: 秦項羽矯殺卿子冠軍而自尊，罪二。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu falsely killed Lord Superior to Ministers and exalted himself—crime two.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu falsely killed Lord Superior to Ministers and exalted himself—crime two.

sentences.zh: 項羽已救趙，當還報，而擅劫諸侯兵入關，罪三。

translations.literal: Having already rescued Zhao, Xiang Yu should have returned to report, but instead he seized the feudal lords' troops without authorization and entered the passes—crime three.
translations.idiomatic: Having already rescued Zhao, Xiang Yu should have returned to report. But instead he seized the feudal lords' troops without authorization and entered the passes—crime three.

sentences.zh: 懷王約入秦無暴掠，項羽燒秦宮室，掘始皇帝冢，私收其財物，罪四。

translations.literal: King Huai's agreement was that in entering Qin there should be no violence or plunder; Xiang Yu burned the Qin palace chambers, dug up the First Emperor's tomb, and privately took its wealth and goods—crime four.
translations.idiomatic: King Huai's agreement was that in entering Qin there should be no violence or plunder. Xiang Yu burned the Qin palace chambers, dug up the First Emperor's tomb, and privately took its wealth and goods—crime four.

sentences.zh: 又彊殺秦降王子嬰，罪五。

translations.literal: He also forcibly killed the surrendered King of Qin, Ziying—crime five.
translations.idiomatic: He also forcibly killed the surrendered King of Qin, Ziying—crime five.

sentences.zh: 詐阬秦子弟新安二十萬，王其將，罪六。

translations.literal: He deceitfully buried alive two hundred thousand Qin sons and younger brothers at Xin'an and made their generals kings—crime six.
translations.idiomatic: He deceitfully buried alive two hundred thousand Qin sons and younger brothers at Xin'an and made their generals kings—crime six.

sentences.zh: 項羽皆王諸將善地，而徙逐故主，令臣下爭叛逆，罪七。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu made kings of all the generals in good lands while moving and expelling the former lords, causing ministers and subordinates to compete in rebellion and treason—crime seven.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu made kings of all the generals in good lands while moving and expelling the former lords. He caused ministers and subordinates to compete in rebellion and treason—crime seven.

sentences.zh: 項羽出逐義帝彭城，自都之，奪韓王地，并王梁楚，多自予，罪八。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu expelled the Righteous Emperor from Pengcheng and made it his own capital, seized the King of Han's territory, and combined to rule Liang and Chu, taking much for himself—crime eight.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu expelled the Righteous Emperor from Pengcheng and made it his own capital. He seized the King of Han's territory and combined to rule Liang and Chu, taking much for himself—crime eight.

sentences.zh: 項羽使人陰弒義帝江南，罪九。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu sent men to secretly assassinate the Righteous Emperor south of the Yangtze—crime nine.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu sent men to secretly assassinate the Righteous Emperor south of the Yangtze—crime nine.

sentences.zh: 夫為人臣而弒其主，殺已降，為政不平，主約不信，天下所不容，大逆無道，罪十也。

translations.literal: Being a minister who assassinates his lord, kills those who have already surrendered, governs unjustly, does not keep agreements with his lord—these all under Heaven cannot tolerate; this is great rebellion and lawlessness—crime ten.
translations.idiomatic: Being a minister who assassinates his lord, kills those who have already surrendered, governs unjustly, does not keep agreements with his lord—these all under Heaven cannot tolerate. This is great rebellion and lawlessness—crime ten.

sentences.zh: 吾以義兵從諸侯誅殘賊，使刑餘罪人擊殺項羽，何苦乃與公挑戰！」

translations.literal: I with righteous troops follow the feudal lords to execute cruel rebels; I will have criminals with sentences of mutilation strike and kill Xiang Yu—why would I suffer to challenge you to combat!"
translations.idiomatic: I with righteous troops follow the feudal lords to execute cruel rebels. I will have criminals with sentences of mutilation strike and kill Xiang Yu—why would I suffer to challenge you to combat!''

sentences.zh: 項羽大怒，伏弩射中漢王。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu greatly enraged, hidden crossbow shot hit King of Han.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu greatly enraged, his hidden crossbow shot hit the King of Han.

sentences.zh: 漢王傷匈，乃捫足曰：「虜中吾指！」

translations.literal: The King of Han was wounded in the chest but grasped his foot and said: "The bandit hit my toe!"
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han was wounded in the chest but grasped his foot and said: 'The bandit hit my toe!''

sentences.zh: 漢王病創臥，張良彊請漢王起行勞軍，以安士卒，毋令楚乘勝於漢。

translations.literal: The King of Han lay ill from the wound; Zhang Liang strongly requested the King of Han to rise and go comfort the army to reassure the officers and troops and not let Chu take advantage of Han.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han lay ill from the wound. Zhang Liang strongly requested the King of Han to rise and go comfort the army to reassure the officers and troops and not let Chu take advantage of Han.

sentences.zh: 漢王出行軍，病甚，因馳入成皋。

translations.literal: The King of Han went out to tour the army; his illness was severe, so he galloped into Chenggao.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han went out to tour the army. His illness was severe, so he galloped into Chenggao.

translations.literal: Chu and Han long confronted each other without resolution; the able-bodied suffered from military service, the old and weak were exhausted transporting grain. The King of Han and Xiang Yu faced each other between Guangwu and spoke. Xiang Yu wished to challenge the King of Han to single combat. The King of Han enumerated Xiang Yu's crimes, saying: "At first Xiang Yu and I both received orders from King Huai saying he who first enters and settles Guanzhong shall be its king; Xiang Yu broke the agreement and made me king in Shu and Han—crime one. Xiang Yu falsely killed Lord Superior to Ministers and exalted himself—crime two. Having already rescued Zhao, Xiang Yu should have returned to report, but instead he seized the feudal lords' troops without authorization and entered the passes—crime three. King Huai's agreement was that in entering Qin there should be no violence or plunder; Xiang Yu burned the Qin palace chambers, dug up the First Emperor's tomb, and privately took its wealth and goods—crime four. He also forcibly killed the surrendered King of Qin, Ziying—crime five. He deceitfully buried alive two hundred thousand Qin sons and younger brothers at Xin'an and made their generals kings—crime six. Xiang Yu made kings of all the generals in good lands while moving and expelling the former lords, causing ministers and subordinates to compete in rebellion and treason—crime seven. Xiang Yu expelled the Righteous Emperor from Pengcheng and made it his own capital, seized the King of Han's territory, and combined to rule Liang and Chu, taking much for himself—crime eight. Xiang Yu sent men to secretly assassinate the Righteous Emperor south of the Yangtze—crime nine. Being a minister who assassinates his lord, kills those who have already surrendered, governs unjustly, does not keep agreements with his lord—these all under Heaven cannot tolerate; this is great rebellion and lawlessness—crime ten. I with righteous troops follow the feudal lords to execute cruel rebels; I will have criminals with sentences of mutilation strike and kill Xiang Yu—why would I suffer to challenge you to combat!" Xiang Yu greatly enraged, hidden crossbow shot hit King of Han. The King of Han was wounded in the chest but grasped his foot and said: "The bandit hit my toe!" The King of Han lay ill from the wound; Zhang Liang strongly requested the King of Han to rise and go comfort the army to reassure the officers and troops and not let Chu take advantage of Han. The King of Han went out to tour the army; his illness was severe, so he galloped into Chenggao.

sentences.zh: 病愈，西入關，至櫟陽，存問父老，置酒，梟故塞王欣頭櫟陽市。

translations.literal: When his illness improved, he went west into the passes, reached Liyang, inquired after the elders, held a banquet, and displayed the former King of Sai Xin's severed head in the Liyang marketplace.
translations.idiomatic: When his illness improved, he went west into the passes, reached Liyang, inquired after the elders, held a banquet, and displayed the former King of Sai Xin's severed head in the Liyang marketplace.

sentences.zh: 留四日，復如軍，軍廣武。

translations.literal: He remained four days, then returned to the army and encamped at Guangwu.
translations.idiomatic: He remained four days, then returned to the army and encamped at Guangwu.

sentences.zh: 關中兵益出。

translations.literal: Troops from within the passes increasingly came out.
translations.idiomatic: Troops from within the passes increasingly came out.

translations.literal: When his illness improved, he went west into the passes, reached Liyang, inquired after the elders, held a banquet, and displayed the former King of Sai Xin's severed head in the Liyang marketplace. He remained four days, then returned to the army and encamped at Guangwu. Troops from within the passes increasingly came out.

sentences.zh: 當此時，彭越將兵居梁地，往來苦楚兵，絕其糧食。

translations.literal: At this time, Peng Yue led troops stationed in the land of Liang, traveling back and forth tormenting the Chu troops and cutting off their grain supply.
translations.idiomatic: At this time, Peng Yue led troops stationed in the land of Liang, traveling back and forth tormenting the Chu troops and cutting off their grain supply.

sentences.zh: 田橫往從之。

translations.literal: Tian Heng went to join him.
translations.idiomatic: Tian Heng went to join him.

sentences.zh: 項羽數擊彭越等，齊王信又進擊楚。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu repeatedly struck Peng Yue and others; King Xin of Qi also advanced to strike Chu.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu repeatedly struck Peng Yue and others. King Xin of Qi also advanced to strike Chu.

sentences.zh: 項羽恐，乃與漢王約，中分天下，割鴻溝而西者為漢，鴻溝而東者為楚。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu was afraid and then made an agreement with the King of Han to divide all under Heaven in the middle: those west of the Hong Canal would be Han, those east of the Hong Canal would be Chu.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu was afraid and then made an agreement with the King of Han to divide all under Heaven in the middle: those west of the Hong Canal would be Han, those east of the Hong Canal would be Chu.

sentences.zh: 項王歸漢王父母妻子，軍中皆呼萬歲，乃歸而別去。

translations.literal: King Xiang returned the King of Han's father, mother, wife, and children; the army all shouted 'Long live!'; they then returned and parted ways.
translations.idiomatic: King Xiang returned the King of Han's father, mother, wife, and children. The army all shouted 'Long live!' They then returned and parted ways.

translations.literal: At this time, Peng Yue led troops stationed in the land of Liang, traveling back and forth tormenting the Chu troops and cutting off their grain supply. Tian Heng went to join him. Xiang Yu repeatedly struck Peng Yue and others; King Xin of Qi also advanced to strike Chu. Xiang Yu was afraid and then made an agreement with the King of Han to divide all under Heaven in the middle: those west of the Hong Canal would be Han, those east of the Hong Canal would be Chu. King Xiang returned the King of Han's father, mother, wife, and children; the army all shouted 'Long live!'; they then returned and parted ways.

sentences.zh: 項羽解而東歸。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu was released and returned eastward.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu was released and returned eastward.

sentences.zh: 漢王欲引而西歸，用留侯、陳平計，乃進兵追項羽，至陽夏南止軍，與齊王信、建成侯彭越期會而擊楚軍。

translations.literal: The King of Han wished to lead his troops and return westward, but using the plans of the Marquis of Liu and Chen Ping, he then advanced his troops to pursue Xiang Yu, reached south of Yangxia and stopped his army, making an appointment with King Xin of Qi and Marquis of Jiancheng Peng Yue to meet and strike the Chu army.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han wished to lead his troops and return westward, but using the plans of the Marquis of Liu and Chen Ping, he then advanced his troops to pursue Xiang Yu. He reached south of Yangxia and stopped his army, making an appointment with King Xin of Qi and Marquis of Jiancheng Peng Yue to meet and strike the Chu army.

sentences.zh: 至固陵，不會。

translations.literal: Reaching Guling, they did not meet.
translations.idiomatic: Reaching Guling, they did not meet.

sentences.zh: 楚擊漢軍，大破之。

translations.literal: Chu struck the Han army and greatly broke them.
translations.idiomatic: Chu struck the Han army and greatly broke them.

sentences.zh: 漢王復入壁，深塹而守之。

translations.literal: The King of Han again entered his ramparts, dug deep trenches, and defended.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han again entered his ramparts, dug deep trenches, and defended.

sentences.zh: 用張良計，於是韓信、彭越皆往。

translations.literal: Using Zhang Liang's plan, thereupon Han Xin and Peng Yue both went.
translations.idiomatic: Using Zhang Liang's plan, thereupon Han Xin and Peng Yue both went.

sentences.zh: 及劉賈入楚地，圍壽春，漢王敗碧陵，乃使使者召大司馬周殷舉九江兵而迎（之）武王，行屠城父，隨（何）劉賈、齊梁諸侯皆大會垓下。

translations.literal: When Liu Jia entered Chu territory and besieged Shouchun, the King of Han was defeated at Biling, so he sent envoys to summon Grand Marshal Zhou Yin to raise the troops of Jiujiang and welcome King Wu, marched and massacred Chengfu, following Liu Jia; the feudal lords of Qi and Liang all assembled in great numbers at Gaixia.
translations.idiomatic: When Liu Jia entered Chu territory and besieged Shouchun, the King of Han was defeated at Biling. So he sent envoys to summon Grand Marshal Zhou Yin to raise the troops of Jiujiang and welcome King Wu. He marched and massacred Chengfu, following Liu Jia. The feudal lords of Qi and Liang all assembled in great numbers at Gaixia.

sentences.zh: 立武王布為淮南王。

translations.literal: He installed King Wu Bu as King of Huainan.
translations.idiomatic: He installed King Wu Bu as King of Huainan.

translations.literal: Xiang Yu was released and returned eastward. The King of Han wished to lead his troops and return westward, but using the plans of the Marquis of Liu and Chen Ping, he then advanced his troops to pursue Xiang Yu, reached south of Yangxia and stopped his army, making an appointment with King Xin of Qi and Marquis of Jiancheng Peng Yue to meet and strike the Chu army. Reaching Guling, they did not meet. Chu struck the Han army and greatly broke them. The King of Han again entered his ramparts, dug deep trenches, and defended. Using Zhang Liang's plan, thereupon Han Xin and Peng Yue both went. When Liu Jia entered Chu territory and besieged Shouchun, the King of Han was defeated at Biling, so he sent envoys to summon Grand Marshal Zhou Yin to raise the troops of Jiujiang and welcome King Wu, marched and massacred Chengfu, following Liu Jia; the feudal lords of Qi and Liang all assembled in great numbers at Gaixia. He installed King Wu Bu as King of Huainan.

sentences.zh: 五年，高祖與諸侯兵共擊楚軍，與項羽決勝垓下。

translations.literal: In the fifth year, Gao Zu together with the feudal lords' troops jointly struck the Chu army and decided victory with Xiang Yu at Gaixia.
translations.idiomatic: In the fifth year, Gao Zu together with the feudal lords' troops jointly struck the Chu army and decided victory with Xiang Yu at Gaixia.

sentences.zh: 淮陰侯將三十萬自當之，孔將軍居左，費將軍居右，皇帝在後，絳侯、柴將軍在皇帝後。

translations.literal: The Marquis of Huaiyin led three hundred thousand and directly opposed them; General Kong was on the left, General Fei on the right, the Emperor behind, and Marquis of Jiang and General Chai behind the Emperor.
translations.idiomatic: The Marquis of Huaiyin led three hundred thousand and directly opposed them. General Kong was on the left, General Fei on the right, the Emperor behind, and Marquis of Jiang and General Chai behind the Emperor.

sentences.zh: 項羽之卒可十萬。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu's troops numbered about a hundred thousand.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu's troops numbered about a hundred thousand.

sentences.zh: 淮陰先合，不利，卻。

translations.literal: Huaiyin first engaged, went unfavorably, and retreated.
translations.idiomatic: Huaiyin first engaged, went unfavorably, and retreated.

sentences.zh: 孔將軍、費將軍縱，楚兵不利，淮陰侯復乘之，大敗垓下。

translations.literal: General Kong and General Fei were released; the Chu troops went unfavorably, and the Marquis of Huaiyin again rode upon them, greatly defeating them at Gaixia.
translations.idiomatic: General Kong and General Fei were released. The Chu troops went unfavorably, and the Marquis of Huaiyin again rode upon them, greatly defeating them at Gaixia.

sentences.zh: 項羽卒聞漢軍之楚歌，以為漢盡得楚地，項羽乃敗而走，是以兵大敗。

translations.literal: Xiang Yu's troops heard the Han army's Chu songs and thought Han had completely obtained the lands of Chu; Xiang Yu was then defeated and fled; because of this the troops were greatly defeated.
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu's troops heard the Han army's Chu songs and thought Han had completely obtained the lands of Chu. Xiang Yu was then defeated and fled. Because of this the troops were greatly defeated.

sentences.zh: 使騎將灌嬰追殺項羽東城，斬首八萬，遂略定楚地。

translations.literal: He sent cavalry general Guan Ying to pursue and kill Xiang Yu at Dongcheng, behead eighty thousand, and then take and settle the lands of Chu.
translations.idiomatic: He sent cavalry general Guan Ying to pursue and kill Xiang Yu at Dongcheng, behead eighty thousand, and then take and settle the lands of Chu.

sentences.zh: 魯為楚堅守不下。

translations.literal: Lu firmly defended for Chu and would not surrender.
translations.idiomatic: Lu firmly defended for Chu and would not surrender.

sentences.zh: 漢王引諸侯兵北，示魯父老項羽頭，魯乃降。

translations.literal: The King of Han led the feudal lords' troops north and showed Xiang Yu's head to the fathers and elders of Lu; Lu then surrendered.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han led the feudal lords' troops north and showed Xiang Yu's head to the fathers and elders of Lu. Lu then surrendered.

sentences.zh: 遂以魯公號葬項羽穀城。

translations.literal: They then buried Xiang Yu at Gucheng with the rites of Duke of Lu.
translations.idiomatic: They then buried Xiang Yu at Gucheng with the rites of Duke of Lu.

sentences.zh: 還至定陶，馳入齊王壁，奪其軍。

translations.literal: Returning to reach Dingtao, he galloped into the King of Qi's encampment and seized his army.
translations.idiomatic: Returning to reach Dingtao, he galloped into the King of Qi's encampment and seized his army.

translations.literal: In the fifth year, Gao Zu together with the feudal lords' troops jointly struck the Chu army and decided victory with Xiang Yu at Gaixia. The Marquis of Huaiyin led three hundred thousand and directly opposed them; General Kong was on the left, General Fei on the right, the Emperor behind, and Marquis of Jiang and General Chai behind the Emperor. Xiang Yu's troops numbered about a hundred thousand. Huaiyin first engaged, went unfavorably, and retreated. General Kong and General Fei were released; the Chu troops went unfavorably, and the Marquis of Huaiyin again rode upon them, greatly defeating them at Gaixia. Xiang Yu's troops heard the Han army's Chu songs and thought Han had completely obtained the lands of Chu; Xiang Yu was then defeated and fled; because of this the troops were greatly defeated. He sent cavalry general Guan Ying to pursue and kill Xiang Yu at Dongcheng, behead eighty thousand, and then take and settle the lands of Chu. Lu firmly defended for Chu and would not surrender. The King of Han led the feudal lords' troops north and showed Xiang Yu's head to the fathers and elders of Lu; Lu then surrendered. They then buried Xiang Yu at Gucheng with the rites of Duke of Lu. Returning to reach Dingtao, he galloped into the King of Qi's encampment and seized his army.

sentences.zh: 正月，諸侯及將相相與共請尊漢王為皇帝。

translations.literal: In the first month, the feudal lords and generals and ministers together jointly requested to honor the King of Han as Emperor.
translations.idiomatic: In the first month, the feudal lords and generals and ministers together jointly requested to honor the King of Han as Emperor.

sentences.zh: 漢王曰：「吾聞帝賢者有也，空言虛語，非所守也，吾不敢當帝位。」

translations.literal: The King of Han said: "I have heard that the title of Emperor is something the worthy possess; empty words and vain speech are not what I uphold—I dare not accept the position of Emperor."
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han said: 'I have heard that the title of Emperor is something the worthy possess. Empty words and vain speech are not what I uphold—I dare not accept the position of Emperor.''

sentences.zh: 群臣皆曰：「大王起微細，誅暴逆，平定四海，有功者輒裂地而封為王侯。

translations.literal: The assembled ministers all said: "The great king arose from humble and minor beginnings, executed the violent and rebellious, pacified the four seas; those with achievements were immediately given divided territory and enfeoffed as kings and marquises.
translations.idiomatic: The assembled ministers all said: 'The great king arose from humble and minor beginnings, executed the violent and rebellious, pacified the four seas. Those with achievements were immediately given divided territory and enfeoffed as kings and marquises.'

sentences.zh: 大王不尊號，皆疑不信。

translations.literal: If great king not take honored title, all doubt not believe.
translations.idiomatic: If great king not take honored title, all doubt not believe.

sentences.zh: 臣等以死守之。」

translations.literal: We your ministers will defend this to the death."
translations.idiomatic: We your ministers will defend this to the death.''

sentences.zh: 漢王三讓，不得已，曰：「諸君必以為便，便國家。」

translations.literal: The King of Han declined three times; unable to refuse, he said: "If you lords must consider it convenient and beneficial to the state."
translations.idiomatic: The King of Han declined three times. Unable to refuse, he said: 'If you lords must consider it convenient and beneficial to the state.''

sentences.zh: 甲午，乃即皇帝位汜水之陽。

translations.literal: On the jiawu day, he then assumed the position of Emperor north of the Fan River.
translations.idiomatic: On the jiawu day, he then assumed the position of Emperor north of the Fan River.

translations.literal: In the first month, the feudal lords and generals and ministers together jointly requested to honor the King of Han as Emperor. The King of Han said: "I have heard that the title of Emperor is something the worthy possess; empty words and vain speech are not what I uphold—I dare not accept the position of Emperor." The assembled ministers all said: "The great king arose from humble and minor beginnings, executed the violent and rebellious, pacified the four seas; those with achievements were immediately given divided territory and enfeoffed as kings and marquises. If great king not take honored title, all doubt not believe. We your ministers will defend this to the death." The King of Han declined three times; unable to refuse, he said: "If you lords must consider it convenient and beneficial to the state." On the jiawu day, he then assumed the position of Emperor north of the Fan River.

sentences.zh: 皇帝曰義帝無後。

translations.literal: The Emperor said the Righteous Emperor had no descendants.
translations.idiomatic: The Emperor said the Righteous Emperor had no descendants.

sentences.zh: 齊王韓信習楚風俗，徙為楚王，都下邳。

translations.literal: King Han Xin of Qi was familiar with Chu customs and was moved to be King of Chu, with his capital at Xiapei.
translations.idiomatic: King Han Xin of Qi was familiar with Chu customs and was moved to be King of Chu, with his capital at Xiapei.

sentences.zh: 立建成侯彭越為梁王，都定陶。

translations.literal: He installed Marquis of Jiancheng Peng Yue as King of Liang, with his capital at Dingtao.
translations.idiomatic: He installed Marquis of Jiancheng Peng Yue as King of Liang, with his capital at Dingtao.

sentences.zh: 故韓王信為韓王，都陽翟。

translations.literal: The former King Xin of Han remained King of Han, with his capital at Yangzhai.
translations.idiomatic: The former King Xin of Han remained King of Han, with his capital at Yangzhai.

sentences.zh: 徙衡山王吳芮為長沙王，都臨湘。

translations.literal: He moved King Wu Rui of Hengshan to be King of Changsha, with his capital at Linxiang.
translations.idiomatic: He moved King Wu Rui of Hengshan to be King of Changsha, with his capital at Linxiang.

sentences.zh: 番君之將梅鋗有功，從入武關，故德番君。

translations.literal: Lord Fan's general Mei Xuan had achievements and followed them entering Wuguan, therefore he favored Lord Fan.
translations.idiomatic: Lord Fan's general Mei Xuan had achievements and followed them entering Wuguan. Therefore he favored Lord Fan.

sentences.zh: 淮南王布、燕王臧荼、趙王敖皆如故。

translations.literal: King Bu of Huainan, King Zang Tu of Yan, and King Ao of Zhao all remained as before.
translations.idiomatic: King Bu of Huainan, King Zang Tu of Yan, and King Ao of Zhao all remained as before.

translations.literal: The Emperor said the Righteous Emperor had no descendants. King Han Xin of Qi was familiar with Chu customs and was moved to be King of Chu, with his capital at Xiapei. He installed Marquis of Jiancheng Peng Yue as King of Liang, with his capital at Dingtao. The former King Xin of Han remained King of Han, with his capital at Yangzhai. He moved King Wu Rui of Hengshan to be King of Changsha, with his capital at Linxiang. Lord Fan's general Mei Xuan had achievements and followed them entering Wuguan, therefore he favored Lord Fan. King Bu of Huainan, King Zang Tu of Yan, and King Ao of Zhao all remained as before.

sentences.zh: 天下大定。

translations.literal: All under Heaven was greatly settled.
translations.idiomatic: All under Heaven was greatly settled.

sentences.zh: 高祖都雒陽，諸侯皆臣屬。

translations.literal: Gao Zu made capital Luoyang, feudal lords all became ministers subordinates.
translations.idiomatic: Gao Zu made capital Luoyang. Feudal lords all became ministers and subordinates.

sentences.zh: 故臨江王驩為項羽叛漢，令盧綰、劉賈圍之，不下。

translations.literal: The former King Huan of Linjiang rebelled against Han for Xiang Yu; he ordered Lu Wan and Liu Jia to besiege him, but he did not surrender.
translations.idiomatic: The former King Huan of Linjiang rebelled against Han for Xiang Yu. He ordered Lu Wan and Liu Jia to besiege him, but he did not surrender.

sentences.zh: 數月而降，殺之雒陽。

translations.literal: After several months he surrendered and they killed him at Luoyang.
translations.idiomatic: After several months he surrendered and they killed him at Luoyang.

translations.literal: All under Heaven was greatly settled. Gao Zu made capital Luoyang, feudal lords all became ministers subordinates. The former King Huan of Linjiang rebelled against Han for Xiang Yu; he ordered Lu Wan and Liu Jia to besiege him, but he did not surrender. After several months he surrendered and they killed him at Luoyang.

sentences.zh: 五月，兵皆罷歸家。

translations.literal: In the fifth month, all troops were dismissed to return home.
translations.idiomatic: In the fifth month, all troops were dismissed to return home.

sentences.zh: 諸侯子在關中者復之十二歲，其歸者復之六歲，食之一歲。

translations.literal: Sons of feudal lords who were in Guanzhong were exempted from taxes for twelve years; those who returned were exempted for six years and provided food for one year.
translations.idiomatic: Sons of feudal lords who were in Guanzhong were exempted from taxes for twelve years. Those who returned were exempted for six years and provided food for one year.

translations.literal: In the fifth month, all troops were dismissed to return home. Sons of feudal lords who were in Guanzhong were exempted from taxes for twelve years; those who returned were exempted for six years and provided food for one year.

sentences.zh: 高祖置酒雒陽南宮。

translations.literal: Gao Zu held a banquet at the Southern Palace of Luoyang.
translations.idiomatic: Gao Zu held a banquet at the Southern Palace of Luoyang.

sentences.zh: 高祖曰：「列侯諸將無敢隱朕，皆言其情。

translations.literal: Gao Zu said: "Ranked marquises and various generals, do not hide from me; all speak your true feelings.
translations.idiomatic: Gao Zu said: 'Ranked marquises and various generals, do not hide from me. All speak your true feelings.'

sentences.zh: 吾所以有天下者何？

translations.literal: Why is it that I possess all under Heaven?
translations.idiomatic: Why is it that I possess all under Heaven?

sentences.zh: 項氏之所以失天下者何？」

translations.literal: Why is it that the Xiang clan lost all under Heaven?"
translations.idiomatic: Why is it that the Xiang clan lost all under Heaven?''

sentences.zh: 高起、王陵對曰：「陛下慢而侮人，項羽仁而愛人。

translations.literal: Gao Qi and Wang Ling replied: "Your Majesty is informal and makes light of people; Xiang Yu was benevolent and loved people.
translations.idiomatic: Gao Qi and Wang Ling replied: 'Your Majesty is informal and makes light of people. Xiang Yu was benevolent and loved people.'

sentences.zh: 然陛下使人攻城略地，所降下者因以予之，與天下同利也。

translations.literal: Yet Your Majesty has men attack cities and take territory; those who are subdued and surrender are consequently given it—you share benefits with all under Heaven.
translations.idiomatic: Yet Your Majesty has men attack cities and take territory. Those who are subdued and surrender are consequently given it—you share benefits with all under Heaven.'

sentences.zh: 項羽妒賢嫉能，有功者害之，賢者疑之，戰勝而不予人功，得地而不予人利，此所以失天下也。」

translations.literal: Xiang Yu was jealous of the worthy and envious of the able; those with achievements he harmed, the worthy he suspected; when battles were won he would not give others credit, when territory was obtained he would not give others benefits—this is why he lost all under Heaven."
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu was jealous of the worthy and envious of the able. Those with achievements he harmed, the worthy he suspected. When battles were won he would not give others credit, when territory was obtained he would not give others benefits—this is why he lost all under Heaven.''

sentences.zh: 高祖曰：「公知其一，未知其二。

translations.literal: Gao Zu said: "You know one aspect but do not know the second.
translations.idiomatic: Gao Zu said: 'You know one aspect but do not know the second.'

sentences.zh: 夫運籌策帷帳之中，決勝於千里之外，吾不如子房。

translations.literal: In devising strategies within the command tent and deciding victory a thousand li away, I am not equal to Zifang.
translations.idiomatic: In devising strategies within the command tent and deciding victory a thousand li away, I am not equal to Zifang.'

sentences.zh: 鎮國家，撫百姓，給餽馕，不絕糧道，吾不如蕭何。

translations.literal: In stabilizing the state, comforting the hundred clans, providing provisions and grain, and not severing the supply routes, I am not equal to Xiao He.
translations.idiomatic: In stabilizing the state, comforting the hundred clans, providing provisions and grain, and not severing the supply routes, I am not equal to Xiao He.'

sentences.zh: 連百萬之軍，戰必勝，攻必取，吾不如韓信。

translations.literal: In commanding armies of a million, certainly winning battles and certainly taking what is attacked, I am not equal to Han Xin.
translations.idiomatic: In commanding armies of a million, certainly winning battles and certainly taking what is attacked, I am not equal to Han Xin.'

sentences.zh: 此三者，皆人傑也，吾能用之，此吾所以取天下也。

translations.literal: These three are all heroes among men, and I was able to employ them—this is why I took all under Heaven.
translations.idiomatic: These three are all heroes among men, and I was able to employ them—this is why I took all under Heaven.'

sentences.zh: 項羽有一范增而不能用，此其所以為我擒也。」

translations.literal: Xiang Yu had one Fan Zeng but could not employ him—this is why he became my captive."
translations.idiomatic: Xiang Yu had one Fan Zeng but could not employ him—this is why he became my captive.''

translations.literal: Gao Zu held a banquet at the Southern Palace of Luoyang. Gao Zu said: "Ranked marquises and various generals, do not hide from me; all speak your true feelings. Why is it that I possess all under Heaven? Why is it that the Xiang clan lost all under Heaven?" Gao Qi and Wang Ling replied: "Your Majesty is informal and makes light of people; Xiang Yu was benevolent and loved people. Yet Your Majesty has men attack cities and take territory; those who are subdued and surrender are consequently given it—you share benefits with all under Heaven. Xiang Yu was jealous of the worthy and envious of the able; those with achievements he harmed, the worthy he suspected; when battles were won he would not give others credit, when territory was obtained he would not give others benefits—this is why he lost all under Heaven." Gao Zu said: "You know one aspect but do not know the second. In devising strategies within the command tent and deciding victory a thousand li away, I am not equal to Zifang. In stabilizing the state, comforting the hundred clans, providing provisions and grain, and not severing the supply routes, I am not equal to Xiao He. In commanding armies of a million, certainly winning battles and certainly taking what is attacked, I am not equal to Han Xin. These three are all heroes among men, and I was able to employ them—this is why I took all under Heaven. Xiang Yu had one Fan Zeng but could not employ him—this is why he became my captive."

sentences.zh: 高祖欲長都雒陽，齊人劉敬說，乃留侯勸上入都關中，高祖是日駕，入都關中。

translations.literal: Gao Zu wished to make Luoyang his permanent capital; the Qi man Liu Jing persuaded him, and the Marquis of Liu urged the superior to make his capital within the passes; Gao Zu that very day took his carriage and went in to make his capital within the passes.
translations.idiomatic: Gao Zu wished to make Luoyang his permanent capital. The Qi man Liu Jing persuaded him, and the Marquis of Liu urged the superior to make his capital within the passes. Gao Zu that very day took his carriage and went in to make his capital within the passes.

sentences.zh: 六月，大赦天下。

translations.literal: In the sixth month, they granted a great amnesty to all under Heaven.
translations.idiomatic: In the sixth month, they granted a great amnesty to all under Heaven.

translations.literal: Gao Zu wished to make Luoyang his permanent capital; the Qi man Liu Jing persuaded him, and the Marquis of Liu urged the superior to make his capital within the passes; Gao Zu that very day took his carriage and went in to make his capital within the passes. In the sixth month, they granted a great amnesty to all under Heaven.

sentences.zh: 十月，燕王臧荼反，攻下代地。

translations.literal: In the tenth month, King Zang Tu of Yan rebelled and attacked and took the land of Dai.
translations.idiomatic: In the tenth month, King Zang Tu of Yan rebelled and attacked and took the land of Dai.

sentences.zh: 高祖自將擊之，得燕王臧荼。

translations.literal: Gao Zu personally commanded to strike him and captured King Zang Tu of Yan.
translations.idiomatic: Gao Zu personally commanded to strike him and captured King Zang Tu of Yan.

sentences.zh: 即立太尉盧綰為燕王。

translations.literal: He immediately installed Grand Commandant Lu Wan as King of Yan.
translations.idiomatic: He immediately installed Grand Commandant Lu Wan as King of Yan.

sentences.zh: 使丞相噲將兵攻代。

translations.literal: He sent Prime Minister Kuai to lead troops to attack Dai.
translations.idiomatic: He sent Prime Minister Kuai to lead troops to attack Dai.

translations.literal: In the tenth month, King Zang Tu of Yan rebelled and attacked and took the land of Dai. Gao Zu personally commanded to strike him and captured King Zang Tu of Yan. He immediately installed Grand Commandant Lu Wan as King of Yan. He sent Prime Minister Kuai to lead troops to attack Dai.

sentences.zh: 其秋，利幾反，高祖自將兵擊之，利幾走。

translations.literal: That autumn, Li Ji rebelled; Gao Zu personally led troops to strike him; Li Ji fled.
translations.idiomatic: That autumn, Li Ji rebelled. Gao Zu personally led troops to strike him. Li Ji fled.

sentences.zh: 利幾者，項氏之將。

translations.literal: Li Ji was a general of the Xiang clan.
translations.idiomatic: Li Ji was a general of the Xiang clan.

sentences.zh: 項氏敗，利幾為陳公，不隨項羽，亡降高祖，高祖侯之潁川。

translations.literal: When the Xiang clan was defeated, Li Ji was Duke of Chen and did not follow Xiang Yu; he fled and surrendered to Gao Zu, and Gao Zu made him a marquis at Yingchuan.
translations.idiomatic: When the Xiang clan was defeated, Li Ji was Duke of Chen and did not follow Xiang Yu. He fled and surrendered to Gao Zu, and Gao Zu made him a marquis at Yingchuan.

sentences.zh: 高祖至雒陽，舉通侯籍召之，而利幾恐，故反。

translations.literal: When Gao Zu reached Luoyang, he raised the register of ranked marquises and summoned him; Li Ji was afraid and therefore rebelled.
translations.idiomatic: When Gao Zu reached Luoyang, he raised the register of ranked marquises and summoned him. Li Ji was afraid and therefore rebelled.

translations.literal: That autumn, Li Ji rebelled; Gao Zu personally led troops to strike him; Li Ji fled. Li Ji was a general of the Xiang clan. When the Xiang clan was defeated, Li Ji was Duke of Chen and did not follow Xiang Yu; he fled and surrendered to Gao Zu, and Gao Zu made him a marquis at Yingchuan. When Gao Zu reached Luoyang, he raised the register of ranked marquises and summoned him; Li Ji was afraid and therefore rebelled.

sentences.zh: 六年，高祖五日一朝太公，如家人父子禮。

translations.literal: In the sixth year, Gao Zu every five days would have an audience with the Grand Duke, following the rites of father and son in an ordinary family.
translations.idiomatic: In the sixth year, Gao Zu every five days would have an audience with the Grand Duke, following the rites of father and son in an ordinary family.

sentences.zh: 太公家令說太公曰：「天無二日，土無二王。

translations.literal: The Grand Duke's steward persuaded the Grand Duke, saying: "Heaven has no two suns; the land has no two kings.
translations.idiomatic: The Grand Duke's steward persuaded the Grand Duke, saying: 'Heaven has no two suns. The land has no two kings.'

sentences.zh: 今高祖雖子，人主也；

translations.literal: Now though Gao Zu is your son, he is the lord of men;
translations.idiomatic: Now though Gao Zu is your son, he is the lord of men;'

sentences.zh: 太公雖父，人臣也。

translations.literal: though the Grand Duke is his father, you are a minister of men.
translations.idiomatic: though the Grand Duke is his father, you are a minister of men.'

sentences.zh: 柰何令人主拜人臣！

translations.literal: How can you have the lord of men bow to a minister of men!
translations.idiomatic: How can you have the lord of men bow to a minister of men!''

sentences.zh: 如此，則威重不行。」

translations.literal: If this continues, authority and dignity will not function."
translations.idiomatic: If this continues, authority and dignity will not function.''

sentences.zh: 後高祖朝，太公擁篲，迎門卻行。

translations.literal: Later when Gao Zu came to audience, the Grand Duke held a broom, welcomed him at the gate, and walked backward.
translations.idiomatic: Later when Gao Zu came to audience, the Grand Duke held a broom, welcomed him at the gate, and walked backward.

sentences.zh: 高祖大驚，下扶太公。

translations.literal: Gao Zu was greatly shocked and got down to support the Grand Duke.
translations.idiomatic: Gao Zu was greatly shocked and got down to support the Grand Duke.

sentences.zh: 太公曰：「帝，人主也，柰何以我亂天下法！」

translations.literal: The Grand Duke said: "The Emperor is the lord of men—how can you use me to disorder the laws of all under Heaven!"
translations.idiomatic: The Grand Duke said: 'The Emperor is the lord of men—how can you use me to disorder the laws of all under Heaven!'

sentences.zh: 於是高祖乃尊太公為太上皇。

translations.literal: Thereupon Gao Zu then honored the Grand Duke as Grand Supreme Sovereign.
translations.idiomatic: Thereupon Gao Zu then honored the Grand Duke as Grand Supreme Sovereign.

sentences.zh: 心善家令言，賜金五百斤。

translations.literal: In heart approved steward words, bestowed five hundred jin gold.
translations.idiomatic: In his heart he approved the steward's words and bestowed five hundred jin of gold.

translations.literal: In the sixth year, Gao Zu every five days would have an audience with the Grand Duke, following the rites of father and son in an ordinary family. The Grand Duke's steward persuaded the Grand Duke, saying: "Heaven has no two suns; the land has no two kings. Now though Gao Zu is your son, he is the lord of men; though the Grand Duke is his father, you are a minister of men. How can you have the lord of men bow to a minister of men! If this continues, authority and dignity will not function." Later when Gao Zu came to audience, the Grand Duke held a broom, welcomed him at the gate, and walked backward. Gao Zu was greatly shocked and got down to support the Grand Duke. The Grand Duke said: "The Emperor is the lord of men—how can you use me to disorder the laws of all under Heaven!" Thereupon Gao Zu then honored the Grand Duke as Grand Supreme Sovereign. In heart approved steward words, bestowed five hundred jin gold.

sentences.zh: 十二月，人有上變事告楚王信謀反，上問左右，左右爭欲擊之。

translations.literal: In the twelfth month, someone submitted a report accusing the King of Chu Xin of plotting rebellion; the superior asked those around him, and those around him competed to attack him.
translations.idiomatic: In the twelfth month, someone submitted a report accusing the King of Chu Xin of plotting rebellion. The superior asked those around him, and those around him competed to attack him.

sentences.zh: 用陳平計，乃偽遊雲夢，會諸侯於陳，楚王信迎，即因執之。

translations.literal: Using Chen Ping's plan, he then pretended to make a tour to Yunmeng and assembled the feudal lords at Chen; the King of Chu Xin came to welcome him and was consequently seized.
translations.idiomatic: Using Chen Ping's plan, he then pretended to make a tour to Yunmeng and assembled the feudal lords at Chen. The King of Chu Xin came to welcome him and was consequently seized.

sentences.zh: 是日，大赦天下。

translations.literal: That day, they granted a great amnesty to all under Heaven.
translations.idiomatic: That day, they granted a great amnesty to all under Heaven.

sentences.zh: 田肯賀，因說高祖曰：「陛下得韓信，又治秦中。

translations.literal: Tian Ken congratulated him and consequently persuaded Gao Zu, saying: "Your Majesty has obtained Han Xin and also governs the Qin heartland.
translations.idiomatic: Tian Ken congratulated him and consequently persuaded Gao Zu, saying: 'Your Majesty has obtained Han Xin and also governs the Qin heartland.'

sentences.zh: 秦，形勝之國，帶河山之險，縣隔千里，持戟百萬，秦得百二焉。

translations.literal: Qin is a state of natural advantage, girded by the dangers of rivers and mountains, separated by a thousand li, wielding a million halberds—Qin obtains a hundred to two advantage.
translations.idiomatic: Qin is a state of natural advantage, girded by the dangers of rivers and mountains, separated by a thousand li, wielding a million halberds—Qin obtains a hundred to two advantage.

sentences.zh: 地勢便利，其以下兵於諸侯，譬猶居高屋之上建瓴水也。

translations.literal: The terrain is convenient and advantageous; using it to send down troops against the feudal lords is like residing atop a tall building pouring water from a roof."
translations.idiomatic: The terrain is convenient and advantageous; using it to send down troops against the feudal lords is like residing atop a tall building pouring water from a roof.''

sentences.zh: 夫齊，東有瑯邪、即墨之饒，南有泰山之固，西有濁河之限，北有勃海之利。

translations.literal: As for Qi, to the east it has the wealth of Langye and Jimo, to the south the stronghold of Mount Tai, to the west the barrier of the Turbid River, to the north the benefits of the Bohai.
translations.idiomatic: As for Qi, to the east it has the wealth of Langye and Jimo, to the south the stronghold of Mount Tai, to the west the barrier of the Turbid River, to the north the benefits of the Bohai.

sentences.zh: 地方二千里，持戟百萬，縣隔千里之外，齊得十二焉。

translations.literal: Its territory is two thousand li square, wielding a million halberds, separated a thousand li away—Qi obtains a ten to two advantage.
translations.idiomatic: Its territory is two thousand li square, wielding a million halberds, separated a thousand li away—Qi obtains a ten to two advantage.

sentences.zh: 故此東西秦也。

translations.literal: Therefore this is the eastern Qin.
translations.idiomatic: Therefore this is the eastern Qin.

sentences.zh: 非親子弟，莫可使王齊矣。」

translations.literal: Unless it is your own sons and younger brothers, none should be sent to be king of Qi."
translations.idiomatic: Unless it is your own sons and younger brothers, none should be sent to be king of Qi.''

sentences.zh: 高祖曰：「善。」

translations.literal: Gao Zu said: "Excellent."
translations.idiomatic: Gao Zu said: 'Excellent.''

sentences.zh: 賜黃金五百斤。

translations.literal: He bestowed five hundred jin of gold.
translations.idiomatic: He bestowed five hundred jin of gold.

translations.literal: In the twelfth month, someone submitted a report accusing the King of Chu Xin of plotting rebellion; the superior asked those around him, and those around him competed to attack him. Using Chen Ping's plan, he then pretended to make a tour to Yunmeng and assembled the feudal lords at Chen; the King of Chu Xin came to welcome him and was consequently seized. That day, they granted a great amnesty to all under Heaven. Tian Ken congratulated him and consequently persuaded Gao Zu, saying: "Your Majesty has obtained Han Xin and also governs the Qin heartland. Qin is a state of natural advantage, girded by the dangers of rivers and mountains, separated by a thousand li, wielding a million halberds—Qin obtains a hundred to two advantage. The terrain is convenient and advantageous; using it to send down troops against the feudal lords is like residing atop a tall building pouring water from a roof." As for Qi, to the east it has the wealth of Langye and Jimo, to the south the stronghold of Mount Tai, to the west the barrier of the Turbid River, to the north the benefits of the Bohai. Its territory is two thousand li square, wielding a million halberds, separated a thousand li away—Qi obtains a ten to two advantage. Therefore this is the eastern Qin. Unless it is your own sons and younger brothers, none should be sent to be king of Qi." Gao Zu said: "Excellent." He bestowed five hundred jin of gold.

sentences.zh: 後十餘日，封韓信為淮陰侯，分其地為二國。

translations.literal: After over ten days, he enfeoffed Han Xin as Marquis of Huaiyin and divided his territory into two states.
translations.idiomatic: After over ten days, he enfeoffed Han Xin as Marquis of Huaiyin and divided his territory into two states.

sentences.zh: 高祖曰將軍劉賈數有功，以為荊王，王淮東。

translations.literal: Gao Zu said General Liu Jia had repeatedly achieved merit and made him King of Jing, ruling east of the Huai.
translations.idiomatic: Gao Zu said: 'General Liu Jia has repeatedly achieved merit and made him King of Jing, ruling east of the Huai.'

sentences.zh: 弟交為楚王，王淮西。

translations.literal: His younger brother Jiao became King of Chu, ruling west of the Huai.
translations.idiomatic: His younger brother Jiao became King of Chu, ruling west of the Huai.

sentences.zh: 子肥為齊王，王七十餘城，民能齊言者皆屬齊。

translations.literal: His son Fei became King of Qi, ruling over seventy cities; all people who could speak the Qi language belonged to Qi.
translations.idiomatic: His son Fei became King of Qi, ruling over seventy cities; all people who could speak the Qi language belonged to Qi.

sentences.zh: 乃論功，與諸列侯剖符行封。

translations.literal: He then evaluated merits and with all the ranked marquises divided tallies and carried out enfeoffments.
translations.idiomatic: He then evaluated merits and with all the ranked marquises divided tallies and carried out enfeoffments.

sentences.zh: 徙韓王信太原。

translations.literal: He moved King Xin of Han to Taiyuan.
translations.idiomatic: He moved King Xin of Han to Taiyuan.

translations.literal: After over ten days, he enfeoffed Han Xin as Marquis of Huaiyin and divided his territory into two states. Gao Zu said General Liu Jia had repeatedly achieved merit and made him King of Jing, ruling east of the Huai. His younger brother Jiao became King of Chu, ruling west of the Huai. His son Fei became King of Qi, ruling over seventy cities; all people who could speak the Qi language belonged to Qi. He then evaluated merits and with all the ranked marquises divided tallies and carried out enfeoffments. He moved King Xin of Han to Taiyuan.

sentences.zh: 七年，匈奴攻韓王信馬邑，信因與謀反太原。

translations.literal: In the seventh year, the Xiongnu attacked King Xin of Han at Mayi; Xin consequently plotted rebellion with them at Taiyuan.
translations.idiomatic: In the seventh year, the Xiongnu attacked King Xin of Han at Mayi; Xin consequently plotted rebellion with them at Taiyuan.

sentences.zh: 白土曼丘臣、王黃立故趙將趙利為王以反，高祖自往擊之。

translations.literal: Man Qiu Chen of Baitu and Wang Huang installed the former Zhao general Zhao Li as king to rebel; Gao Zu personally went to strike them.
translations.idiomatic: Man Qiu Chen of Baitu and Wang Huang installed the former Zhao general Zhao Li as king to rebel; Gao Zu personally went to strike them.

sentences.zh: 會天寒，士卒墮指者什二三，遂至平城。

translations.literal: Meeting cold weather, two or three out of ten officers and troops lost fingers; they then reached Pingcheng.
translations.idiomatic: Meeting cold weather, two or three out of ten officers and troops lost fingers; they then reached Pingcheng.

sentences.zh: 匈奴圍我平城，七日而後罷去。

translations.literal: The Xiongnu surrounded us at Pingcheng for seven days before withdrawing.
translations.idiomatic: The Xiongnu surrounded us at Pingcheng for seven days before withdrawing.

sentences.zh: 令樊噲止定代地。

translations.literal: He ordered Fan Kuai to remain and settle the land of Dai.
translations.idiomatic: He ordered Fan Kuai to remain and settle the land of Dai.

sentences.zh: 立兄劉仲為代王。

translations.literal: He installed his elder brother Liu Zhong as King of Dai.
translations.idiomatic: He installed his elder brother Liu Zhong as King of Dai.

translations.literal: In the seventh year, the Xiongnu attacked King Xin of Han at Mayi; Xin consequently plotted rebellion with them at Taiyuan. Man Qiu Chen of Baitu and Wang Huang installed the former Zhao general Zhao Li as king to rebel; Gao Zu personally went to strike them. Meeting cold weather, two or three out of ten officers and troops lost fingers; they then reached Pingcheng. The Xiongnu surrounded us at Pingcheng for seven days before withdrawing. He ordered Fan Kuai to remain and settle the land of Dai. He installed his elder brother Liu Zhong as King of Dai.

sentences.zh: 二月，高祖自平城過趙、雒陽，至長安。

translations.literal: In the second month, Gao Zu from Pingcheng passed through Zhao and Luoyang and reached Chang'an.
translations.idiomatic: In the second month, Gao Zu from Pingcheng passed through Zhao and Luoyang and reached Chang'an.

sentences.zh: 長樂宮成，丞相已下徙治長安。

translations.literal: Changle Palace was completed; the prime minister and below moved to govern at Chang'an.
translations.idiomatic: Changle Palace was completed; the prime minister and below moved to govern at Chang'an.

translations.literal: In the second month, Gao Zu from Pingcheng passed through Zhao and Luoyang and reached Chang'an. Changle Palace was completed; the prime minister and below moved to govern at Chang'an.

sentences.zh: 八年，高祖東擊韓王信餘反寇於東垣。

translations.literal: In the eighth year, Gao Zu went east to strike the remaining rebel bandits of King Xin of Han at Dongyuan.
translations.idiomatic: In the eighth year, Gao Zu went east to strike the remaining rebel bandits of King Xin of Han at Dongyuan.

translations.literal: In the eighth year, Gao Zu went east to strike the remaining rebel bandits of King Xin of Han at Dongyuan.

sentences.zh: 蕭丞相營作未央宮，立東闕、北闕、前殿、武庫、太倉。

translations.literal: Prime Minister Xiao constructed Weiyang Palace, establishing the Eastern Tower, Northern Tower, Front Hall, Armory, and Great Granary.
translations.idiomatic: Prime Minister Xiao constructed Weiyang Palace, establishing the Eastern Tower, Northern Tower, Front Hall, Armory, and Great Granary.

sentences.zh: 高祖還，見宮闕壯甚，怒，謂蕭何曰：「天下匈匈苦戰數歲，成敗未可知，是何治宮室過度也？」

translations.literal: When Gao Zu returned and saw the palace towers were exceedingly grand, he was angry and said to Xiao He: "All under Heaven has suffered bitterly fighting for several years; success or failure cannot yet be known—why do you govern palace chambers to excess?"
translations.idiomatic: When Gao Zu returned and saw the palace towers were exceedingly grand, he was angry and said to Xiao He: 'All under Heaven has suffered bitterly fighting for several years; success or failure cannot yet be known—why do you govern palace chambers to excess?'

sentences.zh: 蕭何曰：「天下方未定，故可因遂就宮室。

translations.literal: Xiao He said: "Precisely because all under Heaven is not yet settled, we can consequently proceed to complete the palace chambers.
translations.idiomatic: Xiao He said: 'Precisely because all under Heaven is not yet settled, we can consequently proceed to complete the palace chambers.'

sentences.zh: 且夫天子四海為家，非壯麗無以重威，且無令後世有以加也。」

translations.literal: Moreover, the Son of Heaven has the four seas as his home; without grandeur and magnificence there is no way to give weight to authority, and moreover we must not allow later generations to have anything to add."
translations.idiomatic: Moreover, the Son of Heaven has the four seas as his home; without grandeur and magnificence there is no way to give weight to authority, and moreover we must not allow later generations to have anything to add.''

sentences.zh: 高祖乃說。

translations.literal: Gao Zu was then pleased.
translations.idiomatic: Gao Zu was then pleased.

translations.literal: Prime Minister Xiao constructed Weiyang Palace, establishing the Eastern Tower, Northern Tower, Front Hall, Armory, and Great Granary. When Gao Zu returned and saw the palace towers were exceedingly grand, he was angry and said to Xiao He: "All under Heaven has suffered bitterly fighting for several years; success or failure cannot yet be known—why do you govern palace chambers to excess?" Xiao He said: "Precisely because all under Heaven is not yet settled, we can consequently proceed to complete the palace chambers. Moreover, the Son of Heaven has the four seas as his home; without grandeur and magnificence there is no way to give weight to authority, and moreover we must not allow later generations to have anything to add." Gao Zu was then pleased.

sentences.zh: 高祖之東垣，過柏人，趙相貫高等謀弒高祖，高祖心動，因不留。

translations.literal: When Gao Zu went to Dongyuan and passed through Bairen, Zhao Prime Minister Guan Gao and others plotted to assassinate Gao Zu; Gao Zu's heart was stirred and consequently he did not remain.
translations.idiomatic: When Gao Zu went to Dongyuan and passed through Bairen, Zhao Prime Minister Guan Gao and others plotted to assassinate Gao Zu; Gao Zu's heart was stirred and consequently he did not remain.

sentences.zh: 代王劉仲棄國亡，自歸雒陽，廢以為合陽侯。

translations.literal: King Liu Zhong of Dai abandoned his state and fled, returning on his own to Luoyang; he was demoted to be Marquis of Heyang.
translations.idiomatic: King Liu Zhong of Dai abandoned his state and fled, returning on his own to Luoyang; he was demoted to be Marquis of Heyang.

translations.literal: When Gao Zu went to Dongyuan and passed through Bairen, Zhao Prime Minister Guan Gao and others plotted to assassinate Gao Zu; Gao Zu's heart was stirred and consequently he did not remain. King Liu Zhong of Dai abandoned his state and fled, returning on his own to Luoyang; he was demoted to be Marquis of Heyang.

sentences.zh: 九年，趙相貫高等事發覺，夷三族。

translations.literal: In the ninth year, the affair of Zhao Prime Minister Guan Gao and others was discovered; their three clans were exterminated.
translations.idiomatic: In the ninth year, the affair of Zhao Prime Minister Guan Gao and others was discovered; their three clans were exterminated.

sentences.zh: 廢趙王敖為宣平侯。

translations.literal: They demoted King Ao of Zhao to be Marquis of Xuanping.
translations.idiomatic: They demoted King Ao of Zhao to be Marquis of Xuanping.

sentences.zh: 是歲，徙貴族楚昭、屈、景、懷、齊田氏關中。

translations.literal: That year, they relocated noble clans—the Zhao, Qu, Jing, and Huai of Chu, and the Tian clan of Qi—to Guanzhong.
translations.idiomatic: That year, they relocated noble clans—the Zhao, Qu, Jing, and Huai of Chu, and the Tian clan of Qi—to Guanzhong.

translations.literal: In the ninth year, the affair of Zhao Prime Minister Guan Gao and others was discovered; their three clans were exterminated. They demoted King Ao of Zhao to be Marquis of Xuanping. That year, they relocated noble clans—the Zhao, Qu, Jing, and Huai of Chu, and the Tian clan of Qi—to Guanzhong.

sentences.zh: 未央宮成。

translations.literal: Weiyang Palace was completed.
translations.idiomatic: Weiyang Palace was completed.

sentences.zh: 高祖大朝諸侯群臣，置酒未央前殿。

translations.literal: Gao Zu held a great court with the feudal lords and assembled ministers and held a banquet in the front hall of Weiyang.
translations.idiomatic: Gao Zu held a great court with the feudal lords and assembled ministers and held a banquet in the front hall of Weiyang.

sentences.zh: 高祖奉玉卮，起為太上皇壽，曰：「始大人常以臣無賴，不能治產業，不如仲力。

translations.literal: Gao Zu presented a jade cup, rose to offer a toast for the Grand Supreme Sovereign, and said: "At first the great man always considered me worthless, unable to manage productive work, not as capable as Zhong.
translations.idiomatic: Gao Zu presented a jade cup, rose to offer a toast for the Grand Supreme Sovereign, and said: 'At first the great man always considered me worthless, unable to manage productive work, not as capable as Zhong.'

sentences.zh: 今某之業所就孰與仲多？」

translations.literal: Now whose achievements are greater, mine or Zhong's?"
translations.idiomatic: Now whose achievements are greater, mine or Zhong's?''

sentences.zh: 殿上群臣皆呼萬歲，大笑為樂。

translations.literal: All the assembled ministers in the hall shouted 'Long live!' and laughed greatly in merriment.
translations.idiomatic: All the assembled ministers in the hall shouted 'Long live!' and laughed greatly in merriment.

translations.literal: Weiyang Palace was completed. Gao Zu held a great court with the feudal lords and assembled ministers and held a banquet in the front hall of Weiyang. Gao Zu presented a jade cup, rose to offer a toast for the Grand Supreme Sovereign, and said: "At first the great man always considered me worthless, unable to manage productive work, not as capable as Zhong. Now whose achievements are greater, mine or Zhong's?" All the assembled ministers in the hall shouted 'Long live!' and laughed greatly in merriment.

sentences.zh: 十年十月，淮南王黥布、梁王彭越、燕王盧綰、荊王劉賈、楚王劉交、齊王劉肥、長沙王吳芮皆來朝長樂宮。

translations.literal: In the tenth month of the tenth year, King Bu of Huainan, King Peng Yue of Liang, King Lu Wan of Yan, King Liu Jia of Jing, King Liu Jiao of Chu, King Liu Fei of Qi, and King Wu Rui of Changsha all came to court at Changle Palace.
translations.idiomatic: In the tenth month of the tenth year, King Bu of Huainan, King Peng Yue of Liang, King Lu Wan of Yan, King Liu Jia of Jing, King Liu Jiao of Chu, King Liu Fei of Qi, and King Wu Rui of Changsha all came to court at Changle Palace.

sentences.zh: 春夏無事。

translations.literal: In spring and summer there were no events.
translations.idiomatic: In spring and summer there were no events.

translations.literal: In the tenth month of the tenth year, King Bu of Huainan, King Peng Yue of Liang, King Lu Wan of Yan, King Liu Jia of Jing, King Liu Jiao of Chu, King Liu Fei of Qi, and King Wu Rui of Changsha all came to court at Changle Palace. In spring and summer there were no events.

sentences.zh: 七月，太上皇崩櫟陽宮。

translations.literal: In the seventh month, the Grand Supreme Sovereign died at Liyang Palace.
translations.idiomatic: In the seventh month, the Grand Supreme Sovereign died at Liyang Palace.

sentences.zh: 楚王、梁王皆來送葬。

translations.literal: The King of Chu and King of Liang both came to attend the funeral.
translations.idiomatic: The King of Chu and King of Liang both came to attend the funeral.

sentences.zh: 赦櫟陽囚。

translations.literal: They pardoned prisoners of Liyang.
translations.idiomatic: They pardoned prisoners of Liyang.

sentences.zh: 更命酈邑曰新豐。

translations.literal: They renamed Li township as Xinfeng.
translations.idiomatic: They renamed Li township as Xinfeng.

translations.literal: In the seventh month, the Grand Supreme Sovereign died at Liyang Palace. The King of Chu and King of Liang both came to attend the funeral. They pardoned prisoners of Liyang. They renamed Li township as Xinfeng.

sentences.zh: 八月，趙相國陳豨反代地。

translations.literal: In the eighth month, Zhao Prime Minister Chen Xi rebelled in the land of Dai.
translations.idiomatic: In the eighth month, Zhao Prime Minister Chen Xi rebelled in the land of Dai.

sentences.zh: 上曰：「豨嘗為吾使，甚有信。

translations.literal: The superior said: "Xi was once my envoy and was very trustworthy.
translations.idiomatic: The superior said: 'Xi was once my envoy and was very trustworthy.'

sentences.zh: 代地吾所急也，故封豨為列侯，以相國守代，今乃與王黃等劫掠代地！

translations.literal: The land of Dai is what I urgently need; therefore I enfeoffed Xi as a ranked marquis to serve as prime minister defending Dai—now he actually joins with Wang Huang and others to rob and plunder the land of Dai!
translations.idiomatic: The land of Dai is what I urgently need; therefore I enfeoffed Xi as a ranked marquis to serve as prime minister defending Dai—now he actually joins with Wang Huang and others to rob and plunder the land of Dai!'

sentences.zh: 代地吏民非有罪也。

translations.literal: The officials and people of the land of Dai are not guilty.
translations.idiomatic: The officials and people of the land of Dai are not guilty.

sentences.zh: 其赦代吏民。」

translations.literal: Pardon the officials and people of Dai."
translations.idiomatic: Pardon the officials and people of Dai.''

sentences.zh: 九月，上自東往擊之。

translations.literal: In the ninth month, the superior personally went east to strike him.
translations.idiomatic: In the ninth month, the superior personally went east to strike him.

sentences.zh: 至邯鄲，上喜曰：「豨不南據邯鄲而阻漳水，吾知其無能為也。」

translations.literal: Reaching Handan, the superior was pleased and said: "Xi did not occupy Handan to the south and block the Zhang River—I know he is incapable."
translations.idiomatic: Reaching Handan, the superior was pleased and said: 'Xi did not occupy Handan to the south and block the Zhang River—I know he is incapable.''

sentences.zh: 聞豨將皆故賈人也，上曰：「吾知所以與之。」

translations.literal: Hearing that Xi's generals were all former merchants, the superior said: "I know how to deal with them."
translations.idiomatic: Hearing that Xi's generals were all former merchants, the superior said: 'I know how to deal with them.''

sentences.zh: 乃多以金啗豨將，豨將多降者。

translations.literal: He then enticed Xi's generals with much gold; many of Xi's generals surrendered.
translations.idiomatic: He then bribed Xi's generals with large sums of gold; many of them surrendered.

translations.literal: In the eighth month, Zhao Prime Minister Chen Xi rebelled in the land of Dai. The superior said: "Xi was once my envoy and was very trustworthy. The land of Dai is what I urgently need; therefore I enfeoffed Xi as a ranked marquis to serve as prime minister defending Dai—now he actually joins with Wang Huang and others to rob and plunder the land of Dai! The officials and people of the land of Dai are not guilty. Pardon the officials and people of Dai." In the ninth month, the superior personally went east to strike him. Reaching Handan, the superior was pleased and said: "Xi did not occupy Handan to the south and block the Zhang River—I know he is incapable." Hearing that Xi's generals were all former merchants, the superior said: "I know how to deal with them." He then enticed Xi's generals with much gold; many of Xi's generals surrendered.

sentences.zh: 十一年，高祖在邯鄲誅豨等未畢，豨將侯敞將萬餘人游行，王黃軍曲逆，張春渡河擊聊城。

translations.literal: In the eleventh year, when Gao Zu at Handan had not yet finished executing Xi and others, Xi's general Hou Chang led over ten thousand men traveling and marching; Wang Huang's army was at Quyi; Zhang Chun crossed the Yellow River to strike Liaocheng.
translations.idiomatic: In the eleventh year, while Gao Zu was still executing Xi and others at Handan, Xi's general Hou Chang led over ten thousand troops in a roaming campaign; Wang Huang's army held Quyi; and Zhang Chun crossed the Yellow River to attack Liaocheng.

sentences.zh: 漢使將軍郭蒙與齊將擊，大破之。

translations.literal: Han sent General Guo Meng with Qi generals to strike and greatly break them.
translations.idiomatic: Han dispatched General Guo Meng along with Qi generals to attack and decisively defeat them.

sentences.zh: 太尉周勃道太原入，定代地。

translations.literal: Grand Commandant Zhou Bo went by way of Taiyuan and entered to settle the land of Dai.
translations.idiomatic: Grand Commandant Zhou Bo passed through Taiyuan and entered Dai territory to pacify it.

sentences.zh: 至馬邑，馬邑不下，即攻殘之。

translations.literal: Reaching Mayi, Mayi would not surrender, so he attacked and devastated it.
translations.idiomatic: When he reached Mayi and the city refused to surrender, he attacked and destroyed it.

translations.literal: In the eleventh year, when Gao Zu at Handan had not yet finished executing Xi and others, Xi's general Hou Chang led over ten thousand men traveling and marching; Wang Huang's army was at Quyi; Zhang Chun crossed the Yellow River to strike Liaocheng. Han sent General Guo Meng with Qi generals to strike and greatly break them. Grand Commandant Zhou Bo went by way of Taiyuan and entered to settle the land of Dai. Reaching Mayi, Mayi would not surrender, so he attacked and devastated it.

sentences.zh: 豨將趙利守東垣，高祖攻之，不下。

translations.literal: Xi's general Zhao Li defended Dongyuan; Gao Zu attacked it but it did not fall.
translations.idiomatic: Xi's general Zhao Li held Dongyuan against Gao Zu's attacks, and the city did not fall.

sentences.zh: 月餘，卒罵高祖，高祖怒。

translations.literal: After over a month, the troops reviled Gao Zu; Gao Zu was angry.
translations.idiomatic: After more than a month, the soldiers cursed Gao Zu, and he became furious.

sentences.zh: 城降，令出罵者斬之，不罵者原之。

translations.literal: When the city surrendered, he ordered those who had reviled to be beheaded; those who had not reviled were pardoned.
translations.idiomatic: When the city finally surrendered, he ordered the execution of those who had cursed him and pardoned those who had not.

sentences.zh: 於是乃分趙山北，立子恒以為代王，都晉陽。

translations.literal: Thereupon he divided the mountains north of Zhao and installed his son Heng as King of Dai, with his capital at Jinyang.
translations.idiomatic: He then divided the territory north of Zhao's mountains and installed his son Heng as King of Dai with his capital at Jinyang.

translations.literal: Xi's general Zhao Li defended Dongyuan; Gao Zu attacked it but it did not fall. After over a month, the troops reviled Gao Zu; Gao Zu was angry. When the city surrendered, he ordered those who had reviled to be beheaded; those who had not reviled were pardoned. Thereupon he divided the mountains north of Zhao and installed his son Heng as King of Dai, with his capital at Jinyang.

sentences.zh: 春，淮陰侯韓信謀反關中，夷三族。

translations.literal: In spring, the Marquis of Huaiyin Han Xin plotted rebellion in Guanzhong; his three clans were exterminated.
translations.idiomatic: In spring, Han Xin, Marquis of Huaiyin, plotted rebellion in Guanzhong and his entire clan was wiped out.

translations.literal: In spring, the Marquis of Huaiyin Han Xin plotted rebellion in Guanzhong; his three clans were exterminated.

sentences.zh: 夏，梁王彭越謀反，廢遷蜀；

translations.literal: In summer, King Peng Yue of Liang plotted rebellion and was demoted and exiled to Shu;
translations.idiomatic: In summer, King Peng Yue of Liang plotted rebellion and was stripped of his title and exiled to Shu;

sentences.zh: 復欲反，遂夷三族。

translations.literal: wishing to rebel again, his three clans were thereupon exterminated.
translations.idiomatic: but when he tried to rebel again, his entire clan was exterminated.

sentences.zh: 立子恢為梁王，子友為淮陽王。

translations.literal: He installed his son Hui as King of Liang and his son You as King of Huaiyang.
translations.idiomatic: He installed his son Hui as King of Liang and his son You as King of Huaiyang.

translations.literal: In summer, King Peng Yue of Liang plotted rebellion and was demoted and exiled to Shu; wishing to rebel again, his three clans were thereupon exterminated. He installed his son Hui as King of Liang and his son You as King of Huaiyang.

sentences.zh: 秋七月，淮南王黥布反，東并荊王劉賈地，北渡淮，楚王交走入薛。

translations.literal: In the seventh month of autumn, King Bu of Huainan rebelled, absorbed the territory of King Liu Jia of Jing to the east, crossed the Huai to the north; the King of Chu Jiao fled and entered Xue.
translations.idiomatic: In the seventh month of autumn, King Bu of Huainan rebelled, annexed King Liu Jia's Jing territory to the east, crossed north over the Huai River, and King Jiao of Chu fled to Xue.

sentences.zh: 高祖自往擊之。

translations.literal: Gao Zu personally went to strike him.
translations.idiomatic: Gao Zu went in person to attack him.

sentences.zh: 立子長為淮南王。

translations.literal: He installed his son Chang as King of Huainan.
translations.idiomatic: He installed his son Chang as King of Huainan.

translations.literal: In the seventh month of autumn, King Bu of Huainan rebelled, absorbed the territory of King Liu Jia of Jing to the east, crossed the Huai to the north; the King of Chu Jiao fled and entered Xue. Gao Zu personally went to strike him. He installed his son Chang as King of Huainan.

sentences.zh: 十二年，十月，高祖已擊布軍會甀，布走，令別將追之。

translations.literal: In the tenth month of the twelfth year, Gao Zu having struck Bu's army met at Kuai; Bu fled and he ordered separate generals to pursue him.
translations.idiomatic: In the tenth month of the twelfth year, after defeating Bu's army and meeting at Kuai, Bu fled and Gao Zu ordered other generals to pursue him.

translations.literal: In the tenth month of the twelfth year, Gao Zu having struck Bu's army met at Kuai; Bu fled and he ordered separate generals to pursue him.

sentences.zh: 高祖還歸，過沛，留。

translations.literal: Gao Zu returned, passing through Pei, and remained.
translations.idiomatic: On his return home, Gao Zu passed through Pei and stayed there.

sentences.zh: 置酒沛宮，悉召故人父老子弟縱酒，發沛中兒得百二十人，教之歌。

translations.literal: He held a banquet at Pei Palace, summoned all his old friends, fathers, elders, sons, and younger brothers to drink without restraint, and gathered one hundred twenty boys from Pei and taught them to sing.
translations.idiomatic: He held a banquet at Pei Palace and summoned all his old friends, family, and elders for unrestrained drinking. He gathered 120 boys from Pei and taught them to sing.

sentences.zh: 酒酣，高祖擊筑，自為歌詩曰：「大風起兮雲飛揚，威加海內兮歸故鄉，安得猛士兮守四方！」

translations.literal: When the wine was flowing, Gao Zu struck the zhu and composed a song himself, saying: "The great wind rises and clouds fly; authority extends over the seas and I return to my native place; where can I find brave men to defend the four quarters!"
translations.idiomatic: As the wine flowed freely, Gao Zu played the zhu and composed his own song: 'A great wind rises, scattering the clouds; my authority spans the realm as I return home. Where can I find brave warriors to guard the four corners?'

sentences.zh: 令兒皆和習之。

translations.literal: He had the boys all harmonize and practice it.
translations.idiomatic: He had all the boys join in the chorus and practice the song.

sentences.zh: 高祖乃起舞，慷慨傷懷，泣數行下。

translations.literal: Gao Zu then rose to dance, impassioned and moved in feeling, weeping tears streaming down.
translations.idiomatic: Gao Zu then began to dance, filled with passion and deep emotion, his tears flowing freely.

sentences.zh: 謂沛父兄曰：「游子悲故鄉。

translations.literal: He said to the fathers and elder brothers of Pei: "A traveler grieves for his native place.
translations.idiomatic: He said to Pei's elders: 'A wanderer longs for his homeland.'

sentences.zh: 吾雖都關中，萬歲後吾魂魄猶樂思沛。

translations.literal: Though I have made my capital in Guanzhong, after ten thousand years my spirit and soul will still delight in longing for Pei.
translations.idiomatic: Though I've established my capital in Guanzhong, even after a thousand years my soul will still yearn for Pei.'

sentences.zh: 且朕自沛公以誅暴逆，遂有天下，其以沛為朕湯沐邑，復其民，世世無有所與。」
